NOTES: A wreck discovered at Black Assarca Island in 1995. It was excavated in 1997, and found to hold a cargo of amphoras.
A cargo ship that ran aground off Mombasa.
A 545-ton Isles-class trawler built for World War II. It ran aground three miles (4.8 km) north of Mombasa.
A Likoni and Mombasa route ferry that capsized due to overcrowding off Kilindini Harbour. 270 people lost their lives.
An oil tanker that was damaged in a storm, spilling several thousand tonnes of oil.
An American-built extreme clipper sold to Havana and put to work in the slave trade. It was captured by the Royal Navy and used as a store ship, before striking a reef and sinking at Mayotte.
A cruise ship that was hijacked in 1985 by the Palestine Liberation Front. It ultimately sank after an explosion in the engine room started a fire that engulfed the ship.
A Type IXD2 U-boat that was attacked by British aircraft and run aground near Bayla.
A Königsberg-class light cruiser that was sunk in the Rufiji River.
A Pelorus-class protected cruiser that was sunk at Zanzibar by SMS Königsberg.
A RORO ferry that sank between Unguja and Pemba Island, with the loss of at least 200 lives.
A Lake Victoria ferry that sank off Mwanza with over 200 confirmed dead.
A train ferry that collided with MV Kaawa near the Ssese Islands.
A British ferry named after Robert Coryndon, Governor of Uganda (1918–22).
A galley that was captained by William Kidd, who ordered it burnt at Île Sainte-Marie.
A Roebuck-class fifth-rate that caught fire and sank off Île Sainte-Marie.
Troop carrier (infantry), former BI cargo liner. Sunk by German aircraft off Bougie (Béjaïa).
An Algerine-class minesweeper that was torpedoed by the Italian submarine Ascianghi off Béjaïa.
A troopship that was torpedoed by the German submarine U-375.
Narkunda British P&O requisitioned troopship bombed and sunk by German aircraft. Sister ship Naldera. Located off Bougie (Béjaïa), Algeria, passing Cape Carbon.
A Black Swan-class sloop that was sunk by an Italian aircraft north of Algiers.
A troopship that was sunk by the German submarine U-331 off Algiers.
A Flower-class corvette that was sunk by German aircraft near Mostaganem.
A British troop carrier sunk north of Béjaïa in an air attack during World War II.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by an Italian submarine off Béjaïa.
A Strath-class liner that was being used as a troop transport was sunk by a German submarine off the coast of Algeria.
An Acheron-class destroyer that was sunk northwest of Alexandria.
A D-class destroyer that was attacked by a German bomber and sank under tow off Sidi Barrani.
A Z-class destroyer that was sunk by Israeli aircraft in Foul Bay.
An Océan-class ship of the line and Napoleon's flagship, destroyed by fire and explosion in Aboukir Bay during the Battle of the Nile.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-568 about 100 nautical miles west of Alexandria.
A cargo ship that ran aground on a reef at Ras Muhammad.
A roll-on/roll-off passenger ferry that ran aground at midnight on a reef near Safaga, sinking rapidly with the loss of at least 464 civilians.
A D-class destroyer that was sunk by German bombers east of Tobruk.
An Insect-class gunboat that was sunk by German dive bombers at Tobruk.
A passenger and cargo liner that was torpedoed by the German submarine U-559 east of Tobruk.
A Tribal-class destroyer that was sunk by shore batteries off Tobruk.
An Erebus-class monitor that was attacked by German aircraft and sank under tow off Derna.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was attacked by a British aircraft and scuttled north of Bardia.
A troopship that was torpedoed by the German submarine U-81 northwest of Derna.

An American merchant ship that ran aground off Cape Bojador in what is now the Western Sahara. The surviving crew, led by Captain James Riley, were subsequently captured and taken as slaves by local tribes.
A steamship that ran aground in heavy fog. The Duke of Fife was rescued from the sinking ship, but contracted pleurisy and died soon afterward.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by the U-77 off Morocco.
A Hugh L. Scott-class troopship that was torpedoed by U-130 off Casablanca.
A warship that was torpedoed by U-374 in the Straits of Gibraltar.
A Tasker H. Bliss-class troopship that was sunk by U-130 off Casablanca.

The sailing yacht Taube, sailing for the (since abandoned) cultural exploration project Migrobirdo, capsized in heavy swell on the approach to the port of Mehdya on the Sebou River. Six youths of different nationalities drowned, while one German female survived. An investigation concluded that several factors contributed to the accident, including an untrained skipper, an inexperienced crew, overloading, and the absence of a clear line of command.
A Type IXC U-boat that was sunk by American destroyers off Casablanca.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by HMS Mallow and HMS Rochester near Tangier.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by British ships north of Tangier.
A Type VIIC U-boat that came under attack from British forces and was scuttled north of Tangier.
A H-class destroyer that ran aground off Kelibia.
A H-class destroyer that struck a mine and was scuttled off Cap Bon.
An ancient shipwreck discovered near Mahdia in 1907. It is thought to date from around 80 BC.
A Town-class light cruiser that was sunk during Operation Pedestal.
A PC-461-class submarine chaser that sank off Bizerte.
A Lapwing-class minesweeper that capsized off Bizerte.
A Malawian ship owned by the Nyasaland Railway Company that set sail from Monkey Bay to Chilumba in Karonga, Malawi in 1946. It capsized en route with no body recoveries.
A Portuguese nau that set sail from Lisbon in 1533. It was discovered in 2008 on the coast near Oranjemund.
A refrigerator ship that ran aground on the Skeleton Coast, 80 kilometres (50 mi) south of the Cunene River.
A freighter that ran aground south of Conception Bay.

A Durban steamer that ran aground on a sandbank in dense fog, about 18 kilometres (11 mi) north of Swakopmund. The crew were unharmed and were able to get off the ship once the area's coast guard arrived and allowed everyone off.
A steamer that ran aground in Spencer Bay.
The cargo ship ran aground at Lüderitz, Namibia.
The ship ran aground 14 km south of Henties Bay, Namibia.

A Dutch East Indiaman carrying copper duits, silver bars, and gold ducats, which hit a reef twenty-one kilometres (13 mi) from the eastern coast of Africa and 190 kilometres (120 mi) south of the Portuguese settlement of Mozambique. The wreck was discovered in 1986.
After placing a distress call to Durban Radio at 10:30 pm requesting immediate assistance due to a leak in a hold, the freighter sank off Port St JohnsSouth Africa, with the loss of all 23 lives.
An East Indiaman that was wrecked at Bird Island in Algoa Bay.
An East Indiaman that was wrecked off the Pondoland coast.
A Greek bulk carrier wrecked at Cape Recife near Port Elizabeth
A bulk carrier that was stranded northeast of Port Alfred.
A fishing trawler that sank near St Francis Bay.
A cruise liner that sank off the Transkei coast, after leaving East London en route to Durban.
A Portuguese vessel wrecked at Sardinia Bay near Port Elizabeth
A combined ocean liner/cruise ship that sank off Cape St. Francis while under tow to be scrapped.
Stranded southwest of East London.
An Odin-class submarine that was scuttled off Durban.
A tanker that ran aground near Ballito on 26 July 2011, and was then refloated and scuttled offshore.
A barque that was stranded in the Bushman River.
A British East Indiaman, requisitioned for troop transport, wrecked near Waenhuiskrans.
A British iron-hulled troopship that struck a submerged rock near Gansbaai. The chivalry of the soldiers in abandoning ship gave rise to the "women and children first" protocol.
A Derrick/Lay Barge that ran aground on Duiker point after breaking loose while being towed around the Cape Peninsula by the tug Tigr in a storm.
A three-masted iron sailing ship that ran aground near the Cape of Good Hope.
A wooden 3-masted full-rigged sailing ship that caught fire and sank south of the Cape of Good Hope, with a loss of 369 lives.
A 44-gun Roebuck-class ship laid down in 1780. Severely damaged by an iceberg, the ship was sailed 400 leagues (1,900 km) to the Cape of Good Hope, where it was intentionally grounded.
A cargo ship that ran aground near Cape Town, and was re-floated and scuttled 320 kilometres (200 mi) from shore.
An East Indiaman (the first to be wrecked off the South African coast) that sank near Cape Agulhas. A considerable amount of gold was on the ship.
A Prussian barque that ran ashore due to navigational error near Muizenberg.
A British 665-ton schooner-rigged steamship built in 1898 by the Grangemouth Dockyard Company
A Shaw Savill Line steamship that was wrecked near Llandudno, Cape Town.
A fishing trawler that sank near Cape Aghulas.
A coastal trading vessel that sunk near Olifantsbos Bay.
A bulk carrier that sank near Saldanha Bay.

A British Algerine-class minesweeper built in 1943. It was renamed SAS Pietermarizburg in 1947, and at the end of its career was scuttled to make an artificial reef at Miller's Point near Simon's Town.
A merchant vessel that was wrecked near Simon's Town.
A South African frigate that sank in deep water after a collision with its refueling ship, SAS Tafelberg.
A Portuguese slave ship that was wrecked on the rocks off Cape Town, resulting in the deaths of over 200 slaves. The wreck was rediscovered in the 1980s, but was not identified until 2015.
A 64-gun third-rate ship of the line of the Royal Navy that was blown ashore in Table Bay by a gale, with heavy losses.
A Turkish bulk carrier carrying coal that ran aground on Bloubergstrand near Table Bay.
A Dutch ship of the line that was scuttled near Simon's Town to prevent her falling into enemy hands following the Battle of Blaauwberg.
Stranded in Shell Bay on Robben Island.

A former Mersey-class protected cruiser that became famous as SATS General Botha, a merchant naval training ship. After retiring as a training ship, it reverted to its original name and was sunk in False Bay near Simon's Town as a target.
A Houston-built munitions carrier that ran ashore on Oliphantsbos Point, near Cape Point.
A bulk ore carrier that developed a hole in its hull and sank under tow northwest of Cape Town, causing an oil spill that killed around 2,000 endangered African penguins.
An oil tanker that grounded near Cape Agulhas, causing an oil spill. The ship was later refloated, towed out to sea, and re-sunk to avoid further contamination of the coastline.
A British convict ship that was driven ashore in Table Bay by a storm, together with the troop transport Abercrombie Robinson.
An East Indiaman that was wrecked off the Banana Islands, Sierra Leone. The wreck was rediscovered in 2014.
An East Indiaman that ran aground off Cape Verde following a mutiny.
A Nigerian and Port Harcourt to Nembe route ferry that capsized in rough sea off Port Harcourt. At least 100 people were killed.
A Senegalese passenger ship that capsized off the coast of the Gambia.
A French passenger ship that sank near Bank of Arguin. The traumatic experience of the stranded passengers and crew was immortalized in Géricault's painting, The Raft of the Medusa.
A Norwegian patrol boat that served in WWII before being sold off to civilian ownership as a fishing vessel.
A French Duguay-Trouin-class light cruiser, laid down in 1923, that was sunk by gunfire from USS Massachusetts.
A full-rigged ship that sank off Dakar.

The Spanish galleon Santo Cristo de Burgos wrecked on Nehalem Spit en route from Manila to Acapulco, loaded with a cargo of beeswax. The existence of the wreck was recorded in native oral history, with descendants of survivors including Chief Kilchis. It the earliest known shipwreck in the Pacific Northwest.
Grounded on Clatsop Spit and wrecked in heavy seas
Bumped ground putting out of the Columbia River. Crew abandoned ship after she took on 7 feet (210 cm) of water. Ship drifted south and ran aground at Tillamook Head.
Refloated.
Wrecked on sand spit near Tillamook Bar. Refloated.
All 16 humans on board died; the only survivor was the ship's dog.
Wrecked on Tillamook Bar. Parts washed up at Nehalem.
Stranded on Nestucca Bar.
Ran aground in Nestucca Bay.
Wrecked at the mouth of the Nehalem River.
Wrecked near Cape Meares Lighthouse.
Total loss
Wrecked on Tillamook Bar.

Went ashore on north spit of Tillamook Bar. Refloated and towed back to San Francisco for repairs, but during a gale abandoned at a point ten miles SWW of Crescent City.   Ran aground on July 17 at the Klamath River for a total loss.
Remains can still be seen when erosion takes place.
Stranded on Nehalem Spit, refloated and scrapped.
Ran aground on the beach near the Tillamook Bay north jetty.
Remains can still be seen.
Wrecked on the north spit at the entrance to Nestucca harbor.
built 1887 in Benicia, CA for salmon packer. Wrecked at Nehalem River.
Loaded with 2,100 tons of coal, the ship ran ashore and broke apart. The captain, his wife and seven crewmen survived, but eight died. Remains are occasionally seen after storms.
Wrecked at Nehalem Bar.
Wrecked on Tillamook Bar. While waiting for tug into harbor, wind shifted and she was pushed ashore for a total loss.
Struck the bar off the entrance to Tillamook Bay and foundered. Two crew and two passengers were drowned. Sister ship, the Argo #2, a river steamer, went down at Dixon Entrance in Alaska.
Lost rudder and broke to pieces on Tillamook Bar.
Hole punched in hull by underwater rock. The crew attempted to plug the hole with a spare fuel tank. Though the effort was ultimately futile, the crew was rescued.
Stranded on the south side of the Nehalem Bar. Salvaged.
Ran aground in fog on Nehalem Spit, then capsized in salvage operation, killing 17.
Sailed into the rocks at the base of Neahkahnie Mountain, on a clear day. All survived, but rocks penetrated the hull and little was salvaged. A naval court of inquiry ruled the cause was negligence.

Lost in a gale due to being overloaded. Two survived, but the 60 who were lost make it the worst maritime disaster in Oregon history. The railroad ties that were its cargo were used for construction in Manzanita when they washed ashore.
Abandoned at sea. After running ashore, it was refloated and renamed the Mary Hanlon. Ultimately lost off Mendocino, California.
Foundered off Neahkahnie, washed ashore and covered by sand. Uncovered by a bulldozer in 1949.

Capsized on Nestucca Bar. Captain Adolph Kangiser and his engineer made a swim for shore. The captain felt something tug him down. Kicking hard he managed to free himself. Upon reaching shore, he found part of his boot missing, though he himself was not injured.  The marks on the boots indicated a shark, making him the first shark attack victim in Oregon history.[citation needed]
Capsized on Tillamook Bar. Four died.
Rum-Runner.
Foundered off Tillamook Bar. The engine was ripped out, saving the crew by lightening the ship.
Owned by a man named Gardiner, much of the vessel was salvaged and used in the building of the town of Gardiner, Oregon.
Wrecked at Siletz River while offloading supplies for Indian Affairs. Captain B. Jennings.
Oyster pirate vessel. Sank while being pursued by Annie G. Doyle.
Ran aground at nearly the same location as the pirate vessel Cornelia Terry, which it had pursued half a year prior.
Engines salvaged and installed on the vessel Beaver
No further information.
Salvaged, but later lost at Mendocino, California.
Run into by the steamer Ancon.
Predecessor of the Yaquina Bay. Lost a year later at the same spot, effectively ruining the vessel owners, the Oregon Development Co.
Originally named Caracas. She was the sister ship of the SS Valencia and successor of the Yaquina Bay. Ran aground near the wreckage of the Yaquina City and was declared a total loss.
While sailing to San Francisco from the Columbia River, the Alaskan ran into bad weather and the river going vessel began to fall apart from the stress off Cape Foulweather.

Formerly a brig named the Star of China. Ran aground in 1873, refloated, and converted into a tugboat. Loss not discovered until the next day when debris and one survivor washed ashore. However, he perished before he could reveal the final fate of the Fearless.
Constructed in John Fraser's shipyard on Courtney Bay in Saint John, New Brunswick, in 1877
Burned in Yaquina Bay in Newport.
Ran into a reef while coasting along the shore.
Caught fire off Newport, and drifted north, eventually grounding at what is now Boiler Bay. Boiler Bay was named after the discarded boiler from the J. Marhoffer
Refloated and renamed as the Ozmo.
Ran aground while towing the disabled G.C. Lindauer.
Had a history of wrecks prior to final loss at Reedsport. Came loose and lost soon after the towing Admiral Nicholson wrecked.
Coast guard patrol boat. Lost while attempting to aid the crew of a barge caught on the Yaquina Bar.
As of 1986, portions of her hull were still visible at low tide.
Ran aground at Bandon. While under tow to the Columbia River by the Salvage Chief, she came loose and sank of the coast at Yachats.
Half of the ship. This half was beached before being towed off and sunk by Navy. The other half is at Coos Bay. The ship broke apart at Coos Bay, with the rear portion drifting north.
Grounded several times before being sold.
No further information.
Refloated.
No further information.
No further information.
Grounded at Rogue River. Survivors marched overland to the Willamette Valley.
Survivors established Camp Castaway.
One survivor.
Burned when her cargo of lime ignited.
Refloated. Lost for good later at Punta Maria, California.
Foundered in a gale offshore.
Formerly a Confederate blockade runner named the Gertrude that had been captured.
Sank in bay when its boiler exploded.
Drifted for nine days before being towed into Coos Bay. However, abandoned due to the ship being waterlogged.
Destroyed by on board fire.
Ran aground during storm attempting to enter Coquille River.
Destroyed by fire.
Started breaking up 100 miles (160 km) offshore. Part of hull drifted north and ran aground at the Yaquina jetty.
Previously ran afoul of Columbia Bar after rudder came loose.
Repaired and renamed the Arago. The re-christened Arago sank at the same location.
Abandoned by crew during a storm. Found ran aground the next day.
Struck bar previously in 1891 at same location.
Destroyed by fire prior to launch.
Salvaged and converted into a whaler.
Refloated. Converted into barge.
Collided with the vessel Sea Foam.
Began as a Cape Horn windjammer in 1876, turned into a barge after damage at Cape Blanco in 1906. Sunk to form part of breakwater at Royston, British Columbia in 1946.: 14
Destroyed by forest fire prior to launch.
Abandoned. Final resting spot unknown.
Formally named John S. Kimball and then James Dollar.
Second ship named Fifield.
Destroyed by on board fire.
Originally christened as Hugh Hogan
Wrecked while towing the vessel Ecola. The Ecola survived.
Refloated.

Ran aground at Horsfall Beach in heavy fog missing Coos Bay entrance by a few miles.  During WWII much of the hull was scrapped for iron.  The wreck is partially visible each winter due to seasonal sand movement; more than usual emerged April 2010.
Hit south jetty and ran aground inland.
Scuttled by captain after ship sprang a leak.
Superstructure began to fall apart, incapacitating the ship and crew. Towed by the Active and converted into a barge. Now a part of a breakwater in British Columbia.
Originally christened as Frank D. Stout
Formerly christened Florence Olson. Crew saved by local fishermen.
Torpedoed off Coos Bay by Japanese submarine I-25. Towed north by tug Kenai to attempt salvage. Sank off Grays Harbor several days later.
Torpedoed and sank off Gold Beach by Japanese submarine I-25.
Formerly named the Willamette and California.
Formerly named the Ryder Hanify.
Grounded and burned.
Salvaged by crew of the Salvage Chief and repaired. Sister ship of the Oliver Olson.
Filled with rocks and sank as extension of the south Coquille River jetty. Sister ship of the Cynthia Olson.
After running aground, oil cargo was burned out. Half of the ship remained beached while the other half was taken out to sea and scuttled. Remaining half has since been scrapped.
Filled in as the foundation of a dock.
Struck the revetment on the eastern shore of Coon Island.  Heavy fog prevented the pilot from seeing its red cautionary light.  The 80 passengers and 30 crew members were all saved.

Wrecked on the rocks.  The 160 passengers and most of the freight were landed on the Oregon shore.  Towed in to drydock at Cascade Locks around September 1.  The hull was found to be a "complete wreck."
Tore hole in bottom and sank in ten feet of water.
Struck a rock at what is now known as either Boiler Rapid or Boiler Riffle.
Sunk as an artificial reef.
Sloop under the command of Blackbeard. Ran aground attempting to kedge the Queen Anne's Revenge off the bar near Beaufort Inlet, North Carolina.
American tanker; torpedoed off Hatteras by U-66.
Submarine; Sank off of Cape Hatteras.
Ran aground at Cape Hatteras.
Swedish freighter; torpedoed off Cape Hatteras by U-106.
Steamboat that was scuttled to prevent capture near Elizabeth City.
Torpedoed off Cape Lookout by U-158.
Russian tanker; torpedoed by U-402 off Cape Lookout.
Brazilian freighter; torpedoed off Hatteras by U-155.
Ran aground at Kure Beach.
Q-ship; torpedoed by U-123.
Ironclad warship that sank off Cape Hatteras.
American tanker; torpedoed off Cape Lookout by U-552.
American tanker; torpedoed off Cape Hatteras by U-332.
Capsized off Cape Hatteras.
Sank in Roanoke River near Jamseville after striking a mine while attempting to aid USS Otsego.
Anti-submarine trawler torpedoed by German submarine U-588 off the coast of Ocracoke Island.
Formerly USCGC Antietam; sank off Oregon Inlet in the 1944 Great Atlantic Hurricane.
Iron-hulled sidewheel blockade runner; ran aground in Lockwood's Folly Inlet.
Burned at Elizabeth City.
Nicaraguan freighter; torpedoed off Cape Hatteras by U-576.
Replica of the original HMS Bounty. Sank during Hurricane Sandy with 16 people aboard.
British tanker; torpedoed by U-552 off the coast of Ocracoke Island.
Brazilian passenger and cargo ship; torpedoed by U-432.
Tanker; torpedoed by U-552.

Five-masted commercial schooner that ran aground in late January off the coast of Cape Hatteras. When the wreck was discovered and boarded, it was found to have been completely abandoned. Its crew were never heard from again.
Torpedoed by U-158 off Cape Lookout.
Ran aground off Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina.
Sank following collision with SS Lara off Cape Lookout.
Four-masted schooner; foundered after running aground on Diamond Shoals.
Sidewheel steamer carrying 10 tons of gold when it was caught up in a Category 2 hurricane.
Freighter; torpedoed by U-576 and subsequently ran aground off Cape Hatteras.
Sunk off Cape Hatteras, while being rigged as a tethered underwater target.
Latvian freighter; torpedoed off Nags Head.
American freighter; torpedoed by U-123.
Foundered off Frying Pan Shoals in a storm.
Ran aground off Masonboro Inlet.
Sunk as a target, along with her sister ship, Stump.
Sunk in battle off Roanoke Island.
Patrol boat that was torpedoed by U-402.
Sunk off Pea Island as an artificial reef.
American tanker; torpedoed off Cape Hatteras by U-71.
Gunboat that ran aground in New River and was destroyed to prevent capture.
American tanker; torpedoed off Diamond Shoals by U-124.
British tanker; torpedoed off Diamond Shoals by U-66.
Torpedoed by U-203.
Panamanian freighter; torpedoed by U-160.
American tanker; torpedoed by U-124; stern section was salvaged.
Sunk off Nags Head.
Steamboat and balloon carrier that ran aground near Elizabeth City.
Gunboat that was burned to prevent capture at Elizabeth City.
American tanker; struck a naval mine at Diamond Shoals.
Foundered in a storm.
Blown ashore by a storm, and now on display at Nags Head town hall.
Victim of the 1933 Chesapeake–Potomac hurricane. Wrecked two miles south of Gull Shoal Coast Guard Station. Nine men and one woman from the ship were saved by breeches buoy.
Merchant sailing vessel; sank during the 1899 San Ciriaco hurricane in Pamlico Sound.
American lumber schooner; foundered in a storm near Diamond Shoals Lightship.
Burned and sank off Frying Pan Shoals.
British cargo ship; ran aground on outer Diamond Shoals.
Schooner that was wrecked in a gale off Cape Hatteras.
Sunk and later recovered near Belhaven.
Wooden schooner; ran aground 2 miles south of Nag's Head.
Norwegian barque; wrecked off Hatteras Island.
British cargo ship; stranded on Diamond Shoals.
Steam packet ship wrecked off the beach of Ocracoke Island, N.C. in the 1837 Racer's Storm hurricane.
Steamship that sank off Cape Hatteras.
Ran aground off Nags Head.
Foundered in a storm while under tow
Sunk as artificial reef.
Ran aground at Lockwood's Folly Inlet while attempting to refloat CSS Bendigo.
British cargo ship; wrecked near Hatteras Inlet.
Sank off Oregon Inlet in the 1944 Great Atlantic Hurricane.
Torpedoed by U-158.
Disappeared off Cape Hatteras.
Greek cargo ship; torpedoed off Diamond Shoals by U-124.

The 996 gross ton and 203 feet long steamer headed from New York to the Pacific Coast for Tacoma to Alaska service.  Leaking, she stopped for repairs at Newport News, VA where she was deemed seaworthy.  She developed catastrophic leaks and sank 110 NM off North Carolina.  The use of radio to communicate "S.O.S." messages were among the first recorded, saving 46 lives.
Navy tug; struck a naval mine off Cape Hatteras while attempting to rescue SS Chilore.
Norwegian tanker; torpedoed by U-571.
Ran aground near Kill Devil Hills.
Norwegian tanker; torpedoed by U-552 off Cape Hatteras.
Ran ashore on Coquina Beach.
Freighter; torpedoed off Diamond Shoals by U-552.
Yugoslavian freighter; torpedoed by U-404.
Sank in surf in Oregon Inlet.
Set afire and exploded at Fort Fisher.
Sank off Cape Hatteras while under tow.
American freighter; torpedoed by U-160.
American freighter; torpedoed off Cape Lookout by U-404.
Cargo ship that was sunk by U-571 off Cape Hatteras.
Liberian cargo ship; foundered after her cargo shifted.
Torpedoed off Kinnakeet station by U-432.
American tanker; ran aground on Diamond Shoals while avoiding torpedoes from U-140.
Sunk off Corolla.
Torpedoed by U-117 off Wimble Shoal Buoy.
Sunk at Kure Beach.
Lost off Cape Hatteras while under tow by Rhode Island.
Tanker; torpedoed off Cape Lookout by U-124.
Burned to avoid capture in Neuse River; currently installed beside the river at the Governor Caswell Memorial.
Bombed as a target off Cape Hatteras.
Panamanian cargo ship; torpedoed by U-404.
Foundered in a storm at Frying Pan Shoals.
American tanker; ran aground on Diamond Shoals.
American freighter; torpedoed off Cape Hatteras by U-123.
Gunboat that sank off Southport.
Panamanian tanker; torpedoed off Hatteras by U-130.
Sank near Oregon Inlet.
Sank in the Roanoke River after striking two mines near Jamesville.
Tanker; torpedoed and sank off Oregon Inlet.
Mistaken for a blockade runner and rammed by USS Monticello off Kure Beach.
Blockade runner, sank off Atlantic Beach.
Steel-hulled blockade runner; sunk at Topsail Inlet.
Patrol vessel that was scuttled off Harkers Island as a breakwater.
Dredge; sank for unknown reasons.
Ran aground at Cape Lookout.
Sank following collision with tanker SS Cushing in heavy fog, southwest of Diamond Shoals.
The American steam packet Pulaski was lost thirty miles off the coast of North Carolina when its starboard boiler exploded.
French frigate that was captured by pirates and became Blackbeard's flagship, eventually running aground at Beaufort Inlet. She was discovered in 1996, near Atlantic Beach by Intersal, Inc.
Ran aground at Cape Fear.
Spanish merchantman ran aground during a hurricane near Beaufort Inlet, North Carolina
British tanker; torpedoed by U-203.
American cargo and passenger ship; foundered off Cape Hatteras in a storm.
Sank in a collision with SS Florida.
Rammed and sunk by USS Commodore Perry (1859) off Elizabeth City.
Rammed by  USS Semmes which mistook it for a U-boat.
Schooner that was scuttled in the Ocracoke Inlet.
American bulk carrier; broke apart and sank.
Sank following collision with CSS Albemarle on Roanoke River, near its mouth at Albemarle Sound.
Scuttled in 108 feet (33 m) of water, 30 miles (48 km) off Morehead City, as an artificial reef.
Canadian destroyer; sank off Cape Hatteras while under tow to breakers.
Ran aground near Chicomacomico.
Iron-hulled sidewheel blockade runner; sunk at Kure Beach.
Brazilian cargo ship; sank after striking the submerged wreck of the W. E. Hutton.
American tanker; torpedoed off Cape Lookout by U-552.
Foundered off Cape Hatteras.
Sunk as an artificial reef.
American tanker; torpedoed by U-754.
Balao-class submarine sunk as a target off Cape Hatteras.
Sunk by depth charges from USCGC Icarus.
Sunk off Hatteras by depth charges from aircraft and gunfire from SS Unicoi.
Sunk off Cape Hatteras by depth charges from aircraft.
Sunk off Bodie Island by gunfire from USS Roper.
British passenger and cargo ship; torpedoed by U-160 south of Cape Hatteras.
Captured and burned by Confederate forces off New Bern.
Sank in a storm

A cargo ship that was lost in the Japanese bombing of Darwin.
A German made barque that ran aground near Cape Moreton, and is now a historical site.
A ferry that ran aground at Picnic Bay.
A lighter that was scuttled at Hervey Bay.
A full-rigged ship that ran aground on the Wreck Reefs, along with HMS Porpoise.
A hospital ship that was torpedoed by Japanese submarine I-177, killing 268 medical staff and crew.
A cargo ship that ran aground on Teewah Beach.
A steamship that ran aground off Cockle Bay, Magnetic Island, and used as target practice for the Royal Australian Air Force during World War II. The wreck was sunk by Cyclone Althea in 1971.
A steamship that ran aground at Dicky Beach. The visible remains of the wreck were removed in 2015.
A barque that was wrecked off Moreton Bay.
Wrecked at Cape Flinders, Stanley Island.
A flat-iron gunboat that was beached as a breakwater off Woody Point.
A paddle steamer that was scuttled in Picnic Bay, Magnetic Island.
A steamship that struck the Great Barrier Reef.
A schooner that was wrecked on the Great Barrier Reef near Cooktown.
A barque that was wrecked on Kenn Reef on the Great Barrier Reef.
A schooner that ran aground on a reef.
An ocean liner that was beached on Fraser Island while under tow for scrapping in Japan.
A steamship that was beached on Fraser Island.
A cutter that was wrecked east of Normanby Island.
A barque that was scuttled in Geoffrey Bay, Magnetic Island.
A Porcupine-class post ship that struck and was wrecked on the Great Barrier Reef.
A sloop that ran aground on the Wreck Reefs, along with Cato.
A merchant ship that struck a rock off Albany Island.

A barque carrying passengers and cargo from Glasgow was wrecked at the southern tip of Stradbroke Island. The passengers and crew were rescued. Parts of the wreck can still be found in shallow water approximately 500 metres (1,600 ft) offshore south of the Southport Spit and it is a popular diving site. Since 2013, sand movement has resulted in increasing amounts of the wreck becoming visible.
A brig that was wrecked off the Cape York Peninsula.
A Bathurst-class corvette that hit a mine in the Great Barrier Reef.
A motor vessel that was wrecked in a storm off Double Island Point.
A passenger ship that sank in a cyclone off Townsville.
A patrol vessel that foundered off Townsville.
A sailing ship that was wrecked on Wardang Island.
A passenger ship that ran onto a reef off the Carpenter Rocks, with 89 lives lost including 14 children.
A ketch that struck Eclipse Reef, off Wardang Island, during a gale.
A two decked turret steam ship which capsized and sank in a storm, killing 40 of her crew of 64, near the town of Edithburgh.
A brig that was wrecked on the Carpenter Rocks. One seaman drowned attempting to swim to shore.
A screw steamer deliberately sunk to make an artificial reef between Goat Island and St Peter Island.
A freighter/trawler that was wrecked in Gulf St Vincent at Morgan's Beach.
An iron barque which ran aground at Reef Head, near Cape Spencer
A schooner that was blown ashore near Cape Jaffa, Kingston District Council.

A steamship that was fraudulently taken from its home in Scotland, and arrived in Victoria six months later. The conspirators were caught and charged, but the ship remained in Australia, eventually running aground off Cape Spencer in a storm.
A cutter that was wrecked in the Neptune Islands.
A cray-fishing boat that was wrecked in the North Neptune Islands.
A barque that struck a reef near the town of Southend.
A barque that sank in a gale off Port Adelaide, one man drowned.
A barque that was scuttled as a breakwater in Stenhouse Bay.
A steamship that sank in rough weather southwest of Wardang Island.
A barque 800 tons that was wrecked off Robe, off with the loss of 16 crew after unloading 397 Chinese passengers for the Victorian goldfields.
A barque that ran aground off Port Neill.
A barque that was wrecked in the Brothers Rocks, off Kangaroo Island.
A clipper that sank off Kangaroo Island with the loss of 27 lives.
A schooner that was wrecked on a reef off Wardang Island.
A brigantine that was wrecked off Cape Jaffa, South Australia
A screw steamer wrecked off Cable Hut Bay.
A hopper barge that was scuttled in Gulf St Vincent.
A barque that ran aground on Wardang Island. The wreck was gutted by an accidental fire the following May.
A schooner that was wrecked at Arno Bay.
A fishing boat that was wrecked on South Neptune Islands.
A 3 masted barque abandoned in the Garden Island Ships' Graveyard near Port Adelaide.
A Norwegian cargo ship that sank near Wardang Island when its hull was pierced by one of its own anchors. The wreck was eventually blown up as a shipping hazard.
A cargo ship that was wrecked in a storm off Port Willunga.
A brig-sloop, formerly the former RN vessel (the Swallow (1824)),  was wrecked at Encounter Bay.
A barge abandoned on the Birdsville Track to the south of the Cooper Creek in Etadunna.
A cargo ship that was wrecked twenty miles west of Cape Northumberland.
A cutter which sunk whilst moored in the River Murray at Moorundie, South Australia.
A screw steamer wrecked south of Rhino Head, near Marion Bay.
A cutter that was wrecked in the North Neptune Islands.
A barque which foundered during a squall in Gulf St Vincent.
A ship that was wrecked in the D'Entrecasteaux Channel.
A coastal freighter that capsized and sank off South West Cape. All the crew escaped the vessel but three lives were lost before the survivors were rescued.
A schooner that was driven ashore near the Kent Group.
400 lost when wrecked on King Island.
A ship that was wrecked off Macquarie Island.
A brig that was wrecked off East Island.
A barque that struck the rocks about half a mile off the western shore of Bruny Island.
A convict ship that sank in the D'Entrecasteaux Channel.
A ship that struck a reef off George Town.
A bulk carrier that ran aground on a reef off George Town, causing an oil spill. It was refloated and scuttled off Flinders Island.
Bulk carrier wrecked in the River Derwent, with 12 lives lost.
An icebreaker that ran aground off Macquarie Island, and was subsequently scuttled.
A full-rigged ship that ran aground off King Island.
A convict ship that sank off King Island, with about 225 lives lost.
A ship that ran aground on Hunter Island.
Sank at Preservation Island with no loss of life.
A steamship that sank off Cape Schanck.
A steamship that hit a mine off Wilsons Promontory.
A breastwork monitor that was scuttled as a breakwater in Half Moon Bay.
A steamship that was wrecked near Point Nepean.
A steamship that collided with SS Penola at Port Phillip.
A steamship that hit a mine off Cape Otway.
A paddle steamer that was wrecked at Clonmel Island, near the entrance to Corner Inlet.
A paddle steamer that was washed out to sea in a flash flood, and stranded on a beach at Marlo.
A passenger ship that ran aground off Barwon Heads.
A barque that ran onto the rocks near Peterborough.
A minesweeper that collided with Duntroon at Port Phillip.
A torpedo boat that was rammed and sunk at Port Phillip.
A full-rigged ship that ran aground on a reef off Torquay.
One of Victoria's largest shipwrecks, found in 2005 in Bass Strait.
A brig that was beached at Port Fairy.
An extreme clipper that caught fire and was scuttled off Geelong.
Struck Mutton Bird Island.
An oil tanker that struck a reef off Point Nepean, releasing Australia's first major oil spill.
A dredger that was scuttled off Port Phillip.
Ran aground at Point Hicks.
A tugboat that was wrecked in a storm in Cockburn Sound.
A 132-ton vessel that was wrecked on Brue reef with the loss of 13 of its 41 crew.
Greek merchant ship.
Merchant ship wrecked off Cheyne Beach
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
A Dutch vessel that was run aground after it began taking on water.
A brig that foundered off Middle Island in the Recherche Archipelago.
A Castle-class trawler that was scuttled near Swarbricks Beach east of Albany
An 1107-ton iron sailing ship that ran aground on Pelsaert Island in the Houtman Abrolhos, without loss of life, in the same location as the wreck of the Marten several years previously.
Three masted schooner, Capt. A. Bergman or Berghmann, taking jarrah piles from Hamlyn to Darwin, wrecked off Browse Island.
A cutter engaged in transporting materials for the construction of a telegraph line, ran aground at Twilight Cove in a storm that also claimed the Twilight. The crew survived.
British iron ship that struck a reef near Rockingham with the loss of 24 lives, in the same storm that claimed the City of York.
A brig that struck a reef near Perth.
A barque used for whaling, blown onto a sandbar and subsequently abandoned. The crew survived.
A barque that hit a reef off Rottnest Island with the loss of 11 lives (in the same storm that claimed the Carlisle Castle).
An American barque that struck a reef west of Rat Island in the Houtman Abrolhos. A crew member travelled overland to Fremantle to summon help for the remainder.
A 322-ton barque that dragged its anchor and went ashore at what is now Rockingham.
A Portuguese vessel wrecked at Point Cloates
A ship wrecked after hitting a submerged rock off Cape Leeuwin en route to Fremantle.
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as an artificial reef.
A 194-ton merchant ship that ran aground at Cottesloe.
A vessel blown onto shore near Fremantle (the same storm that wrecked the James).
A 116-ton two-masted wooden-hulled schooner, wrecked near Coral Bay.
A barque that was wrecked at Goode Beach in King George Sound.
A steamship that was wrecked at Calgardup Bay with 12 lives lost.
A 316-ton barque that struck a reef near Beacon Island in the Houtman Abrolhos without loss of life.
A barque involved in the guano trade, wrecked without loss of life after striking a reef at Warnbro Sound.
A fishing lugger that overturned in strong winds off Gun Island, Houtman Abrolhos, with the loss of 2 of the 3 crew members. The vessel eventually drifted, mastless, onto Wooded Island.
A passenger and cargo ship that was blown onto shore from Owen Anchorage, off Fremantle (the same storm that wrecked the Emily Taylor).
A 107-ton former slave ship, which struck rocks and sank near Woodman Point after parting its anchor warp.
A barque that went down in a storm off Mandurah.
A fishing boat that ran aground at Pelsaert Island, Houtman Abrolhos.
A merchant vessel that was bombed by Japanese aircraft and later capsized at Wyndham. The wreck was towed further out to sea in 1948.
A Panamanian bulk carrier that was lost off Cape Cuvier.
A schooner that foundered at Tappers Inlet during a tropical cyclone, without loss of life.
German merchant raider scuttled after being damaged in battle by HMAS Sydney.
A steamship wrecked in a storm off Kwinana.
A barque that struck a reef off Rottnest Island.
A barque that sank in Emu Point Channel near Albany
An English whaler wrecked at Mermaid Reef, Rowley Shoals.
A 585-ton barque that was wrecked in a tropical cyclone while collecting guano at the Lacepede Islands.
A sealing vessel that was swept ashore in a gale without any loss of life.
A cutter that was wrecked in the Geelvink Channel during a gale, with the loss of one life.
A barque that ran aground at Half Moon Reef, Pelsaert Group, Houtman Abrolhos.
A Royal Mail Ship that ran aground off Rockingham.
An ocean liner that struck a rock and sank 6 miles south of Cape Leeuwin.
A Perth-class guided missile destroyer scuttled as a dive wreck off Albany.
A 20-ton schooner that ran aground on Pelsaert Island in the Pelsaert Group of the Houtman Abrolhos without any loss of life.
An American China trader wrecked at Ningaloo Reef
Ex- North American. A wooden Clipper abandoned or sunk off Cockburn.
A ship that foundered at Careening Bay, Garden Island.
A bulk carrier that struck a reef off Esperance.
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a dive wreck off Dunsborough.
A Tasmanian-built ketch that struck a submerged rock at Twilight Cove. The crew survived.
Leander class cruiser sunk in battle by the German merchant raider Kormoran.
A ship blown onto shore near Fremantle, during the same storm that wrecked the James and the Emily Taylor.
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a target.
Honourable East India Company ship.
A cutter engaged in transporting materials for the construction of a telegraph line, ran aground at Twilight Cove in a storm that also claimed the Bunyip.
A gunboat that was wrecked in the King George Sound.
A schooner that struck a reef in the Pelsaert Group of the Houtman Abrolhos, with the loss of one life. Survivors were stranded on Middle Island for six months.
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
A Bathurst-class corvette that collided with the Henry Gilbert Costin off Fremantle.
A brig sunk off Cheynes Beach near Cape Riche
An iron steamer wrecked on Half Moon Reef, Pelsaert Group, Houtman Abrolhos with the loss of 3 lives, plus a further 2 rescuers. It had been en route from Fremantle to Hong Kong.
A steamship that sank off Gregory.
A schooner that hit Scott Reef during a gale.
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
A luxury yacht that was rammed in fog by the steamer H. F. Dimock off Chatham.
A passenger steamer that collided with the schooner barge Glendower in fog, off Chatham.
A Clemson-class destroyer that sank in a collision off Cape Cod.
A cargo ship that foundered in a storm off Monomoy Island, and is thought to have been torpedoed.
An 82-foot (25 m) long fishing vessel, lost in a storm about 20 miles (32 km) northeast of Provincetown, Massachusetts with four crew members aboard, all presumed deceased.
A USCG Cutter that was blown onto a beach at Sandwich while disabled in storm.
A steamship that collided in fog with the freighter H. F. Dimock, 3 miles east of Chatham.
A Liberty ship that ran aground in 1943, and was used as a target ship until 1971.
A barque that was beached in a storm, near Cape Cod Light.
A ship that served in the Quasi-War and was wrecked off Cape Cod.
A schooner that ran aground off Nauset Light in a storm.
A schooner that caught fire and sank off Provincetown.

A brig shipwrecked off of Truro under Capt. John Callahan. Passengers included John Wheelock and James Wheelock who were returning from a fundraising tour in Europe for Dartmouth College, they lost all of their papers and the money raised in the wreck.
A tanker that broke in half in a storm, 1 mile east of Monomoy Island.
A third-rate ship of the line that ran aground in a storm off Provincetown.
The flagship of the pirate "Black Sam" Bellamy, which sank in a storm off Marconi Beach, claiming the lives of Bellamy and most of his crew.
A cement barge that broke its towline in a storm and grounded on a reef off Westport.
A steamship that was beached at Somerset and abandoned.
A ferry that struck Hens and Chickens Reef off Westport and sank quickly.
A dredger that struck a reef off Westport.
A steamboat that sank in Buzzards Bay while under tow.
A cargo ship that collided in fog with the steamer Herman Winter in Vineyard Sound.
A steamboat that ran aground on Devil's Bridge, off Aquinnah.
A tanker that collided with Norwegian freighter Fernview northwest of Pasque Island.
A steamship that was stranded on Devils Bridge reef, off Martha's Vineyard.
A rum runner that was scuttled south of Nashawena Island.

A 57-foot scallop fishing vessel that capsized and sank during a powerful storm off the coast of Martha's Vineyard with four crew members aboard. Only one survivor was found, and the other three are presumed deceased.
A schooner that ran aground on Wasque Shoal, off Martha's Vineyard.
A whaler that was wrecked on Nashawena Island.
An Accentor-class minesweeper sunk by USS Richard W. Suesens off Cuttyhunk.
A Grand Banks schooner that wrecked on Crane Beach in Ipswich, Massachusetts.
A cutter that grounded on Boo Hoo Ledge off Manchester.
A schooner that ran aground and broke up in a storm off Manchester.
A schooner that collided with the steamer Belfast off Marblehead.
A fishing trawler that ran aground on a ledge off Rockport.
A cargo ship that was stranded on a ledge off Rockport.
A tanker that was grounded on the Sandy Bay Breakwater northeast of Thatcher Island.
An oil tanker that broke in half in a storm, southwest of Eastern Point Light.
A schooner that struck the Sandy Bay Breakwater off Rockport in fog.
A schooner that caught fire and sank in Gloucester Harbor.
A schooner that collided with the Louise B. Crary off Gloucester.
A YMS-1-class minesweeper that ran aground off Rockport.
A lighter that was rammed in fog by the steamer City of Gloucester while at anchor off Nahant.
A schooner smashed into one of the jetties in a storm off Salisbury.
A schooner that caught fire and sank off Gloucester. The wreck was discovered in 2006.
A schooner that sank in a storm off Gloucester. The wreck was discovered in 2004.
A schooner that collided with the Frank A. Palmer off Gloucester.
A paddle steamer that sank off Salem Harbor.
A training ship that caught fire and sank in the Hudson River on 23 May 1921. She was raised and sold for scrap, but caught fire again and sank while under tow off Manchester.

The navy tug was steaming from Portsmouth to Boston carrying a cargo of chains, anchors and search light equipment for the USS Missouri. She capsized and sank when a deck load shifted in heavy seas off Cape Ann. Of the 9 person crew, there were 4 fatalities
A fishing trawler that was scuttled off Gloucester.
A factory ship that foundered during sea trials after refit, 2.5 miles east of Eastern Point Light.
A steamship that sank off Cape Ann in the Portland Gale.
A schooner that was grounded on Tuckernuck Shoal, in Nantucket Sound.  The vessel grounded upon the French Van Gilder (see below).
An oil tanker that ran aground 25 miles southeast of Nantucket, Massachusetts, causing an oil spill.
A crane barge that foundered in Nantucket Sound.
A schooner that foundered in a gale 6 miles northeast of Great Point Light.
A tanker that broke in half in heavy seas southeast of Nantucket.
A schooner that was grounded on Tuckernuck Shoal in Nantucket Sound.
A schooner that was grounded on Halfmoon Shoal in Nantucket Sound.
A cargo ship that collided with the liner President Garfield northeast of East Chop Light.
A lightvessel that was rammed by RMS Olympic off Nantucket.
A lightvessel that started to leak and sank while being towed off Nantucket.
A steamboat that sank under tow off Nantucket.
A schooner that caught fire and sank northeast of Nobska Light.
A wheelchair-accessible galleon that sank off Nantucket.
Torpedoed by and sunk by SM U-53, 2.5 miles east-north-east of Nantucket.
A Type IXC/40 U-boat sunk by USS Joyce off Nantucket.
A steam-powered ocean liner that collided with SS Florida south of Nantucket Island.
Andrea Doria class ocean liner capsized and sunk after colliding with the MS Stockholm (1948).

A brig that was drove ashore at Duxbury Beach in the Blizzard of 1805. "Loss of Brig Ann. A gentleman, arrived in town [Boston], last evening from Duxbury, informs, that the brig Ann, Capt. Lathrop, was drove on shore, at Duxbury Beach, on Monday night last, about 11 o'clock. The crew got on shore safe, and it is expected the cargo will be saved. The Ann is owned by Mr. William Parsons, of this town [Boston]. Capt Lothrop, informs, that she saw a brig on shore at Race Point, [Provincetown] as he passed that place, but could not understand who she was."

A ship that went shore on Salt House Beach off Marshfield and Duxbury in the Blizzard of 1805. "A new ship went ashore on Salt House Beach, a few hours before the loss of the Hibernia; this intelligence is corroborated by Mr. Payne, the surviving mate of the above vessel, who stated to our informant, that he saw her driving towards the shore, and that she is the Ceres, Capt. Sampson, who sailed in company with the Hibernia, from this place, for Charleston. No further particulars of the situation of the ship or crew have been received."

A ship that was stranded on High Pines, a section of Duxbury beach off the Gurnet. "In March 1792, the ship Columbia, of three hundred tons, of Portland, Capt. Isaac Chauncy, was stranded on the beach at the High Pines, and fourteen men lost, and two, the second mate and a boy, were saved."
A schooner that was blown onto the beach at Scituate in the Portland Gale.
A barge that sank off Scituate in the Portland Gale.
A fishing vessel that sank near Stellwagen Bank.

A ship Favorite bilged off Rocky Point, Plymouth in the Blizzard of 1805. "Boston, January 31. Loss of Ship Favorite. The ship Favorite, Nathaniel M. Perley, master, sailed from hence, on Saturday morning, for Lisbon: After standing off with a light breeze from 11 A.M. until 8 P.M. the wind beginning to haul to the N.E. and coming on to snow, the weather very thick. Capt. Perley thought best to heave about and stand in, and endeavor to make a harbor - he run in about a mile above the light and came too, with both anchors ahead, rode until five o'clock, on Monday Morning, it then blowing very hard from E. N. E. the ship parted both cables, and in 10 minutes struck on Rocky Point, and is bilged; it is expected a large part of the cargo will be saved."
A cargo ship that grounded off Second Cliff Beach, Scituate, in a storm.

A schooner wrecked off High Pines, Duxbury in the Snow Hurricane of 1804. "Further Accounts of the Late Storm... A wreck was seen near the high pines, after the gale; has since been towed into Plymouth; proves to be the schooner Franklin, of Falmouth; about 100 tons. The body of a seaman has been found on the Outer Beach, two others have been found in the wreck."

An American brig that shipwrecked in Plymouth Bay during the Revolutionary War in a blizzard. "On Friday the 25th ult. at 6 A.M. the wind to the westward, sailed from this port the brig General Arnold, James Magee, commander; and about meridian the wind chop'd round to N.E. and looking likely for a gale they thought best to put into Plymouth, and came to anchor in a place called the Cow Yard. On Saturday, the gale encreasing, she started from her anchor, and struck on the White Flat; they then cut both cables and masts away, in hopes to drive over but she immediately bilged; it being low water, left her quarter-deck dry, where all hands got relief. A schooner lying within hail, heard their cries, but could not assist them. On Saturday the inhabitants were cutting ice most of the day before they got on board, when they saw 75 of the men had perished, and 34 very much froze, which they got on shore; and on Monday they got on shore and buried the dead. Great part of the brig's stores will be saved."
A schooner that foundered southeast of Manomet while under tow in heavy seas.

Loss of Ship Hibernia in the Blizzard of 1805. "The Hibernia, Capt. Farrill, also sailed from this port for Trinidad, on Saturday last. By a gentleman, arrived in town yesterday express from Plymouth, we learn, that the above ship drove ashore at that place, a mile and a half to the south of the Point - she is parted, and her stern drove about a quarter of a mile from her head; the cargo which was in her stern, is scattered along the shore; that in her bows being principally hogsheads, is still in her. The Capt. and all the crew, excepting the first mate, perished." "The Captain and all her crew, excepting her first mate, perished, viz, Andrew Farrill, master, of Boston; William Payne, first mate, formerly of Wellfleet, but now of Boston, the only survivor who was lashed to the helm, and taken from thence almost lifeless; Joseph Cordis, second mate, of Charlestown; and the following seamen, viz James D. Hammond of Marblehead, Ezra Bicknall of Weymouth, John Smith of Boston, Samuel Carter of Philadelphia, John Smith of Newport, Thomas Brown of Gloucester, William Howard, boy, of New York, and Francis Trask Cook of Newburyport."
A schooner that was blown onto rocks in a gale, north of Cedar Point, Scituate.
A tug that collided with the tanker Bidwell east of Manomet.
An Arapaho-class fleet tug that struck a submerged ledge near Nantasket Beach.
A schooner that dragged her anchor onto Nantasket Beach in a storm.
A (coal) schooner barge that burned and sank Nobska Light, Wareham.

A sloop cast ashore off High Pines Ledge on Duxbury Beach. "Duxbury, December 7. Mr. Russell, On the night of the 5th instant, the sloop Prudence, Captain Alexander Gardner, of Nantucket, was cast ashore and stranded, on the beach, two miles north of Plymouth Light House. There were five men on board; the mate and a passenger was saved, the Captain and his son [Charles Gardner] was found dead; the others not yet found. The cargo consisted of fifteen hogsheads spermaceti oil, 100 barrels tar, and the rigging and sails of the ship Charles, which was cast away near Nantucket - all of which will be saved with little damage. It is not known by the mate who the oil belongs to; it will be forwarded to Boston immediately. Your humble servant, Reuben Drew."

A ship that shipwrecked on Duxbury beach. "Tribute of Gratitude. George Whytock, commander of the ship Rodney, of London, which sailed from Boston, on Thursday the 22d of November, and unfortunately was shipwrecked on Duxburough beach, the Sunday morning following, in the severe snowstorm, takes this public method to return his most grateful thanks to the benevolent people of Duxborough, Marshfield, and their vicinities, for their humane, spirited, and generousexertions, in affording him and his crew their assistance, in their distressing calamity. To ALL this tribute is sincerely proffered, and particularly to Captain Samuel Debona [sic, Delano], of Duxburough, for his singularly benevolent, noble, and spirited exertions, who at the risk of his own life, ventured into the boisterous waves, and providentially reached the wreck, for the kind purpose of preventing the sufferers attempting to land in their then situation, but to wait until the tide would admit of their getting safely on shore, and to inspire their almost exhausted spirits every possible degree of fortitude, with the assurance of a ready assistance as soon as it was possible for help to reach them from the beach. (Signed) GEORGE WHYTOCK for himself, family, and ship's company." "Nov. 25, 1792, the ship Rodney, of London, of between four and five hundred tons, Capt. Whytock, was cast ashore on the Branches ledge in a northeast storm, on her passage from Boston for Martinique, and loaded with lumber and brick. There were no deaths. Capt. Samuel Delano Jr., of Duxbury, while endeavoring to render her assistance, scarcely escaped drowning, and for his heroic conduct was rewarded by the Humane Society with a gold medal. Her passengers were rescued by a sloop, and among their number were several females, the Captain's family."

A brig that wrecked on Brant Rock, Marshfield. "FATAL SHIPWRECK. The Brig Success, Tobias Lear Porter, master, belonging to Messrs. J. & S. White of Salem, 84 days from St. Petersburg, on Wednesday evening last, struck on the Brant rock, Marshfield beach, by which accident the Captain, mate, and four seamen perished, two only being saved. The names of those lost besides the master, are, Mr. John Nichols of Salem, mate; Peter Union, John Chappell, Williams Brooks, and Giles Pike of Marblehead, seamen. Capt. Porter (in whose death society has lost a very respectable, enterprising, and valuable member) was son to the Rev. Nathaniel Porter, of Conway, N.H., a clergyman much respected for learning, and venerable for his age and piety. It appeared that on the approach of night, the wind blowing fresh at the eastward, Capt. Porter consulting his mate on the expediency of running in for the land, they being very short of water, having but about 3 gallons on board, and as they supposed they knew their situation (having spoken a vessel out for the land that day) on mutual deliberation concluded to run in; sounding several times in the evening until they shoaled the water to 17 fathoms. Concluding that they were on the northern shore they hauled off to the southward; shortly after they sounded and had 40 fathom water; continued their course to the southward until nearly 8 o'clock P.M. when they saw breakers, and immediately were ship and stood off - directly after which she struck. After beating for two hours she bilged and filled the cabin with water: the mate and people then left the cabin (except the two that were saved) and went forward and lashed themselves [to] the bows, being then quite out of water; sometime after the bows settled away in the cavity of the rocks, when all those lashed forward were drowned; the captain continued about the decks doing everything in his power for the preservation of the whole until after three o'clock A.M.; he then called to the people that were holding on the combings of the companion way, and asked if they were alive; they answered, though the water was nearly up to their mouths; in a few moments he was heard no more. His body was taken up together with those of the mate and the people that morning, and on the following Sabbath were carried into the meeting-house, where a sermon adapted to the occasion was preached to a large concourse of people by the Rev. Mr. Shaw, from Prov. xxvii 1 "Boast not thyself of tomorrow, for thou knowest not what a day may bring forth," when the bodies were interred."

An unknown sloop lost off Duxbury. "Boston, November 24... We hear from Duxbury, that in the storm last Sabbath night the 16th instant, a sloop from the Eastward laden with lumber bound in there, where she was owned, one Ripley, master, was cast away on Duxbury Beach, and all the hands (being three in number) perished, viz, [William] Ripley, master, John Alden, son of Briggs Alden Esq. of Duxbury, and Daniel Weston. One of the dead bodies was found lashed to the quarter, and another floated ashore, the third was not found."

A sloop from Connecticut off Duxbury. "Boston, November 5. Last week we had a very heavy storm of wind and rain, the severity of it was on Wednesday, no great damage down in this Harbour; but in the Bay the wind being violent at N.E. many vessels were in great distress. It is said 17 sail, chiefly sloops, were drove on the Southern Shore [including]... a sloop near Duxbury, the vessel, cargo, and all the people lost; two dead bodies have been taken up, several chests, some bedding, great quantities of cheese, butter, cyder &c. were washed a-shore, by which it is supposed she was from Connecticut; but have not learnt the Master's name." "The vessel that was cast away at Duxbury, in a violent storm as lately mentioned in the papers, every soul on board perished, viz Thomas Griffin, master, Jonathan Babcock, James Miner, John Irish, and two others, whose names we have not yet learnt."

A sloop from North Carolina off Marshfield. "Boston, November 5. Last week we had a very heavy storm of wind and rain, the severity of it was on Wednesday, no great damage down in this Harbour; but in the Bay the wind being violent at N.E. many vessels were in great distress. It is said 17 sail, chiefly sloops, were drove on the Southern Shore [including]... A sloop, Andrews, master, from North Carolina, ashore near Marshfield, the vessel lost but the cargo saved."

A ship drove ashore in Duxbury during a snow storm. "December 24. On Monday the 14th we had here an easterly snow storm, but the wind not severe until late in the evening, when it came about to the westward, and blew exceeding hard all the night, and very cold. No damage that we hear of near this place, excepting two vessels drove ashore, viz, Captain Cobb from Quebec for this post [Boston]; and one outward bound for Philadelphia, on George's Island, both likely to be got off."

A sloop ran ashore on Duxbury Beach during The Great Snow of 1786. "Boston, December 22. Among the many terrible effects of the late violent snow storm, a correspondent, who was personally concerned, has sent us the following: "Between one and two o'clock, Saturday morning, December 9, Capt. Samuel Robbins sailed from the Long Wharf in Boston, in a coasting sloop, bound for Plymouth, with a number of passengers on board, among whom were the Rev. Mr. Robbins of Plymouth, with 13 others; the wind about N by E. We had passed the light house about two leagues, when the wind veering round to E.N.E the heavens grew suddenly black and a squall of snow."

A sloop wrecked off Duxbury Beach. "Duxbury Mass. April 13. On Friday afternoon last was discovered at anchor a sloop of about 70 or 80 tons, about half a mile off Duxbury beach; on which there went off some men in a boat. They found no person on board; but a rauses boat with three oars was discovered which was supposed to belong to her. On Saturday morning the sloop disappeared. On that morning the body of a drowned man was taken up on the beach; and the next day two others were taken up. There was nothing found with them to discover who they were or from whence they came, except a watch, with A. S. engraved on it, should do it. It is conjectured she belonged to the Eastward." "In April 1801, a sloop was wrecked, and three men drowned and two saved."

A schooner wrecked near Rocky Point, Plymouth in the Blizzard of 1805. "At the same time [of the wrecking of Hibernia] a schooner, name unknown, was drove on shore at a short distance from where the ship [Hibernia] was struck, and immediately went to pieces. It is feared every soul on board was lost."
A tug that foundered in Boston Harbor, northeast of The Graves Light, while in tow after a fire on board.
A cargo ship that struck a ledge in fog and broke up in Boston Harbor.
A steamboat that was scuttled outside Boston Harbor.
A schooner that struck Graves Ledge in Boston Harbor.
A steamboat that sank at dock, and was raised and scuttled in Boston Harbor.
A cargo ship that was rammed by the steamer Admiral Dewy in a snowstorm, while anchored southeast of Boston Light.
A fishing vessel that collided with the barge Winifred Sheridan in Boston Harbor.
991-ton Maritana of Providence, Rhode Island, was a commercial vessel, which accidentally rammed Shag Rocks, Boston Harbor, in bad weather, and was torn apart by the waves.

A British sailing ship that ran aground at Cabo San Diego. Abandoned early the next morning and using the ship's boats, her crew of 33 made landfall on Staten Island on Christmas Day. The crew were stranded there for 83 days before being picked up by H.M.S. Cleopatra. All were saved.
A cargo ship that ran aground at Cabo San Pablo.
A sailing ship that sank off Tierra del Fuego.

A Brooklyn-class light cruiser that was torpedoed by HMS Conqueror during the Falklands/Malvinas War. The ship was outside the Total Exclusion Zone at the time, leading to controversy over whether the attack was justified.
A salvage tug that was beached an abandoned at Ushuaia.
A Gearing-class destroyer that was sunk as a target in Samborombón Bay.
A barque that caught fire and was scuttled near Comodoro Rivadavia.
A passenger and cargo ship that sank in the Beagle Channel.
A fishing trawler that was destroyed by fire while at port at Ingeniero White, Buenos Aires. The wreck was moved to Bahía Blanca in 1999.
A Brazilian ironclad warship that sank after exploding near the Jacuacanga strait, in Angra dos Reis bay.
Cargo ship that sunk after a collision.
Rare 1806 "direct acting engine" steamer, with a centered propulsion wheel, carrying personal care articles.  Sunk after a pirate raid at Ilha Grande, Angra dos reis.
Torpedoed by a U-170.
Sunk by British HMS Carmania off the coast of the Island of Trindade, Brazil, South Atlantic Ocean -WWI].
Sunk in Santos Bay.
An emigrant ship that was travelling from London to Australia when it collided with the barque Ada Melmore, with 299 lives lost.
A refrigerator ship that ran aground and then split in two in the Guanabara Bay while under tow.

Sunk at the Queimada Grande Island, due to heavy fog.
Attacked by US Navy aircraft and destroyers off the coast of Recife.  After considerable shelling and aerial bombing that rendered her dead in the water, the crew scuttled her the next day.
Sank in the South Pacific while under tow to be broken up.

Sank after striking rocks near Lebu. Second biggest single-incident maritime losses of life in the history of Chile.

A roll-on, roll-off container ship owned by Cunard. Hit by two Argentine air-launched missiles on the 25 May with the loss of 12 crew including the captain. Sank three days later while under tow.

A Type 21 frigate struck by an Argentine 1000 lb bomb on 23 May 1982. The bomb later exploded while an attempt was being made to defuse it, killing one. The explosion, together with a subsequent fire and multiple explosions of on-board munitions caused catastrophic damage. The vessel sank the next day.
A Type 21 frigate. Caught fire and was abandoned after multiple bomb hits from three waves of Argentine aircraft on 21 May; sank in shallow water the next day.

A merchant vessel that was torpedoed by U-185. The vessel was previously German from when it was built in 1912 to 1917 where it was seized by Brazil. Spent a large part of its career sailing from Brazil to Germany.
Merchant vessel that sank after being torpedoed by U-518. Originally a German ship but it got seized by Brazil in 1942.
A Type 42 destroyer. Hit by three bombs dropped by an Argentine A-4 Skyhawk; two exploded. The ship capsized and sank 20 minutes later with the loss of 19 crew.
A Dale-class oil tanker that was torpedoed by U-68 while anchored at Jamestown, Saint Helena.
A Brooklyn-class cruiser of the Argentine Navy. Sunk by the Royal Navy submarine Conqueror during the Falklands War with the loss of 323 crew.
German Scharnhorst-class armored cruiser sunk during the World War I Battle of the Falkland Islands.
Ran aground at Cape Carysfort on the East Falkland because the helmsman was incapacitated due to drunkenness.
Argentine naval supply ship. Sunk after shellfire from HMS Alacrity caused her cargo of fuel and munitions to explode. Only two of the 24 crew survived.
German Königsberg-class light cruiser sunk during the World War I Battle of the Falkland Islands with the loss of all but five of the crew.
German cruise liner. Sank in the Beagle Channel near Tierra del Fuego after striking an uncharted rock. All 1,200 passengers and 350 crew were saved, with the exception of the ship's captain

American merchant vessel that was sank by U-124. The U-boat's captain thought it was suspicious because lights did not illuminate the flag painted on its side and thus he could not identify the nationality of the vessel because of the dark. It was one of four American ships to be sank by German U-boats prior to the entry of the United States into World War 2.
German Scharnhorst-class armored cruiser sunk during the World War I Battle of the Falkland Islands.
Type 42 destroyer. Was badly damaged by an Argentine air-launched missile on 4 May 1982 during the Falklands War; foundered six days later while under tow.
Hit by two or three 500 lb bombs dropped by Argentine aircraft on 8 June 1982; scuttled on 21 June.
Beached on Bay of Arguin off Mauritania
Stranded on Pic Island.
Ran aground off the shore of Mott Island.

A steamship that broke apart in heavy seas.
A steel-hulled freighter that went missing on Lake Superior.
Lost off Duluth; found 2004.

A bulk steel freighter that ran aground in fog off Isle Royale.
A steam powered tugboat, which caught fire near the shore of its namesake city, Ashland, Wisconsin.

A paddlewheeler that struck a reef near Rock of Ages Light.
A lake freighter that capsized near Deer Park.
Went missing on Lake Superior on 1 December 1908.

Lost in a storm on Lake Superior, the Fitzgerald is one of the largest ships to have sunk in the Great Lakes. The exact cause of the disaster has never been made clear, and has been the subject of much discussion.
A freighter that ran aground off Isle Royale.
A decommissioned U.S. Navy steam sloop that was scrapped and burned to the waterline. Her hull is the only surviving remnant of a vessel built by Donald McKay.

A freighter that ran aground off Menagerie Island.

A wooden steamer that sank near the Huron Islands
Early steel steamer lost off Outer Island with all hands
A wooden ship employed in the fur trade by the Northwest Company. It sank in a storm. Generally considered to be the first recorded ship to sink in the Great Lakes.
Sank off Michipicoten, no lives lost. Wreck discovered in 2016.
Sank in Whitefish Bay with the loss of 14 lives after colliding with the Isaac M. Scott.

A commercial schooner that sank off the coast of Long Island.

A bulk freighter that sank off Michigan Island.

A schooner barge that survived the 1919 storm that took her partner, the SS Myron.  The Miztec's good fortune ended when she sank in 1921 with the loss of all hands.  She came to rest next to the Myron.
Sank off Vermilion Point on Lake Superior.
A passenger and delivery freighter lost in a storm off Isle Royale.
A schooner that sank off the coast of Michigan Island.
Lumber hooker lost in a storm on Lake Superior.
Large wooden rafting tug ran aground at Knife Island
A wooden schooner that caught fire and sank off Stockton Island.

A tugboat that caught fire after rescuing a stranded steamboat.

A steamboat that ran aground off the coast of Sand Island.
Struck by a giant wave, broke in two and sank off the Keweenaw Peninsula
Collided with Willis L. King in Whitefish Bay.
A wooden tugboat that sank between Madeline and Basswood Islands.
A steel ocean steamer that sank in deep water after striking a reef.

Struck by the wooden steamer George Hadley and sunk less than a mile out of the Duluth Ship Canal.

A 600-foot-long (180 m) steel-hulled bulk freighter that ran aground on Sawtooth Reef.
Broke in two in a summer storm on Lake Superior.

A bulk carrier that collided with SS Topdalsfjord in the Straits of Mackinac.

Capsized in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. Sighted floating upside-down 10 November 1913 identified as Charles S. Price before it sank on 15 November 1913. Wreck was not found until the 60s when it was found by Resbert R. Martin.
Sank in a collision with the SS Wahcondah.

The City of Grand Rapids was a double decker passenger streamer that caught fire while docked in Little Tub Harbour. For the security of the harbour, the Grand Rapids was towed out into Georgian Bay and released to burn. From there she drifted to the head of Big Tub Harbour where she burnt to the waterline and sank.
Iced up and slowly sank in a storm after passing through the Straits of Mackinac.
Broke in two in a storm on Lake Huron, with the aft section coming to rest five miles from the bow.
Shallow water shipwreck located in the harbor of Harbor Beach, Michigan. The Dorcas Pendell was a schooner built in 1884 and burned in place on 6 July 1914 after running aground.
A 552-foot (168 m) long steel freighter that sank in a collision with the Quincy A. Shaw.
Collision in fog off Pointe Aux Barques.
A steamship that exploded while attempting to rescue the stranded schooner J. N. Carter.
Ran aground in foggy weather near south east end of Bear's Rump Island in Georgian Bay near Tobermory. Smashed stem is in 60 feet and stern is at 150 feet depth.
Capsized off Point Aux Barques.
Lost on Lake Huron during the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. Its wreck was discovered in July 2015.
A lake freighter that sank in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.
While under tow by W. L. Wetmore, which was wrecked by a storm, the King was wrecked too at the northwest end of Bonnet Island near Tobermory, Ontario in about 90 feet of water.
Lost on Lake Huron during the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.

Wooden bulk freighter wrecked in shallow water off the coast of Thunder Bay Island while towing a consort-barge to Duluth. While still stranded, its engine and boiler were salvaged, and the rest of it has since broken up and separated about 35 feet underwater.
Lost in storm off Harbor Beach in Lake Huron in the Great Storm of 1913. Wreck discovered in 1985.
A wooden steamship lost in a storm.
This schooner broke up in gale force seas in shallow water about 200 feet of the Hope Island Lighthouse in about 30 feet of water near Midland, Ontario.
This steel freighter ran aground in a snow storm on the west side of Christian Island near Midland, Ontario. She is in 35 feet of water with part of the stem sticking out of the water.
Wrecked north of Sturgeon Point Light.
A wooden tug that sank near Pointe au Baril, Georgian Bay.
While removing grain from the stranded Riverton at the north west end of Hope Island near Midland, Ontario, high winds blew her into shallow waters grounding her in 20 feet of water.
Discovered 200 feet below the Georgian Bay in excellent condition with a 1927 Chevrolet Coupe inside.
The wooden steam barge sank after catching fire near Thunder Bay Island in Lake Huron. As the wreck took place near the island's Life Saving Station, there were no deaths.
A cargo ship that collided with SS Royalston north of Thunder Bay Island.
A wooden freighter that sank in a collision with the schooner Ironton.
Wrecked during a storm and is in 100 feet at north east end of Bonnet Island near Tobermory, Ontario.
Lost on Lake Huron during the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.
A schooner that was damaged off Cove Island in August, then sank a month later in Big Tub Harbour, near Tobermory.
A glass-bottomed tour boat that sank in Georgian Bay, killing two students.
The wooden three-masted schooner was run down by the steamer W.P. Ketcham. The ship sank immediately and the four crew on board drowned.
A side-wheel paddle steamer lost in a storm in Georgian Bay.
Wrecked in a storm at the west end of Bonnet Island in about 30 feet of water, near Tobermory, Ontario.
A passenger steamer that sank in Saginaw bay after encountering a gale.
Lost on Lake Huron during the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.
Sank while in tow, near Harbor Beach, Michigan; 9 crew and passengers lost.
A sidewheel steamer that capsized in a storm.

A schooner that sank off the shore of Chambers Island. It was raised in 1969 and taken to Menominee, where it became a tourist attraction. However, it quickly deteriorated, and was demolished in 1994 to make way for a parking lot.
A wooden schooner that struck another vessel's scow line.
A cargo carrier that broke in two and sank during the Armistice Day Blizzard.
A bulk cargo steamship that ran aground in fog.
A wooden steamship that sank after burning to a total loss.

A self-unloading Great Lakes freighter caught in a vicious storm on Lake Michigan. Split in two and sank with all except two survivors. Their company did not believe that the ship split in two. Since this was the first time there were any witnesses to see this happen. The weakened hull was due to, too much sulphur in the metal causing it to become brittle in cold weather.
A steamer that went missing in Lake Michigan
A schooner that sank in a blizzard off Baileys Harbor.
A paddlewheel steamer that struck a pier in a gale at Muskegon, Michigan, sinking in four minutes.
A bulk carrier that sank off the coast of Two Rivers.
A schooner that collided with the Kate Gillett off Algoma.
Schooner which was sunk after collision with the tug "Cheney" off Pt, Au Gres, Saginaw Bay.
A cargo ship that foundered in heavy ice west of Mackinaw City.
A cargo liner that sank in a storm near Green Island, Wisconsin.
Rolled over in the Chicago River in Chicago, Illinois. A total of 848 passengers and crew were killed––the largest loss of life in a single shipwreck on the Great Lakes.
A schooner that ran aground off the coast of Liberty Grove.
Grounded and became a total loss in 1960 off the south shore of South Manitou Island. She ran over the wreck of the bulk freighter SS Walter L Frost.
A bulk carrier that caught fire and sank off the coast of North Bay.
A schooner that sank in a gale off the coast of Centerville.
A schooner that ran aground between Hog and Washington islands in Wisconsin.
