A steel freighter that sank after she sprang a leak.
A steamboat that caught fire in a snowstorm off Washington.
A steamship lost in a violent storm while towing the Olive Jeanette.
A schooner that sank in a storm off the coast of Oak Creek.
A schooner that sank off the coast off Sister Bay.
Train ferry that sank in a storm off Milwaukee with the loss of all hands.  Today she lies about four miles northeast of the North Point Lighthouse.
Ran aground in weather off Kewaunee, Wisconsin
A palace steamer that caught fire and sank off Belgium, Wisconsin.
A schooner that capsized off Port Washington.
A scow schooner that sank in a storm off the coast of Door County.
A steel-hulled car ferry that mysteriously flooded, and sank on Lake Michigan.

Wooden steamship that caught fire from over-stoked boilers and burned to the waterline off the coast of Sheboygan, WI, killing at least 190 but perhaps more than 250 of the nearly 300 souls on board.  39 people survived in lifeboats and three were rescued from the water.
The first Great Lakes freighter; caught fire, ran aground and sank in Green Bay.
A wooden tugboat that sank off the coast of Sheboygan, Wisconsin after striking an obstruction.
A luxury yacht that sank off the coast of Kenosha.
Sunk in a storm on Lake Michigan with its cargo of Christmas trees.
A passenger steamer that ran aground against the Morgan Shoal off the coast of Chicago.
Pushed ashore by a gale during a storm off the coast of Sevastopol, Wisconsin.
A scow schooner that sank off Port Washington.
A schooner that disappeared on Lake Michigan.
A lumber freighter that took on water and was driven aground on South Manitou Island.

79 of 81 passengers and crew were lost when she sank near Port Washington, Wisconsin in 10 to 35 feet of water. Also carried freight. Wood hull, propeller/direct acting steam engine built by B.B. Jones Co, Buffalo, New York 1854.
A wooden package freighter that burned and sank off Pensaukee, Wisconsin.
A German Type UC III submarine sunk as a target off the coast of Highland Park, Illinois.
Sank two miles northeast of Sheboygan.
Stranded off South Manitou Island. Her carcass was struck by and caused the sinking of the SS Francisco Morazan in 1960.
65-ft wooden schooner sunk off South Manitou Island, wreck in excellent condition
Wreck was discovered in 2010 in Platte Bay, near Traverse City, Michigan
Sank near Pentwater in the Armistice Day Blizzard.
The Gilcher was a steel-hulled freighter that went missing on Lake Michigan on 28 October 1892.
A steamboat that sank off the coast of Kenosha.

Lying on a silt bottom at 105 feet

Towing barge CLEVECO (qv), she encountered a heavy gale and began to founder. She radioed in, but C.G. was unable to locate her in the murk before she went down with a loss of 14 people. Owned by Cleveland Tankers, Cleveland.
Wreck located by a commercial diver in 1969.

A wooden-hulled paddle steamer that sank after her boilers exploded. She is the oldest steamboat wreck on the Great Lakes.

A 123-foot two masted schooner.  She was carrying coal en route to Toronto when caught in the Gale of 1880 and after fighting for hours, sank in 12 feet of water in Wellers Bay.  Only one of the crew of seven survived.

A wooden warship that served in the War of 1812. The ship was decommissioned and her hull was used as a storage facility by Morton's Brewery in Kingston. In January 1832, the hull was sold to Robert Drummond for £25. Later, it was sunk close to shore, and is now a popular diving attraction.

A freshwater sloop of war that served in the War of 1812. She was ordered broken up and sold in 1831, and is presumed to have rotted and sunk at Kingston. The wreck, identified as HMS Montreal by Parks Canada in 2006, lies near the Royal Military College of Canada.
Car ferry scuttled to provide scuba attraction off Dawson's Point, Wolfe Island
The Edmund Fitzgerald was 729-foot long freighter that sank of an unknown cause in a storm on Lake Superior. The Fitzgerald is the largest ship to sink on the lakes.
The Carl D. Bradley was a Great Lakes freighter that had a 31-year career that suddenly ended in 1958 when she broke in two in a severe November storm on Lake Michigan.
The Daniel J. Morrell was a Great Lakes bulk carrier that sank with only one survivor; 26-year old watchman Dennis Hale of Ashtabula, Ohio.
The William C. Moreland was a Great Lakes bulk carrier that ran aground due to poor visibility on Sawtooth Reef, Lake Superior.
The Cedarville was a self-unloading freighter that sank in the Straits of Mackinac after being rammed by the M/V Topdalsfjord. Ten of the crew drowned when the ship sank.
The Chester A. Congdon was a steel-hulled bulk carrier that stranded in heavy fog on Canoe Rocks, near Isle Royale.
The D.R. Hanna was a steel-hulled freighter that sank on 16 May 1919 in a collision with the Quincy A. Shaw north of Thunder Bay Island, Lake Huron.
The James C. Carruthers was a 550-foot (170 m) long Canadian freighter that foundered in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.
The Henry B. Smith was an American bulk freighter that foundered in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913 near Marquette, Michigan. Her wreck was discovered in 2013 by a team of divers led by Jerry Eliason.
The Emperor was a Canadian freighter owned by Canada Steamship Lines Ltd. that sank after striking the north side of Canoe Rocks near Isle Royale.

The Isaac M. Scott was an American bulk carrier that sank on Lake Huron in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. She was discovered in 1976, laying upside down, and half buried in mud under 180-feet (55m) of water.
The Charles S. Price capsized on Lake Huron in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. She was discovered floating upside down near Port Huron.

The former steam yacht of Friedrich Augustus II, Grand Duke of Oldenburg (1852-1931). In September 1926, while in Biscayne Bay, the ship was damaged by a hurricane and five of the seven crew died, including the captain. She was towed to the Port of Miami by tugs. In 1928, she was moved to Tampa Bay but she was not repaired and she sank in 1934. Her hulk was towed 15 nautical miles out to sea and abandoned to sink. The location of her wreck was forgotten and only rediscovered in 2007.

A clipper that ran aground near Pigeon Point. "On the night of June 6, 1853, the clipper ship Carrier Pigeon ran aground 500 feet off shore of the central California coast. The area is now called Pigeon Point in her honor. The Carrier Pigeon was a state-of-the art, 19th Century clipper ship. She was 175 feet long with a narrow, 34 foot beam and rated at about 845 tons burden. Launched in the fall of 1852 from Bath, Maine, the Carrier Pigeon ... started out on her maiden voyage on January 28, 1853. Out of Boston and bound for San Francisco, the Carrier Pigeon was under the command of Captain Azariah Doane." (Pigeon Point History). There were no deaths in the sinking.

Clipper ship. The ship was headed for San Francisco and in heavy fog struck rocks off of the point, since then renamed Franklin Point. The ship was destroyed, killing the Captain and eleven men. The point is located in Ano Nuevo State Reserve. The seamen were buried there; the officers in San Francisco.

Built for the Hudson Bay Company in 1891 by Watson of Sunderland England, purchased in 1909 by James Baird Ltd. of St. John’s for the seal fishery. Sprang a leak while butting through slob ice in heavy seas. Engineers kept it afloat for 30 hours to reach St. Mary's Bay, where it ran onto rocks at Branch. All crew were saved.
A Scottish brig sunk near Cape St. Francis.

A barque that sank in a gale near Port Aux Basques. The ship was wrecked on Mouse Island, in the Gulf of Saint Lawrence with the loss of 241 of the 273 people on board. She was on a voyage from Londonderry to Quebec, British North America. Her captain was subsequently found guilty of willfully wrecking the ship and was sentenced to death.
Reported missing in Baccalieu Tickle.
An iron-ore carrier that was torpedoed by U-513 off Bell Island.
A schooner that sank in the St.John's Narrows due to a collision with the Tiber
A Canadian Pacific liner.
A semi-submersible offshore oil drilling unit that sank in a storm off St. John's.
The ship was wrecked near the Burin Peninsula, with some loss of life.
An iron-ore carrier that was torpedoed by U-123 off Bell Island.
A supply ship that sank along with USS Truxtun in a storm.
A schooner sunk in a gale near Cape Race.
Ran aground and sunk in storm at Gull Island.
A Hawkins-class heavy cruiser that sank in fog at Point Amour in Strait of Belle Isle.
An A. Harvey & Company bulk carrier that ran aground and sank off Petty Harbour-Maddox Cove while under tow during a southeast gale.  All 19 crew were lost.
An iron-ore carrier that was torpedoed by U-518 off Bell Island.
An iron-ore carrier that was torpedoed by a U-513 off Wabana, Newfoundland.
A Basque whaling ship that sank at Red Bay, Labrador.
Cod-fishing trawler, it burned down in November 1972 in Saint Pierre (French Newfoundland) and was sunk in the vicinity.
A fifth-rate warship that was scuttled to prevent capture by France.
A schooner that sank in a storm near Spotted Island, Labrador.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-1228 off Channel-Port aux Basques.
A Newfoundland sealing steamer that was lost in a blizzard.

A British passenger liner operated by the White Star Line that sank in the North Atlantic Ocean 370 miles (600 km) south-southeast of Newfoundland, Canada on 15 April 1912, after striking an iceberg during her maiden voyage.
Sunk in a storm near Bay Bulls.
A Type VIIC U-boat sunk by depth charges off Newfoundland.
A Type IXC U-boat sunk by Canadian aircraft off St. John's.
A Type VIIC U-boat sunk by depth charges off Cape Race.
A sealing barque that exploded off Horse Islands during the shooting of extra footage for the film The Viking, killing 27, including the film's producer.
A schooner that was lost at Cape St. Francis.
Sunk near Pouch Cove.
A Canadian National ferry that struck an iceberg.
Arctic exploration ship, part of the McClure Arctic expedition. Icebound in Mercy Bay, abandoned June 1853. Found in the Beaufort Sea, July 2010.
A buoy tender that ran aground on the wreck of Snipe off Seal Island.
An oil tanker that ran aground off Isle Madame.
A White Star Line ocean liner that ran aground near Meagher's Island.
A full-rigged transport, run aground on the northeastern side of Cape Breton Island.
A steamship that foundered off Cape Sable Island while under tow.
A French warship that caught fire and burned in the siege of Louisbourg.
A hydrographic survey vessel and training ship that was scuttled off Sydney.
A French warship that caught fire and burned in the siege of Louisbourg.
A French navy transport ship that was swept by a storm onto rocks near Louisbourg.
A CN Marine car ferry that ran aground and sank off Little Hope Island, near Port Mouton.
A floating medical clinic that struck a reef off the Eastern Shore.
A Bangor-class minesweeper that was torpedoed by U-806 near Sambro Island Light.
A brig that caught fire and only 3 of the 24 crew survived.

A Newfoundland herring seiner fishing vessel which sank during a storm off the northeast coast of Cape Breton Island. All eight crew were lost. The vessel Patrick Morris, while assisting in the search-and-rescue mission, also sank.
A French warship struck with cannon fire by the Royal Navy off Louisbourg, burned and exploded.
A tugboat that sank in Halifax Harbour on 6 June 1943, when she collided with the freighter Norelg; she was raised so that the bodies of the dead could be recovered, then re-sunk on 24 August.
A schooner that hit a submerged wreck off Sable Island.
A Bangor-class minesweeper that was torpedoed by U-190 off Chebucto Head.
A brig-sloop that ran aground near the village of Prospect.
A fifth-rate warship that was wrecked off Louisbourg.
An Irish famine ship which was holed by ice between Nova Scotia and Newfoundland.
A wooden schooner that was accidentally rammed by the steamer Strathcona off Point Pleasant Park.
A steamship wrecked off Cape Sable Island, with the loss of 205 lives.

Halifax Explosion: The cargo ship collided with Mont-Blanc ( France) at Halifax, Nova Scotia. Mont-Blanc caught fire and was obliterated in a massive explosion that killed approximately 2,000 people and drove Imo ashore. Imo subsequently was refloated, repaired, and returned to service.
A Gleaves-class destroyer that collided with USS Chemung.
A Flower-class corvette that was scuttled off the coast of Nova Scotia.
A wooden cargo ship that ran aground at Low Point in Sydney harbour.

An Irish famine ship which sank in Cabot Strait. They sailed from Limerick, Ireland for Quebec, carrying a crew of 10 plus 111 Irish emigrants. Sailing near midnight in a severe storm, the sailing ship sank immediately when it hit an iceberg, about 50 miles (80 km) from St. Paul Island. Only 12 on board survived.

A freighter that collided with Imo in Halifax Harbour, causing a fire that detonated her cargo of military explosives. The resulting Halifax Explosion killed an estimated 2000 people, and fragments of Mont-Blanc were scattered across Halifax and Dartmouth.

A Canadian National Railways train ferry that sank in a storm off the northeast coast of Cape Breton Island while assisting in a search and rescue operation for the sinking fishing trawler Enterprise. Four crew, including the captain, were lost.
A French warship burned following the siege of Louisbourg.
A St. Laurent-class destroyer scuttled as an artificial reef off Lunenburg.
A steamboat that sank en route to be sold for scrap at Sydney.
A barque that ran aground off Pictou.
A frigate that sank off Herring Cove.
A sailing ship wrecked on the coast of Cape Breton Island.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by depth charges near Yarmouth.
A troopship that carried members of the 43rd (Monmouthshire) Regiment of Foot.
A British barque sent to resupply Sir Edward Belcher's expedition to locate the missing Franklin expedition. Crushed by ice south of Beechey Island, August 1853. Found in Barrow Strait, August 1980.

A Hecla-class bomb vessel that was used for Arctic exploration, flagship of Sir John Franklin's lost expedition. Abandoned in Victoria Strait, April 1848. Found in Wilmot and Crampton Bay, September 2014.
A Hecla-class bomb vessel that was used for Arctic exploration, and was abandoned in Prince Regent Inlet.

An Arctic exploration vessel that froze up at Cambridge Bay in 1926, whereafter she was used as a floating warehouse and wireless station until she sank four years later. In 2016 she was raised and in 2017 began her return to Norway.
A steamship that was wrecked near Cape Dorset.

A Vesuvius-class bomb vessel that had participated in the Battle of Fort McHenry during the War of 1812, and later used for Arctic exploration. Part of Sir John Franklin's lost expedition. Abandoned in Victoria Strait, April 1848. Found in Terror Bay, September 2016.

A 99 feet (30 m) wooden rear paddle wheeler steamership that caught fire in front of the Rideau Canal in the Ottawa River and sank in Ottawa. It was relocated under the Rideau Canoe Club wharf at the beginning of the 1980s. Only the hull can be seen.
A wooden cargo ship that caught fire and sank off Cardinal.
A bulk carrier that sank in the Saint Lawrence River near Morrisburg.
A 105 feet (32 m) schooner that caught fire and sank off Kettle Island, opposite Gatineau.
A 100 feet (30 m) paddle sidewheeler that caught fire, exploded and sunk at dock in Gatineau.
A 96 feet (29 m) wooden schooner, formerly Ville de Vanier, that was abandoned.
A drill-boat containing dynamite which was struck by lightning, resulting in an explosion which killed thirty people.
A schooner that hit rocks and sank near Brockville.
The wooden paddle steamer sank in Ottawa
The 104 feet (32 m) steamer caught fire and sank in Ottawa
A steamboat wrecked on a reef near Collingwood.
The 95 feet (29 m) barge leaked and sank in Ottawa at the West exit of the 8 locks of the Rideau Canal, near Parliament Hill
A schooner that was scuttled in the Nottawasaga River to prevent capture, during the War of 1812.
The 102 feet (31 m) tugboat caught fire and sank in Ottawa at the West exit of the 8 locks of the Rideau Canal, near Parliament Hill
Wrecked in the Flood of 1883, London, Ontario.
A 100 feet (30 m) wooden steamship, formerly Salaberry, that leaked and sank in Ottawa.
A 78 feet (24 m) ship that leaked and sank in Ottawa.
The 56 feet (17 m) tugboat caught fire and sank in Ottawa
Stranded on the Canadian side of Niagara River above Horseshoe Falls.
A ferry that capsized and sank near London, Ontario, with the loss of 181 lives.
A 95 feet (29 m) paddle wheeler that was abandoned and sank in Ottawa.
A 4-gun schooner that was wrecked in Charlottetown harbour or Hillsborough Bay, possibly salvaged and broken up in 1799.
A cargo ship that was crushed by pack ice and sank 28 kilometres (15 nmi) off North Cape.
A Great Lakes freighter sold by Canada to the United States for coastal service during World War I. After losing its steering gear off East Point she drifted until running aground off Savage Harbour.
Canadian River-class destroyer that was sold for scrap after seeing action in the Battle of the Atlantic and ran aground after breaking away from her tow off East Point.
A clipper that ran aground on a beach at Cavendish.
A 1,100-tonne steel-hulled barque that ran aground and sank off Hermanville in the Yankee Gale of 1906.
A Doterel-class sloop that ran aground off East Point.
A Mettawee-class gasoline tanker that burned and sank off Charlottetown.
A four-masted barque that ran aground and sank off Priest Pond in the Yankee Gale of 1906.
A passenger cargo ship that struck a reef and sank off East Point.

A steamer owned by Black Diamond Line, which was carrying coal from Pictou, Nova Scotia, to Montreal, Quebec, when it sank after being crushed in the ice off Covehead. All the crew aboard Tunstall made it safely ashore and the wreck is now a popular site for scuba divers.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed and sunk off Cap Chat by U-517.
A Bangor-class minesweeper that collided with Lord Kelvin off Rimouski.
A clipper that sank in fog near Pointe des Monts.
A transatlantic ocean liner that was hit by the coal freighter SS Storstad in the Saint Lawrence River and sank with heavy loss of life.
A troopship that ran aground on Anticosti Island.
A fifth-rate frigate that ran aground and broke apart near Cap des Rosiers in Gaspé.
A buoy tender that sank in a storm near Iles-de-la-Madeleine with all hands on board (44 souls).
A Flower-class corvette that was struck by Polaris at dock in Montreal.

A buoy/lighthouse tender that sank near Montmagny after a collision with the coal carrier Lingan. The incident left 15 dead (one navigation officer and two lightkeeper's families (wives and children)).
A paddle steamer that crashed into the newly built Traffic Bridge on the South Saskatchewan River.
A sternwheeler that sank in a storm on Lake Laberge.
A sternwheeler that hit a rock wall when going around a bend in the Yukon River. It then lost control, ran aground, and sank on a gravel bar.
A fishing sloop that was wrecked on the northern reefs.
A schooner that was wrecked on the reefs en route to Nova Scotia.
A brigantine that was wrecked on Mills Breakers.
A cargo ship that ran aground on Mills Breakers and was abandoned after several unsuccessful salvage attempts.
A schooner that was wrecked on the southwest reefs.
A brig that was wrecked on a reef en route from England to Baltimore.
A mail steamship that was wrecked on the northern barrier reef.
A fifth-rate warship that was lost at Castle Harbour.
A schooner that was wrecked northeast of St. George's.
A luxury yacht that was wrecked on Mills Breakers in severe weather.
A schooner that was wrecked on a reef with a cargo of drugs, cement, and whiskey, an incident which inspired the novel and film The Deep.
An ocean liner that ran aground on a reef, becoming Bermuda's largest shipwreck.
A barquentine that was wrecked on the northern reefs.
A steamship that was wrecked on the Western Reef.
A merchantman that was wrecked on the northeast breakers.
A yacht that was wrecked close to the Eagle.
An unidentified ship, wrecked around 1750; found in 1983.
An American ship that was scuttled as a dive wreck one mile off shore.
A frigate that was wrecked on a reef in rough weather.
A sloop that foundered in a series of storms and was wrecked on the rocks at Hogfish Cut.
A Norwegian steamer also known as Aristo, that grounded after mistaking the Colon wreck for a ship still underway. She was recovered from the reef, but sank under tow the following day.
A British steamer that struck a reef and was run aground to prevent her from sinking.
A brigantine that was wrecked en route to Jamaica.
An American tug that was scuttled as the first intentionally created dive site in Bermuda.
A cargo ship that ran aground near Western Blue Cut, after just five years of operation.
A British armed transport and hospital ship that was wrecked on the western reefs.
A passenger steamer, formerly the Balmoral Castle, that struck a reef near Hamilton Harbour.
An unidentified ship, wrecked mid-18th century.
An American Civil War blockade runner that struck a reef while being piloted by a Bermudian, and sank within eight minutes.
A Spanish privateer that was wrecked on the reefs, and discovered in the early 1960s.
A cargo ship that ran aground on the reefs, and although later recovered, sank en route to St. George's.
An American Civil War blockade runner that hit a reef off the north shore.
A Bermudian fishing ketch that was wrecked on the western reefs.
A barque that was wrecked south of Gibs Hill Lighthouse.
A Greek steamer that was wrecked off David's Head.
A cargo ship, formerly the Herodot, that was wrecked near Elbow Beach.
A Canadian yacht that was wrecked in 1967, refloated for salvaging, and re-sunk near the Royal Naval Dockyard.
A cargo ship that caught fire and sank following a storm.
A Portuguese nao that was wrecked on the west reefs, and discovered in 1960.

A 350-ton Spanish ship that was wrecked to the north of the main island, and discovered in 1951. Valuable treasures and artifacts have been raised, including a 32-ounce gold bar, two smaller gold bars, and an emerald-studded gold cross.
An English ship that was deliberately grounded after taking damage in a storm, and subsequently broke up and sank.
A Norwegian steamer that was wrecked on the northern reefs.
A passenger and cargo ship that ran aground off Sonesta Beach.
A coastal defence ship that was scuttled as a blockship off Daniel's Head.
An English cargo ship that was sunk in a gale in Castle Harbour.
An English steamer that ran aground off Gibs Hill Light. The ship was refloated but then abandoned at Five Fathom's Hole, and later blown up as a hazard to navigation.
A cargo ship, also known as Zovetta or Rita Zovetto, that ran aground off St. David's Light.
A sloop-of-war that struck a reef off Man-O-War Cay.
A Pygmy-class schooner that was wrecked on the Little Bahama Bank.
A brig that ran aground on a reef.
A Conqueror-class ship of the line that was wrecked on Rum Cay.
A storeship and gunboat that ran aground in the Abaco Islands.
A cargo ship that was sunk by Hurricane Joaquin near Crooked Island.
A cargo ship that was scuttled as a dive site and artificial reef about two miles offshore of Xanadu Beach Resort & Marina, Grand Bahama; known as "Theo's Wreck".
A schooner employed in anti-slave trade patrol until it struck a reef in the Old Bahama Channel.
A steam frigate that struck a reef near Great Abaco Island.
A cargo steamer run aground near Bimini during a hurricane.
A British frigate wrecked on Anegada's Horseshoe Reef.
A British sloop that caught fire, foundered, and sank in Road Town's harbour.
A British packet ship wrecked during a hurricane off the coast of Salt Island.
An Infanta Maria Teresa-class armored cruiser that was scuttled about 700 metres (2,300 ft) offshore in the Battle of Santiago de Cuba.
A Giuseppe Garibaldi-class armored cruiser that was sunk in the Battle of Santiago de Cuba.
A steamship that was sunk by Spanish cruisers in the harbor at Santiago de Cuba.
An Infanta Maria Teresa-class armored cruiser that was sunk in the Battle of Santiago de Cuba.
A freighter that ran aground and broke in two off the coast of Punta Cana.
Originally a tourist mover that was to be sunk as an artificial reef off the coast of Bayahibe, but sunk accidentally right in front of Dreams resort.
Scuttled in the area of Juan Dolio at depths ranging from 24 to 60 feet (7.3 to 18.3 m).
A Spanish galleon that ran aground during a hurricane in Samaná Bay.
A French ship lost in the fierce maritime Battle of Palenque, in the 17th century, in Palenque, Bani.
A 64-foot-long (20 m) fishing boat, and sister ship of the Hickory. It lies in El Portillo, Las Terrenas, and has served as an underwater base for rescue operations.

A 140-foot-long (43 m) former US Coast Guard vessel, commanded by Captain Tracy Bowden for underwater exploration and rescue operations, the Hickory was sunk by Hurricane George while carrying 50 passengers. All survived. It is now a national park in La Caleta, Santo Domingo.
A French ship lost in the Battle of Palenque, in the 17th century, in Palenque, Bani.

An old tugboat 155 feet (47 m) long that rests in about 80 feet (24 m) of water very close to the Hickory in the same park. This ship was scuttled there for the same reason – to serve as a tourist attraction. The depth where this shipwreck lies varies from 27–60 feet (8.2–18.3 m). The three propellers of this tugboat are still clearly visible.
Sunk in the 17th century in Samaná Bay.
Thought to have been a merchant trader, probably sunk in the latter part of the 17th century. Named for the large number of clay smoking pipes it carried as cargo.
A Spanish galleon sunk by a hurricane in Samaná Bay.

SHIP: Nuestra Señora de la Limpia y Pura Concepción, known as La Concepción
NOTES:
This Spanish treasure ship built in 1620 was reportedly overloaded with silver bullion for its return journey to Spain as part of the 1641 treasure fleet.
The fleet sailed from Havana on September 20, 1641 but was heavily hit by a hurricane nine days later. Concepción got separated from the main fleet and tried to make for Puerto Rico, but on October 31 foundered and sank on a sand bank north of Hispaniola, which is now called Silver Bank after this shipwreck.
First found by William Phips in 1687, his operation managed to salvage 34 tons of silver and other treasure[a]. Back in England the expedition's revenue was assessed as £205,536[b].
In the 20th century it was the object of several known treasure hunting expeditions: A. Korganoff in 1952, Edwin Link in 1955, Falcon-Barker in 1962 and Cousteau in 1968, until finally being re-discovered by Burt Webber in 1978. More than 95,000 silver coins, Ming Dynasty ceramics, gold chains, and many other artifacts were salvaged at that time.

An Indian merchant vessel captured on 30 January 1696 by William Kidd, who renamed it the Adventure Prize. Shortly before he was arrested for piracy, Kidd entrusted the ship to hired merchants, who sold off most of the goods, set fire to the ship, and absconded to Holland. The wreck was discovered in 2007 off the coast of Catalina Island.

A French ship that took part in the blockade against Cornwallis and thus was instrumental in the American Revolutionary War; sunk in a battle against the British fleet. Found and positively identified by Tracy Bowden. Recovered October 2009 by Deep Blue Marine Inc.
Sunk as an artificial reef near La Romana.
A passenger ship that was torpedoed and sunk by a German submarine in 1944, before construction on the ship was completed. It sank for the second time near St. George's, following an explosion.
A celebrated Canadian racing schooner that foundered on a reef off Île à Vache.
A cruiser that was scuttled to prevent capture while harboured at Gonaïves.

A brigantine found in 1872 in the Atlantic Ocean, unmanned and under full sail, heading towards the Strait of Gibraltar. It was later deliberately run aground and burned in an insurance fraud attempt, off the western coast of Port-au-Prince.
A container ship that capsized off Saint Lucia.
A supply ship that was scuttled to prevent capture off Aruba.
A ferry boat that sank off St. Kitts.
An Abeille-class brig that ran aground off Martinique and was scuttled to prevent capture.
A drug-smuggling ship that was seized by the authorities at Bonaire, then took on water and sank at harbour.
A lake tanker that was torpedoed by U-156, and later towed into a dry dock and cut in three. The fore and aft sections were joined together, and the middle section was sunk as a target.
An ocean liner that ran aground on a reef near the island of Mustique.
An Empire F type coaster that sprung a leak and sank under tow off Port of Spain.

SHIP: 2009 Turks and Caicos Islands migrant shipwreck
NOTES: A wooden boat carrying migrants from Haiti that capsized near West Caicos.
A schooner that was wrecked on Endymion Rock.
Early 16th-century Spanish shipwreck, the earliest European shipwreck in the Americas to be scientifically excavated.
A Spanish slave ship that was wrecked off East Caicos. The crew were arrested upon reaching land, and the 168 Africans took up residence at Grand Turk Island.
A cargo ship that was bombed and sunk off Puerto San José by the CIA, who were engineering a coup d'état in Guatemala.
A patrol boat that caught fire off Puerto Vallarta.
A Crosley-class high speed transport that ran aground on Bahia Peninsula.
An extreme clipper that was wrecked in a gale and drifted ashore at Manzanillo.
A H-class submarine that ran aground off Isla Santa Margarita.
An Admirable-class minesweeper that was sunk as an artificial reef off Veracruz.
A Restigouche-class destroyer that was sunk as an artificial reef.
A schooner that wrecked while being towed across the bar at Tampico.
A schooner that ran aground on Sacramento Reef, 4.5 miles (7.2 km) off the coast of Baja California.
A Restigouche-class destroyer that was sunk as an artificial reef off Acapulco.
An Admirable-class minesweeper that was sunk off Cozumel.
A brig that capsized off Veracruz.
A cargo ship that was wrecked on a reef near Remedios District.
A merchant vessel that sank in a storm at the mouth of the Chagres River. The wreck was rediscovered in 2011.
A submersible that was used for harvesting oysters and pearls in the Pearl Islands, until it was abandoned in 1869.
A Hunt-class minesweeper that struck a mine and foundered under tow off Harwich.
A Japanese ocean liner that struck a German mine off Harwich.
A trawler that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
A Norwegian barque that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
A Spanish cargo ship that was sunk by the Spanish Nationalist auxiliary cruiser Nadir northeast of Cromer, during the Spanish Civil War.
A merchant ship grounded on Hammond Knoll.
A naval trawler that was sunk by German aircraft off Winterton Ness.
A merchant vessel that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
An oil tanker that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
A third rate ship that sank off Great Yarmouth.
A spritsail that foundered off East Runton.
A merchant vessel that was stranded on the Scroby Sands.
A third rate warship that struck rocks off Happisburgh.
A fourth rate frigate that sank off Cromer.
A merchant vessel that was stranded on the wreck of the SS Monte Nevoso at Haisborough Sands, and then bombed by German aircraft.
A merchant vessel that ran aground on Haisborough Sands.
A merchant vessel that ran aground on Ower Bank.
Wrecked on Scroby Sands.
A U-class submarine that collided with the Peter Hendriks off Blakeney.
A German liner sunk in the North Sea after colliding with the steamship Crathie.
A Hunt-class destroyer that was attacked by E-boats and capsized off Lowestoft.
A steam collier that was sunk by a mine east of Southwold.
A passenger ship that struck a mine and sank 5 nautical miles (9.3 km) southeast of Aldeburgh.
A ferry that capsized off Landguard Fort while overburdened with foot soldiers, women and children.
A cargo ship that struck a mine off Thorpeness.
A cargo ship that was sunk by mine off Aldeburgh.
A Type IIB U-boat that was sunk by HMS Weston 11 nautical miles (20 km) southeast of Lowestoft.
A tug scuttled at Stoney Cove to create an artificial reef.
A protected wreck lying in the intertidal zone at Seaton Carew.
A German steamer wrecked on the Farne Islands.
A Racecourse-class minesweeper that was torpedoed by UB-67 off the Farne Islands.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-9 east of Coquet Island.
A paddlesteamer that foundered on the Farne Islands.
A G-class submarine that ran aground near Howick.
A Type UB III U-boat that was sunk by British forces off Newton-by-the-Sea.
A U-class submarine that collided with Atle Jarl off Blyth.
Ran aground off Beadnell Point.
A cargo ship that was sunk by mine east of Roker.
An ocean liner that hit a mine off South Shields.
A German U-boat that struck its own naval mine at Sunderland.
A barque that was caught in a storm and ran aground at Bispham, Blackpool.
A RO-RO ferry that ran aground on Blackpool beach and was finally scrapped in place after refloating attempts failed.
A lightship sunk in a collision in Liverpool Bay.
A privateer that sank in the River Mersey.

Ionic Star was a Blue Star Line cargo ship crashed on the mad wharf sandbank (a mile from Formby point) on a journey from Rio to Liverpool. Her cargo was salvaged and later used as target practice for the Royal Air Force.
Struck a mine off Hastings.
A Dutch East India Company ship that ran aground near Hastings. The wreck site is protected.
A Diadem-class cruiser torpedoed off Beachy Head by German submarine UC-65.
A Holland-class submarine that foundered off Beachy Head while under tow to be scrapped.
An armed merchantman torpedoed off Beachy Head by UB-57.
A Swiss cargo ship that ran aground at Berwickshire in 1958, but was salvaged and repaired. It sank for the final time off Beachy Head, following a collision.
A Norwegian motor tanker that exploded off the coast of Eastbourne.
A British coaster sunk by a German torpedo near Hastings.
A German submarine sunk by a mine off Eastbourne.
A German submarine sunk by a mine 15 nautical miles (28 km) south of Brighton.
A German minelaying submarine torpedoed by HMS C15 off Eastbourne.
A British Cargo Ship sunk after a collision, 11.5 nautical miles (21.3 km) off Beachy Head. Attended by Hastings Lifeboat.
Henry V's flagship, struck by lightning in the River Hamble. Now a protected wrecksite. Wreck found in 1859.
A Téméraire-class ship of the line that took part in the Glorious First of June. It was captured by the British and accidentally destroyed in a fire at Portsmouth.
A ship of the line that ran aground in the East Solent.
A Tudor warship sunk in Portsmouth Harbour, possibly during an engagement with the French fleet. Now a protected wrecksite
A fourth-rate frigate wrecked at Spithead in the Great Storm of 1703.
A first-rate ship of the line that sank at anchor off Portsmouth, with the loss of over 800 lives.
An A-class destroyer sunk by a mine off St. Catherine's Point.
A Flower-class corvette sunk by U-480 off St. Catherine's Point.
A Canadian ship sunk  by a torpedo from a German aircraft off St. Catherine's Point.
A frigate wrecked off The Needles.
An Ardent-class destroyer that collided with SS St Patrick off Culver Down.
A steam powered tugboat, sank and wrecked in Compton Bay; still visible at low tide.
A German ocean liner that ran aground on the Back of the Wight.
A Dryad-class torpedo gunboat that collided with SS Western Australia off Seaview.
A sailing ship wrecked at Scratchell's Bay, near The Needles.
A German coastal trading vessel captured by the British Navy, and bombed by German aircraft off St. Catherine's Point.
An Algerine-class minesweeper sunk by U-480.

A mail steamer that collided with the steamship Mary near The Needles.
A Königsberg-class cruiser that was scuttled in Scapa Flow in 1919, but was raised by Allied forces and ultimately sunk as a target.
A Raven-class minesweeper sunk by a mine.
A Leda-class frigate that served in the Napoleonic Wars, and was wrecked off The Needles.
A 1,028 GRT merchant vessel sank in heavy seas 6.6 nautical miles (12.2 km) SW from the Isle of Wight.
An S-class submarine sunk when she struck a mine 12 nautical miles (22 km) S of St. Catherine's Point.
A German submarine sunk by HMS Watchman.
A German submarine sunk by a mine.
A German submarine that struck a mine and then collided with a patrol boat.
A Greek merchant steamship that ran aground off The Needles.
A torpedo boat destroyer that struck a mine and subsequently sank under tow about 1.5 nautical miles (2.8 km) east of Bembridge.
A French corvette captured by the British and renamed Scout. She was wrecked off The Needles.
An Active-class scout cruiser sunk by a mine laid by SS Königin Luise.
A River-class destroyer that collided with SS Hero east of New Romney.
A B-class destroyer sunk by German dive bombers off Folkestone.
A Formidable-class battleship that exploded off Sheerness with the loss of 736 men.
An A-class destroyer bombed whilst in dock at Dover.
A passenger steamship that ran aground on the Kentish Knock.
A paddle steamer that was sunk by a mine north of Thanet.
A Tribal-class destroyer that hit a mine off Dungeness.
A turret ship that collided with SMS König Wilhelm off Folkestone, resulting in 269 deaths.
An East Indiaman caught in a gale off Margate.
A cargo ship that struck a mine southeast of Folkestone.
A passenger ship that was sunk by a mine off Folkestone.
A minesweeper that was torpedoed by U-12 off Deal.
An American transatlantic ship that ran aground off Thanet.
A Blackwall Frigate that was rammed by a steamer while at anchor off Dungeness, resulting in the loss of 293 lives.
An Acasta-class destroyer in action against eight German torpedo boats was torpedoed in the Strait of Dover.
A five-masted windjammer that was rammed by SS Brighton, and subsequently driven onto rocks off the coast of Dover.
A steamship torpedoed by German destroyer S-60 off the Varne Bank.
A steamship wrecked at Tongue Sands off Margate.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by UB-57 about 9 nautical miles (17 km) southeast of Folkestone.
A German submarine sunk by a mine off Dover.
A German submarine that struck a mine off the Varne Bank.
A Type UB III U-boat that was sunk by a mine.
A Type UB III U-boat that was sunk by a mine.
A Type UB III U-boat that was sunk by a mine.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by HMS Zubian off Dungeness.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by a mine off the Varne Bank.
A V-class destroyer that was sunk by a mine 12 nautical miles (22 km) northeast of Margate.
A merchant vessel sunk in a storm.
A cargo ship wrecked in heavy seas.
A Naval Trawler destroyed by a mine laid by SM UC-1
A Nourse Line sailing ship wrecked en route from Middlesbrough to Calcutta.
A German brig driven onto the South Sand Head by hurricane-force winds.
A steamship that ran aground and broke in two.
A steamship that ran aground and broke in two.
A brig that became stranded in rough weather. Its crew were rescued by a lifeboat which subsequently took the name Mary White.
A transatlantic ocean liner, upon which the murderer Hawley Crippen was arrested while attempting to flee to Canada. The ship was wrecked when she broke loose from her moorings during a gale.
A third-rate ship of the line wrecked in the Great Storm of 1703, with 220 deaths.
A third-rate ship of the line wrecked in the Great Storm of 1703, with 387 deaths.
An East Indiaman that was wrecked in a heavy storm with the loss of all hands. The wreck was discovered in 2004.
A third-rate ship of the line wrecked in the Great Storm of 1703.
A German submarine that ran aground while under attack from HMS Puffin and HMS Cayton Wyke.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by HMS Liberty.
A German minelaying submarine torpedoed by HMS E52.
A naval trawler sune in the Thames Estuary.
A small sailing ship discovered in Blackfriars along the banks of the Thames.
A ship that was most likely carrying supplies to rebuild after the Great Fire of 1666.
These ships collided with each other. The Blackfriar III is the most complete medieval sailing ship found in Great Britain.
A merchantman and convict ship that was stranded on a sandbank near Blackwall.
A second-rate ship of the line that accidentally exploded in the Thames Estuary, killing 300 crewmen.
A pleasure boat and former little ship of Dunkirk that collided with the dredger Bowbelle near Cannon Street railway bridge, with 51 deaths.
An Elizabethan wreck discovered in the Thames Estuary in 2004.
A paddle steamer that collided with the Bywell Castle near North Woolwich, with over 650 deaths.
A Liberty ship that ran aground off the Nore in the Thames Estuary with over a thousand tons of explosives on board. A protected wreck site, designated as dangerous.
A clipper wrecked at the mouth of the Thames.
An A-class submarine sunk as a target of the Isle of Portland.
Struck a mine off Hastings. Amsterdam 26 January 1749 A Dutch East India Company ship that ran aground near Hastings. The wreck site is protected.
A Diadem-class cruiser torpedoed off Beachy Head by German submarine UC-65
A Holland-class submarine that foundered off Beachy Head while under tow to be scrapped.
An armed merchantman torpedoed off Beachy Head by UB-57.
A Swiss cargo ship that ran aground at Berwickshire in 1958, but was salvaged and repaired. It sank for the final time off Beachy Head, following a collision.
A Norwegian motor tanker that exploded off the coast of Eastbourne.
A British coaster sunk by a German torpedo near Hastings.
A German submarine sunk by a mine off Eastbourne.
A German submarine sunk by a mine 15 nautical miles (28 km) south of Brighton.
A German minelaying submarine torpedoed by HMS C15 off Eastbourne.
A British Cargo Ship sunk after a collision, 11.5 nautical miles (21.3 km) off Beachy Head. Attended by Hastings Lifeboat.

Three mast Barque (Bark. Nor). Sailing from Brunswick Georgia to Bristol England. Forced ashore at Berrow beach, Somerset, by a storm. All crew and the ship's dog were rescued. The hull remains as a wreck on the beach to this day.
A collier torpedoed by German submarine U-20.
A cutter that was torpedoed by German submarine UB-91.
A battleship run aground in fog on Shutter Reef, Lundy.
Distilling ship bombed off Devon coast; salvaged and towed to Woodspring Bay for trials and target practice.
A collier hit by bombs off Dartmouth; towed to Woodspring Bay, near Weston, for trials and target practice . The MOD base at St Thomas Head used the vessel for trials after WW2.
Sunk off Weston-super-mare for target training and 'blockship' trials.
An A-class submarine that sank in Whitsand Bay.
A barquentine that was driven ashore at Bass Point.
A third rate ship of the line wrecked off Loe Bar.
A barque wrecked off Doom Bar.
Lost in a heavy storm off Lizard Point; 12 crew perished.
A Scottish fishing trawler wrecked near Falmouth.
A brig that was wrecked near Morwenstow.
A steam merchant that was torpedoed by U-1018 off Lizard Point.
A steamship torpedoed by U-boat UB-57 off Mevagissey.
A River-class destroyer that struck a mine southeast of the Rame Peninsula.
A steamship that sank after taking damage in a storm.
A brigantine driven ashore near Perranporth.
A Liberty ship, situated in 22 metres (72 ft) of water in Whitsand Bay next to the wreck of HMS Scylla.
A cargo ship and mine carrier that was torpedoed by German submarine UC-17 off The Lizard.
A brig that struck rocks at Rump Point.
A merchant ship wrecked off Land's End in rough weather.
Wrecked on The Manacles.
German cargo ship that ran ashore at Land's End. Five crew members were airlifted to safety.
A Cruizer-class brig-sloop that ran aground at The Manacles.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-667 north of Trevose Head.
Torpedoed by UB-40 off Fowey.
A type F71 Frigate sunk to create an artificial reef for divers and marine life by the National Marine Aquarium.
A Portuguese carrack that foundered in Gunwalloe Bay.
A steamship that was scuttled after catching fire in the Carrick Roads.
A supertanker wrecked on Seven Stones reef.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-1004 near Falmouth.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by Allied forces southwest of Lizard Point.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was sunk by HMS Loch Fada in the English Channel.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was sunk by a mine 7 nautical miles (13 km) off Newquay.
A German submarine sunk by HMS Loch Killin off Salcombe.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was sunk by HMS Icarus and HMS Mignonette south of Gwennap Head.
A Type UB III U-boat that sunk for unknown reasons northwest of Doom Bar.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by armed trawler Sea King off Landewednack.
A Norwegian cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-95.
A Canadian cargo ship that struck a mine in Falmouth Bay.
A Baltimore clipper that ran aground on the Doom Bar.
A mini-bulk carrier that ran aground near Mousehole. It caused the Penlee lifeboat disaster.
The SV Carl was impounded by British forces during the First World War and was suspected of being a minelayer. It was being towed to London when it ran aground on Booby's Bay.
A Large S26 Class Schnellboote (also called S-boat or E-boat). That ran aground in Tremoutha Haven after breaking free for being towed.
A frigate that served in the French Revolutionary Wars and the Napoleonic Wars, eventually blown ashore at Mount Batten.
A fifth-rate ship that exploded while undergoing repairs at Plymouth.
Wooden ship, first to be protected under Protection of Wrecks Act 1973.
A former fishing trawler sunk by a mine off Plymouth.
A battleship sunk as a target in Lyme Bay.
A Formidable-class battleship sunk off Start Point by German submarine U-24.
A River-class destroyer that struck a mine in the Strait of Dover but sank while under tow to Plymouth
A luxury yacht sunk as an underwater training facility near Fort Bovisand.
A clipper wrecked off Salcombe.
A German-built barque that was beached at the Kingsbridge Estuary and later capsized.
A cargo ship that sank in the English Channel.
Sank in Rapparee Cove, North Devon in stormy weather, while carrying prisoners and treasure from the Caribbean island of Saint Lucia.
A Belgian steamer that ran aground near Thurlestone.
A US Navy tank landing ship run aground while attempting to enter Plymouth harbour.
An M-class submarine that collided with the SS Vidar in the English Channel.
A British aircraft-carrying submarine shipwrecked in Lyme Bay.
A steamship torpedoed by UC-17 off Dartmouth.
A French ship torpedoed by UB-40.

A Hunt-class destroyer sunk by E-boats off Start Point.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-1017 off the Eddystone Rocks.
A hospital ship torpedoed by German submarine U-55.
A Type VIID U-boat that was sunk by HMS Cooke southeast of Salcombe.
A German submarine sunk by HMS Bickerton off Torquay.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by HMS Opossum off Start Point.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by a mine off Salcombe.
A first-rate ship of the line that was lost in a storm, and discovered in 2009 near Salcombe.
An A-class submarine sunk off Bracklesham Bay.
A Greek freighter that collided with another ship near the Channel Islands, and sank off St Alban's Head.
A battleship sunk as a target in Lyme Bay.
An East Indiaman driven ashore in a storm at Wyke Regis.
A German merchant ship that collided with SS Thor off Portland Bill.
A Dutch cargo ship that struck a mine and sank off Portland Bill.
An Avon-class destroyer that collided with SS Kenilworth off the Isle of Portland.

A merchant ship converted into an anti-aircraft ship, sunk by German Stuka off the Isle of Portland.
A pre-dreadnought battleship sunk as a blockship in Portland Harbour.
An Audacious-class battleship that sank in a storm off Portland Bill.
A luxury liner sunk by German submarine UB-57 near Swanage.
An L-class submarine that collided with HMS Resolution off Portland Bill.
A tank landing ship sunk by German E-boats off the Isle of Portland.
A Danish steamship sunk by UB-40 off Portland Bill.
An S-class submarine that sunk while under tow to be scrapped.
An S-class submarine that sunk in Portland Harbour on 16 June 1955 following an explosion. It was later raised and sunk as a target off Weymouth.
The remains of a 17th-century armed merchantman wrecked outside Poole Harbour.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by HMCS Calgary south of Weymouth.
A steam yacht bombed off the Isle of Portland.
A second rate ship of the line wrecked in the Scilly naval disaster of 1707, with about 800 dead.
A merchant vessel that ran aground off St Mary's.
A protected wreck site, broke anchor and ran aground off Samson.
A steam passenger and cargo ship sunk by German submarine UC-49
A third rate ship of the line wrecked in the Scilly naval disaster of 1707.
A passenger ship that was wrecked off the Eastern Isles.
A fireship wrecked in the Scilly naval disaster of 1707.
An East Indiaman wrecked off the island of Annet with 276 deaths.
A Tucker-class destroyer torpedoed by German submarine U-53
A K-class submarine that sank en route to a mock battle.
A passenger ship that was wrecked on a reef off Samson.
A barque wrecked off Peninnis Head.
A packet ship that ran aground on the Western Rocks.
A fishing vessel that struck rocks off Peninnis Head.
A fourth-rate ship of the line wrecked in the Scilly naval disaster of 1707.
A German ocean liner wrecked on the Retarrier Ledges, with 335 deaths.
An Irish steamship that ran aground on Cribewidden Rock.
An American schooner wrecked off the island of Annet, spilling 58,000 barrels of kerosene.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by HMS Ariel
An unidentified shipwreck located off Little Ganinick, believed to date from around 1835.
A collier that was bombed by German aircraft off Middlesbrough.
A Town-class cruiser sunk by U-63 off Hornsea.
A cargo ship that was sunk by UB-41 off Whitby.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by UB-48 off Whitby.
A Polish ocean liner sunk off Grimsby.
A steamship that struck a reef near Whitby.
An experimental Confederate submarine that sank in Mobile Bay while under tow during a storm.
A commercial steamboat that caught fire and sank in the Tombigbee River, and subsequently entered Alabama folklore as a ghost ship.
A Confederate side-wheel gunboat sunk in Mobile Bay after heavy damage during the Battle of Mobile Bay.
A Confederate ironclad warship scuttled in Spanish River to avoid capture.
A Union side-wheel gunboat sunk in Mobile Bay after heavy damage during the Battle of Mobile Bay.
A Confederate ironclad warship scuttled at Dog River.
A Union stern-wheel tinclad minesweeper and gunboat sunk by a naval mine (called a "torpedo" at the time) in Mobile Bay.
A Union monitor warship sunk by a naval mine (called a "torpedo" at the time) during the Battle of Mobile Bay.
A Confederate ironclad warship scuttled in Spanish River to avoid capture.
A factory ship that flooded and sank off Unalaska.
A passenger steamer, wrecked on Point Augusta.
A passenger steamer which sank after striking a submerged pinnacle rock.
Russian maritime fur trade vessel Sv. Apostol Pavel wrecked on Amchitka Island.
A passenger steamer, in surf broadside.
A crabbing vessel that sank off Saint Paul Island.

American maritime fur trade ship wrecked at Prince of Wales Island near the Kaigani Haida village of Klinkwan (modern day Hydaburg). Crew left in boats and was picked up by the Volunteer. In early 1819 a party from Volunteer investigated the wreck, finding it on the rocks, full of water, with hundreds of Haida on board or nearby, determined to repel any attempt to salvage anything.
A research vessel that ran ashore in the Gulf of Alaska.
A passenger steamer, brought ashore in Alaska.
Also known as Colebrook; a Hog Islander merchant ship grounded off Middleton Island.
A 98' crabbing vessel that sank in 250' of water amid icy conditions just northwest of St. George Island, Alaska in the Bering Sea. The captain and 5 crew members were lost with the boat.

The Fishing Vessel Scandies Rose Sunk on New Years of 2020 after departing Dutch Harbor on the 30th December 2019. Dean Gribble and John Lawler, were hoisted from a life raft by a Coast Guard helicopter at about 2 a.m New Years Day Five other crewmembers Captain Gary Cobban Jr.; his son, David Cobban; Brock Rainey; Arthur Ganacias; and Seth Rousseau-Gano were not found.
The 390-ton 3-masted barquentine was wrecked having run aground on Bird Island, Alaska, carrying general cargo from San Francisco to Unga Island
A steamboat that was abandoned and washed ashore at Dutch Harbor.
Russian maritime fur trade vessel Sv. Evpl wrecked on Amlia Island.
A passenger steamer, wrecked in the Cook Inlet.

Russian-American Company ship Feniks (or Phoenix) lost at sea while sailing for Kodiak Island. Wreckage washed up from Unalaska Island to the Alexander Archipelago. Greatest maritime catastrophe in the history of Russian America. Loss of the largest Russian American ship, about 103 men, including passengers, Bishop Ioasaf, head of the Russian Ecclesiastical Mission in Alaska, and Captain James Shields. Financial loss of 622,328 rubles. This event greatly slowed the tempo of Russian colonization in America.
Discovered in the Bering Sea in August 2007.
Russian maritime fur trade shitik Sv. Ieremiya wrecked on Adak Island.
A Type C submarine that was sunk by USS Larchmont near Shemya.
A Type B1 submarine sunk by gunfire near Attu Island.
A Canadian steamship sunk in Lynn Canal.
A three-mast full-rigged ship, wrecked in Chignik Bay.  Wooden full-rigged ship owned by the Columbia River Packers Association and used as a cannery tender.

Swamped in turbulent water at the mouth of the Kuskokwim River. 18 miners from the Columbia Exploration Company were believed to have been massacred by Yup'ik Natives or lost with wreck. One person, a trader called Ling, survived to bring word of the wreck to St. Michael. Jessie was towing the barge Minerva and a second unknown barge, which were both lost. Yup'ik Eskimos were said to have looted vessels.
A merchant ship that struck a rock off Spruce Island. The wreck was rediscovered in 2003.
Russian maritime fur trade vessel Karluk wrecked at Kodiak Island.

Hit a reef on Strait Island, near Pt. Baker, while carrying 269 passengers and a full cargo of copper ore and canned salmon. The vessel had previously picked up the crew from the wrecked Al-Ki and the pirates from the wrecked Manhattan. All passengers and crew were rescued before vessel sank by the Curaçao, Ravalli, and Jefferson. She went down with 25,000 cases of salmon and 1,200 tons of copper ore. The reef is now called Mariposa Reef.
A passenger steamer, beached near Scotch Cap, Aleutian Islands.
A Hatsuharu-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS Triton off Agattu Island.

Russian-American Company (RAC) ship Neva wrecked on a reef at Kruzof Island, killing 53 people, including Terentii Stepanovich Bornovolokov, who was to replace Alexander Baranov as Governor of the RAC. Total loss from the wreck over 250,000 rubles. Second gravest marine catastrophe in the history of Russian America, after the loss of Feniks in 1799.
Russian-American Company steamship wrecked near Admiralty Island.
Japanese armed freighter sunk by U.S. bombers in Kiska Harbor.
A fishing vessel that sank in the Gulf of Alaska.
A Fubuki-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft northeast of Kiska.
A whaling schooner wrecked near Nome, Alaska.
Ran aground on Bligh Reef and sank without loss of life.
A steam freighter, wrecked and aground at Cape Fairweather.
Russian maritime fur trade shitik Sv. Petr wrecked on Attu Island. One person died.
A sidewheel steamer built by the Russian-American Company, completed 4,000 miles (6,400 km) before being abandoned in St. Michael near the entrance of the Yukon River.
A steam ship which struck the rocks off Cordova.
A passenger steamer, sunk near Point Lena.  When she went aground at Point Lena rock, the vessel was a mile and a half off course. She was the flagship of the Canadian Pacific Lines.
A passenger liner sunk off Vanderbilt Reef near Juneau, with 343 lives lost.
A cruise ship that caught fire and sank off Baranof Island.
A Rescuer-class rescue and salvage ship that was wrecked in the Aleutian Islands.
An S-class submarine that ran aground off Amchitka.
A cargo ship that ran aground off the coast of Unalaska Island, causing an oil spill.

Japanese junk Sinsyo Maru wrecked on Amchitka Island. Junk was sailing for Edo but damaged in a storm and drifted for over seven months before wrecking on Amchitka Island. With Aleuts and Russian promyshlenniki from another wrecked vessel, the group remained on the island for three years, building a new vessel from the wrecked ships. In September 1787 the survivors sailed to Petropavlovsk.
A wooden bark ship that foundered in a storm and went ashore in Cook Inlet.
Russian maritime fur trade galiot Tri Ierarkha wrecked in Cook Inlet.

Russian maritime fur trade galiot Tri Svyatitelya, owned by Shelikhov-Golikov Company, sailed from Okhotsk for Kodiak Island with passenger Alexander Baranov, future governor of the Russian-American Company. Wrecked on Unalaska Island. With help from Aleuts Baranov and crew survived the winter then continued to Kodiak on native boats.
Russian maritime fur trade vessel Sv. Troitsa wrecked on Umnak Island.
Japanese vessel of unknown name wrecked at Attu Island. Of the 12 crewmen, 9 died.

Japanese vessel wrecked at Biorka Island near Sitka. Had sailed from Sendai, Japan, making for Edo. Damaged in a storm and drifted to Biorka Island. Fifteen survivors were brought by Russians to Unalaska then Okhotsk.
A Clemson-class destroyer sunk by her own depth charges in the Aleutian Islands.
A steamboat that sank in a flood near Lee's Ferry.
A paddle steamer that was captured by the Union Army and scuttled at Camden.
A steamer sunk after striking a snag on the Arkansas River.
A steamer blown up by Confederates after capture on the White River.
Sunk off New London in 1947.
A wooden barge that sank in Bridgeport Harbor.
G-class submarine, sank at mooring near Niantic Bay.
Sunk as target off New London.
A patrol vessel that was accidentally rammed by USS O-13 off Penfield Reef Light.
A wooden barge that sank in Bridgeport Harbor.
A tugboat that foundered in a gale off Fenwick Island.
A minesweeper that ran aground at Cape Henlopen.

She was between the two breakwaters when No. 3's paddlewheels became jammed by ice, and, unable to manoeuvre, the vessel was dragged by the ice floes over a recently sunken barge, the Santiago, one of whose broken masts pierced the ice boat's hull below the waterline. Within minutes, water had extinguished No. 3's furnaces and the order was given to abandon ship. Unable to launch a lifeboat because of the surrounding ice, the crew were forced to leap for safety onto the ice floes, the ice boat sinking shortly thereafter, at about 6 am.
A fleet oil tanker, collided with the Liberian freighter Elna II while passing New Castle, caught fire and exploded.

The ocean liner collided with SS Nantucket in the Atlantic Ocean 50 nautical miles (93 km) off the Delaware Capes and sank with the loss of 41 of the 140 people on board. Survivors were rescued by Nantucket.

A Confederate gunboat that had sunk on the Appalachicola River in Florida when its boiler had exploded, then been raised and returned to Columbus for repairs. She was scuttled in the Chattahoochee River to prevent her capture by Union troops.
A medium clipper that ran aground near Tybee Island.
A Civil War ironclad floating battery scuttled off Savannah.
A Confederate ironclad ram that was burned and scuttled in the Chattahoochee River near Columbus.
A Confederate privateer sunk by USS Montauk in Ogeechee River.
A barque that was scuttled as a blockship near Savannah.
A whaler that was scuttled as a breakwater off Tybee Island.
A whaler that was beached at Tybee Island.
Sank in a hurricane about 100 miles (160 km) southeast of Savannah.
A sidewheel gunboat burned to avoid capture at White Bluff.
A car carrier that capsized in St. Simons Sound. Awaiting scrapping operations as of October 2020.
A Japanese Navy transport sunk in Talofofo Bay.
A German steamer scuttled in Apra Harbor to avoid capture at the start of American involvement in World War I.
A Japanese merchant freighter sunk by torpedo in Apra Harbor.
A Japanese Navy armed transport sunk in Apra Harbor.
A battleship lost in the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor.
A Balao-class submarine sunk as a target off Pearl Harbor.
Russian-American Company ship Bering (also spelled Behring; formerly Atahualpa) wrecked at Waimea Bay, Oahu.
A Balao-class submarine sunk as a target.
A schooner that struck a reef off Molokai.
A sailing boat that was sunk as an artificial reef.
The royal yacht of King Kamehameha II that ran aground in Hanalei Bay.
A submarine that was disabled in a collision with Kansas Getty, and sunk as a target off Pearl Harbor.

A Japanese fishery high school training ship sank about 9 nautical miles (17 km) off the south coast of Oahu, after a collision with United States Navy submarine USS Greeneville. Nine of its crewmembers were killed, including four high school students.
A Japanese midget submarine depth-charged at Pearl Harbor.
An I-400-class submarine that was sunk as a target off Kalaeloa.
Russian-American Company ship Kad’yak (also spelled Kad’iak and Kodiak; formerly Myrtle), wrecked at Honolulu Harbor, Oahu.
A tank landing ship sunk following the West Loch Disaster in Pearl Harbor.
A fleet oiler run aground on Maro Reef.
An S-class submarine that sunk off Oahu.
A sloop-of-war that ran aground off Kure Atoll.
A Balao-class submarine sunk in a collision with USS Silverstein.
A Gato-class submarine that was scuttled after being used as an anti-submarine warfare target.
A former battleship converted to a training and target ship lost in the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor.
Sunk by Atlantis Submarines Hawaii as an artificial reef.
Sunk by Atlantis Submarines Hawaii as an artificial reef.
Sank in the Ohio River near New Albany.
A steamboat that sank in the Missouri River. The wreck now lies under a field in Kansas City.
An Admirable-class minesweeper that sank in Ohio River at Maysville.
A Confederate ironclad ram that was destroyed by her crew on 5 August 1862, near Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
A schooner sunk by British forces near New Orleans.
A Spanish brig carrying silver currency, sank 50 miles (80 km) south of New Orleans, discovered by a fishing trawler in 1993.
A gunboat that was scuttled to prevent capture off Alexandria.

A riverboat that ran aground near Shreveport on the Red River while carrying a large number of Confederate soldiers.  Not believed to be in danger, the ship was not evacuated.  The ship sank at night taking approx. 200 lives.   The wreck was rediscovered in 1994.
A merchant ship that ran aground after taking damage during a hurricane. The wreck was rediscovered in 1979.
A gunboat that took heavy damage in the Battle of Forts Jackson and St. Philip and was scuttled to prevent capture.
A steamboat that was sunk by Confederate forces off Port Hudson.
An ironclad that burned, exploded, and sunk near Fort St. Philip on the Mississippi River.
An ironclad warship that was run aground by USS Mississippi in the Battle of Forts Jackson and St. Philip.
A gunboat that took heavy damage in a battle with USS Iroquois, and was scuttled off Algiers.
A barge that sank in the Mississippi River during Hurricane Betsy.  The barge was raised on 12 November 1965.
Sunk in a hurricane off the coast while carrying $40,000 in gold and silver. 17 people out of 53 passengers/crew perished.
A passenger freighter torpedoed by U-166.
A steamship lost in the 1893 Cheniere Caminada hurricane.
A gunboat that was scuttled to prevent capture off Alexandria.
A German U-boat sunk by a depth charge from a US Navy patrol boat.
A steamship that sank in the Battle of Forts Jackson and St. Philip.
A coastal buoy tender sunk in the Mississippi River near White Castle following a collision.
A 4-masted schooner, struck Islesboro Ledge (off Islesboro, Penobscot Bay) in fog.
A fishing vessel, sunk by pirates two miles off the coast of Owls Head.
A barque that ran aground at Portland Head Light.
An Eagle-class patrol boat that was sunk by U-853 off Cape Elizabeth.
A Canadian screw steamer - formerly of the Confederate States Navy.
A British galley which struck rocks and sank near Boon Island.
A 241-foot five masted schooner built in Bath in 1901. It was intentionally sunk in Robinhood Cove in Georgetown. Known locally as Mary Barrett's Bones.
An S-class submarine that was sunk as a target.
World War I and World War II-era patrol boat torpedoed and sunk by German submarine U-583 off the coast of Cape Elizabeth.
A Balao-class submarine that was scuttled as an artificial reef off Ocean City, Maryland.

Built in New Jersey in 1891, and initially named the Edgar F. Luckenbach. The Cherokee spent a year in the service of the U.S. Navy. In February 1918, she foundered off Fenwick Island lightship during a gale while en route to Washington, D.C.

Maryland state steamer, 1884–1945, serving in State Oyster Police Force during Oyster Wars and as State Fishery Force "flagship" and briefly commissioned in U.S. Navy during WW I then the state until 1945 that sunk in Baltimore harbor.
Includes as many as 152 World War I-era merchant ships abandoned after the salvage company went bankrupt.
A Type VII-C/41 U-boat that was wrecked off Piney Point.

A sidewheel steamer built by Thomas Arnold of Gallagher & Company at Marine City, Michigan in 1866. She was operated by the Goodrich Line after being purchased from Gardner, Ward & Gallagher in April 1868. The Alpena sank in Lake Michigan in the "Big Blow" storm on October 15, 1880, with the loss of all 80 on board
A pleasure cruiser that was sunk by ice off Detroit.

The lake freighter sank during a storm on Lake Superior. The ship went down in 460 feet (140 m) of water about 7 nautical miles (13 km) N of Deer Park in Luce County. All but one of the 23 members of the crew perished

She was carrying a load of hardwood worth of $4,200 from Boyne City to Chicago. After leaving Boyne City the vessel was sailing in heavy weather, and the hull began to leak more than usual. In order to save the vessel captain Sam Christopher elected to drive the vessel ashore on South Manitou Island, where she landed just 200 yards (180 m) east of the lifesaving station
A dredge that sank in Torch Lake.
Retired Mississippi River steamboat that eventually sank, still in a drydock cradle.
A decommissioned U.S. Navy steam sloop that was scrapped and burned to the waterline outside Duluth Harbor. Her hull is the only surviving remnant of a vessel built by Donald McKay.
The steamship sank off the coast of Silver Bay in Lake Superior in a late spring snowstorm.

The schooner-barge was under the tow of the steamer William Edenborn when she was caught in a fierce storm with winds around 70 to 80 miles per hour, blowing snow onto the deck and kicking up huge swells. The tow line was cut loose and she crashed into a cliff called Gold Rock, near Beaver Bay, and sank. One life was lost.
Scow schooner of an atypical design which capsized while carrying a load of sandstone blocks.  One life was lost.
The first iron hulled lake freighter that sank after she sprang a leak.
Wooden bulk freighter that foundered when its stern pipe burst.  Whole crew was able to offload to the barge they were towing.

Whaleback freighter that sank outside the entrance to the Duluth harbor after colliding with another ship, prompting operational reforms.  Her hatches were not yet closed because the weather was clear and calm.
A City-class ironclad warship that was sunk by a mine near Yazoo City.
A river gunboat that struck a naval mine in the Yazoo River. The wreck was raised in 1964 and is currently on display at Vicksburg National Military Park.
A side-wheel steamer foundered off the barrier islands.
A tugboat that collided with USS Choctaw in the Yazoo River.
A steamboat that was burned in the Yazoo River.
A steamship that was scuttled as a blockship near Greenwood.
A steamboat that sunk near St. Charles on the Missouri River.

A decommissioned minesweeper, anchored at St. Louis as a floating museum from 1968 until the Great Flood of 1993. During the flood, the Inaugural was ripped from its moorings and carried a mile downstream, where it came to rest on its side, partially submerged, and where it remains to this day.
A steamboat that sunk off Cape Girardeau.
Large paddle wheeler, beached after collision with bridge near Bridgeton.
A steamboat built in 1872 that sank at the mouth of the Missouri River. Several lives lost.
A steamboat that sank at Napoleon.
A steamship that exploded near Lexington.
A steamboat that burned near Fort Peck on the Missouri River.
A steamboat built in 1859, that burned near the mouth of the Poplar River in the Missouri River.
A steamboat that wrecked on the Yellowstone River.
A steamboat that sank in the North Fork of the Flathead River.
A steamboat that sunk near the Red Cloud Bend of the Missouri River.
A steamboat that was deliberately sunk near Fort Peck on the Missouri River. Part of the hull was pulled up in 1935 during the construction of the Fort Peck Dam.
A steamboat that sank in the Yellowstone River.
A steamboat that sunk in the Desoto Bend of the Missouri River.
A steamboat that sank in the Missouri River near Bellevue.
A steamship that operated in Lake Tahoe at the turn of the 20th century.  Scuttled in 1940, rediscovered in 2002, and added to the National Register of Historic Places in 2004.
An O-class submarine that sank off Portsmouth.
Struck shore at Deal Beach.
An Andromeda-class attack cargo ship sunk as an artificial reef in Shark River.
Dutch Cargo Steamer of 5,163 tons built in 1930. When en route from New York for Table Bay and Durban she was torpedoed by U-136 and sunk. 6 crew lost from a total crew of 43
Sank in a storm.
Sank in a collision.
Foundered in a storm.
Sank in a collision.
A passenger liner sunk by U-151 off Atlantic City.
Struck a naval mine.
Sank in a collision.
Burned then sank under tow.
Sank in a collision.
Torpedoed.
Sunk by a U-boat.

Ran aground near Belmar.

A revenue cutter that sank in a collision with SS Vennacher off Sandy Hook.
Sank in a collision with the USS Greer off Cape May.
Caught fire off Long Beach Island.
Sank in a collision.
Torpedoed.
Sank in a collision.
Ran aground on Deal Beach.
Ran aground.

Torpedoed by U-578
Struck wreck of Adonis.
Struck a naval mine.
Ran aground on the beach of Ocean City.
A gunboat that was accidentally rammed by Camas Meadows off Cape May.

A patrol boat that collided with SS Frisa off Fire Island.
Torpedoed.
A German submarine thought to have been sunk near Gibraltar until its wreck was discovered off the coast of New Jersey in 1991.
Capsized under tow.
Sank in a collision.
A sidewheeler that collided with an oil barge on the North River and sunk off Jersey City.
Ran aground.
A sloop that ran aground at Little Egg Harbor.
A schooner that struck a reef near Rock Island Light.
A Gleaves-class destroyer that ran aground near Montauk, and although recovered, was deemed not worth repairing, and subsequently scuttled.
A Canadian schooner, recently revealed by superstorm Sandy on Fire Island (south of Long Island) lost in fog while transporting coal.
A steamboat that was wrecked in Lake George.
An armored cruiser sunk by a torpedo or mine near Fire Island.
A passenger steamboat ran aground by pilot under influence of morphine near Westport on Lake Champlain.
A schooner, went missing and suspected to have rammed the SS Oregon off Long Island.
British ship that ran aground at Montauk during the American Revolution.
A motor launch that was wrecked in Lake George.
A steamboat that caught fire and sank near North Brother Island, with over 1,000 deaths.
An oil tanker that ran aground at Fire Island.
A tugboat that sunk on the approach to Huntington Bay.

The barge moved out of dock at the South Street Seaport in New York City with 7,700 silver and lead ingots, bound for American Smelting and Refining Company in Perth Amboy, New Jersey. The silver and the smelters belonged to the Guggenheim family. The barge sank, and was never recovered.
A prototype submarine built by John Philip Holland and stolen by the Fenian Brotherhood, who accidentally sunk it off Whitestone.
A frigate that sank near Long Island Sound.
A cutter wrecked off Gardiners Point Island.
A ship that was wrecked in a snowstorm at Hampton Bays.
A steel freighter that struck Scow Island shoal.
A radeau that was intentionally sunk in Lake George during the French and Indian Wars.
A paddlewheel steamship which caught fire north of Long Island.
A Coventry-class frigate wrecked in Jamaica Bay.
The result of a gasoline explosion that wrecked the Penobscot, as well. Closest shipwreck to the mouth of the Buffalo River

A passenger paddle steamer of the Stonington Line that burned and sank on June 11, 1880, after a collision with her sister ship SS Stonington in heavy fog at 23:30 in Long Island Sound. Approximately 50 passengers, but only one crewman, died.

A British-built (by Cammell Laird & Company at Birkenhead, England in 1923) canaller, a steamship used to carry grain, coal and other products sunk after being hit by SS Dalwarnic off Somerset, New York. The ship was en route to Montreal from Buffalo, New York. All crew were saved and taken aboard Dalwarnic. Ship was named after one other co-owners of the ship.
A ship of the line that burned in Greenport Harbor.
A passenger liner that was sunk off Long Island following a collision with a schooner believed to be the Charles R. Morse.

The Belgian Red Star Line owned ocean liner ran aground at Long Island. All 125 passengers were taken ashore. There were attempts made to salvage ship, but it broke in two on 16 April and was declared a total loss.
A bulk carrier that struck a buoy, then ran aground on Pullman Shoal near the United States Coast Guard Station at Wellesley Island.
A Sailfish-class submarine that was sunk as a target near Hudson Canyon.
The first steamship to cross the Atlantic, before running aground off Long Island.
Tug boat that sank off of Fire Island, NY with loss of one of her four crew members.
A Balao-class submarine that was sunk as a target off Long Island.
A destroyer; exploded and sunk at Ambrose Light.
A patrol vessel that was wrecked off Watch Island.
A barque that came ashore carrying nuts from the Canary Islands and immigrants.
The wrecks of seven British and colonial bateaux that were scuttled in Lake George in 1758.
A schooner that ran aground at the entrance to the Ambrose Channel.
A steamboat that sank near Fort Buford on the Missouri River.
A steamboat built in 1878, that sank in the Missouri River near Bismarck.
The gunboat caught fire and was destroyed in the Ohio River at Cincinnati
A sidewheel steamer that sank after two of her boilers exploded.
Sank in the Ohio River during a flood.
A riverboat that exploded off Cincinnati.
A towboat that sank in the Ohio River.
She was on a voyage from Boston, Massachusetts, to Philadelphia when she struck a submerged log at the entrance to the back channel of League Island Navy Yard and was wrecked. All hands were saved.
Sank off of Fairview, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank off of Erie, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank off of North East, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank off of Erie, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank off of Harborcreek, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
A Sternwheel steamboat built in 1926.  It Sank in the Ohio River off of Neville Island.
Sank off of North East, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank near the U.S.-Canadian border in Lake Erie.
Sank off of Erie, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
Sank off of North East, Pennsylvania in Lake Erie.
A transoceanic steamer belonging to the Compañía Transatlántica Española.
A steel collier sunk by U-853 after World War II hostilities had ceased.
A frigate that was burnt in Narragansett Bay to prevent capture by the French, along with HMS Lark.
A patrol vessel that caught fire in Narragansett Bay.
A G-class submarine that was sunk as a target in Narragansett Bay.
British customs ship burned and sunk by American patriots in the lead-up to the American Revolution.
A Richmond-class frigate that was burnt in Narragansett Bay to prevent capture by the French, along with HMS Cerberus.
A steamboat and tug that foundered off Block Island.
A British ship that was burned by American colonists off Goat Island.
A Balao-class submarine that was sunk as a target off Newport.
An Edsall-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a target off Newport.
Sunk off Block Island by US Navy blimps' rockets.
British Royal Navy troop transport vessel previously commanded by James Cook on his first voyage of discovery. Scuttled as part of a blockade in Newport Harbor in 1778.
V-boat scuttled off Block Island as a sonar target in 1945.
L-class submarine sunk in a navy torpedo test off Newport, 3 miles south of Brenton Reef Light.
Frigate burned at Charleston; reported as discovered by NUMA in 1981.
A barque that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
Located near Myrtle Beach.
A barque that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
An ironclad warship that was scuttled at Charleston to prevent capture.
Located near Myrtle Beach.
Located near Myrtle Beach.
A submarine tender that was sunk as a target off Charleston.

Iron hulled Confederate cruiser destroyed off Isle of Palms with cargo of munitions, medicines and merchandise then valued at over $1,000,000, while attempting to run past the federal blockade fleet into Charleston.

A side wheel steamer used for federal transport, carrying a marine battalion of 600 under Major John G Reynolds. It sank off Georgetown after a gale and a hit from a rescue vessel. It foundered for 3 days. Seven men lost.
Located near Myrtle Beach.
Sunk by CSS Hunley, becoming the first warship in history to be sunk by a submarine.
Sank three times in its eight-month career, sinking for the final time shortly after its attack on USS Housatonic. Placed on National Register of Historic Places in 1978.
An experimental ironclad steamer, sunk in the First Battle of Charleston Harbor.
A barque that ran aground on the banks of the Combahee River.
Iron-hulled sidewheel steamer of 680 tons, stranded on the wreck of CSS Georgiana while attempting to run the federal blockade into Charleston.
A sailing ship that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
A whaler that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.

Iron-hulled propeller steamer, ran on wreck of CSS Georgiana and stranded a half mile inshore while attempting outbound run through the federal blockade of Charleston with a cargo of cotton. The vessel was owned by George Trenholm (aka the "real Rhett Butler").
An American steamer that ran aground on the shoals at Cape Romain. The wreck was rediscovered in 2013.
Struck a naval mine at Charleston.
A ship of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
Located near Myrtle Beach.
A whaler that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
Blockade runner at Charleston.
A whaler that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
A ship that was part of the Stone Fleet scuttled at Charleston Harbor.
