A Tolland-class attack cargo ship that was sunk as an artificial reef off Myrtle Beach.
American Civil War monitor at Charleston.
A cargo ship that was wrecked in a storm off Hilton Head Island.
A steamboat that sank in the Kate Sweeney Bend of the Missouri River near Vermillion.
A steamboat that sank in the Missouri River near Yankton.
A paddlewheel steamer that sank in the Tennessee River near Chattanooga.
A cottonclad warship that was rammed by USS Queen of the West and USS Monarch in the Battle of Memphis.
A Mississippi River steamboat that exploded near Johnsonville.
A steamboat that sank near Memphis.
A steamboat that sank near Memphis.
A Mississippi River paddlewheeler that exploded four miles (6 km) south of Memphis, killing an estimated 1,600 passengers.
A steam yacht sunk in the Viosca Knoll area.
A barque-longue of French explorer La Salle's expedition, which ran aground in Matagorda Bay.
The Mallory Line (New York) Steamer sunk after a fire aboard off Galveston. 56 lives were lost.
A patrol vessel that was wrecked at the mouth of the Brazos River.
Accidental detonation of 2,300 tons of ammonium nitrate aboard this French-registered vessel killed 581 people in the Texas City disaster.
A fuel tanker torpedoed by U-boat U-506.
Two-masted schooner sunk near Pass Cavallo.
A US Navy gunboat sunk by CSS Alabama off Galveston during the American Civil War.
A United Fruit Company freighter torpedoed by German submarine U-506.
A steamship that ran aground at Aransas Pass.

An oil tanker that exploded near Galveston.
A Spanish cargo ship that was wrecked in a storm on the Padre Island sandbars. The wreck was discovered in 1970.
A concrete oil tanker scuttled off Pelican Island after running aground off Tampico, Mexico.
An oil tanker sunk by a torpedo.
A standard canal boat that broke loose from tug at Proctor Shoal, Lake Champlain.
A sailing canal boat that hit breakwater near Burlington on Lake Champlain.
A sailing canal boat sunk in a gale near Burlington.
A steamer that caught fire near Colchester Shoal.
The only known example of a horse-powered ferry on Lake Champlain, found in Burlington Bay.
A schooner that foundered in a gale off Diamond Island.
Swamped.
A research vessel that was sunk as a target in Chesapeake Bay.
Sunk off Cape Charles.
A Fletcher-class destroyer that was sunk as a target in Chesapeake Bay.
A Benson-class destroyer that was sunk as a target.
A Barnegat-class seaplane tender that was sunk as a target.
A frigate that was rammed by CSS Virginia at Newport News.
Collided with MV Santa Cruz II  off Smith Point. Raised and re-sunk as an artificial reef off the Virginia Capes.
A steamship that was wrecked in a gale off Assateague Island.
A gunboat that was wrecked in the Battle of Trent's Reach.
Sank in a collision.
A cruiser that collided with USAT Alliance at Newport News.
Torpedoed.
An ironclad warship that was scuttled in the James River to prevent capture.
A Gato-class submarine that was sunk as a target off Cape Henry.
Swamped.
A Gearing-class destroyer that was sunk as a target.
Swamped.
A steamship that ran aground off Cape Henry.
A steamship that was sunk as a blockship near Drewry's Bluff.
Collided with SS Montana.
An Allen M. Sumner-class destroyer that was sunk as a target.
Spanish ship lost in a storm; still owned by Spain according to a ruling of the Fourth Circuit (Virginia v. Spain).
An ironclad warship that was sunk as a target in Rappahannock River.
Torpedoed.
Sank in a tropical cyclone; Spain claimed ownership to the wreck, but the Fourth Circuit (Virginia v. Spain) ruled that Spain had expressly abandoned it in 1763.
Sank in a collision.
A Balao-class submarine that was sunk as a target off Norfolk.

A 605-foot bulk carrier that sank 30 miles east of Chincoteague. An investigation by the United States Coast Guard found that the ship had been in an un-seaworthy condition, and that many of its inspection reports had been faked.
Collided with SS Admiral Farragut.
A repair ship that was scuttled as an artificial reef off Wachapreague.
An Edsall-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a target.
Torpedoed.

An Admirable-class minesweeper that was sunk as a target off the Virginia Capes.
A cruise ship that sank off the coast of Virginia.
A steamship that sank in a collision near Smith Island.
A patrol vessel that caught fire in the Hampton Roads.
A pre-dreadnought battleship that was sunk as a target in Tangier Sound.
Torpedoed by U-754 in Chesapeake Bay.
A Cannon-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a target.
A Casco-class cutter that was sunk as an artificial reef.
A steamship that sank in a storm off Norfolk.
An ironclad warship that was scuttled off Craney Island to prevent capture.
An incomplete battleship; construction work ceased upon the signing of the Washington Naval Treaty in February 1922. The ship was ultimately sunk as a target.
A Gearing-class destroyer that was sunk as a target.
Collision in the Chesapeake Bay.
A German barque that shipwrecked on the eastern reef during a gale.
A British tea clipper that struck a reef and sank.

A cargo liner that collided with SS Princess Victoria near Point No Point.
A steamboat that was wrecked in a snowstorm at the entrance to Clallam Bay.
A Balao-class submarine that sunk under tow off Cape Flattery.
A steamship that ran aground in a storm in Grays Harbor.
A steamboat that collided with the Jeanie off Duwamish Head.
A steamboat that struck a rock off Marrowstone Island.
A launch that sank for unknown reasons in Lake Washington, off Kirkland. The wreck was discovered in 2006.
A General John Pope-class troop transport that ran aground under tow in a storm.
An American steamboat accidentally run aground on sand and subsequently destroyed by waves near the mouth of the Columbia River.

A 50-foot yacht capsized and sank when hit by a 35-foot wave at Grays Harbor Bar.  Diane Sheldon Guertin, 37; Glenn Genoway, 60, and Mella Genoway, 60, were killed.  Frank Guertin, 45, skipper and husband of Diane, was the only survivor.
A tugboat that sank after an internal explosion off Purdy Spit.

A Hudson's Bay Company British supply ship. Remains are in 40 feet (12 m) of water off Cape Disappointment near Astoria. Site is listed in the National Register of Historic Places by the National Park Service.
A Russian steamship that ran aground south of Cape Flattery during a violent storm.
A steamship that burned on the Lewis River near La Center.
A steamship that caught fire at Seattle.
A steamboat that ran aground off Marrowstone Point Light.

Russian-American Company schooner, sailed south from Sitka to locate a suitable site for a permanent post in Oregon Country. Wrecked on the Olympic Peninsula near Rialto Beach. The crew was marooned for about 18 months, clashing with the Hoh then enslaved by the Makah. They were rescued in May 1810 at Neah Bay by the American merchant vessel Lydia.
The paddle steamer sank after being in collision with SS Orpheus off Cape Flattery. At least 318 lives lost.
A steamboat that foundered off Lopez Island.
A YMS-1-class minesweeper that sank in Lake Washington.
A steamboat that was wrecked at Port Orchard Narrows.

The wooden steamship went aground in smoke and fog on the Wisconsin coast of Lake Michigan, near Milwaukee in 1905. Crews worked for two weeks in an effort to free the ship, but eventually it broke up, and was abandoned as a total constructive loss.
Steamer from the Goodrich line that caught fire and burned 10 nautical miles (19 km) NE of Port Washington in Lake Michigan.  Captain Delos H. Smith rescued 74 of 75 from the burning ship.
The schooner was in collision with schooner Kate Gillett off Algoma in Lake Michigan. There was no loss of life
Ran aground and sunk in Lake Michigan.
A bulk carrier that sank in Lake Michigan off the coast of North Bay, Door County, Wisconsin
A schooner that was run aground by a gale off the coast of Plum Island. There were no casualties.
A schooner that struck a shoal near the Strawberry Islands

She was a schooner that encountered a squall and sank in Lake Michigan off the coast of Sheboygan, Wisconsin. In 2005, the shipwreck site was added to the National Register of Historic Places. There were no casualties.

She was at anchor in the Sturgeon Bay Ship Canal. At about 1:00 a.m., the captain saw flames from the wheelhouse and sounded the alarm. The crew was able to escape, but in the ensuing chaos the ship was carried in the current toward the canal office and government warehouse. Eventually, efforts from those on land were successful in towing the vessel away from land, where it then burned to the waterline and sank.
Largest wooden steamship on the Great Lakes, sunk in a storm with no survivors. Its wreck was located in June 2010.
Burned in a gale.

The commercial schooner sank with all hands due to bad weather in Lake Superior, off the coast of Long Island in Chequamegon Bay. The site of the wreck was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1991.
While about 5 nautical miles (9.3 km) East of Michigan Island and carrying a cargo of iron ore, she sprang a leak and began to sink. The crew escaped in lifeboats.
Sunk in Lake Michigan from storm damage.
She sank in a storm by Michigan Island while hauling iron ore out of Ashland.
The wooden schooner caught fire and sank in Lake Superior off the coast of Stockton Island, in Chequamegon Bay.

Wooden steamship that caught fire from over-stoked boilers and burned to the waterline off the coast of Sheboygan, WI, killing at least 190 but perhaps more than 250 of the nearly 300 people on board.  40 people survived in lifeboats and three were rescued from the water.
The wooden schooner sank in a storm on Lake Superior near the Apostle Islands
A collision with the Marquette in a dense fog sank the Senator off Port Washington in Lake Michigan.
The steamboat sank in a storm on Lake Superior near Sand Island.
The scow schooner was pushed ashore by a gale during a storm off the coast of Sevastopol, Wisconsin.

The schooner was sailing from Muskegon, Michigan to Milwaukee carrying a cargo of lumber worth roughly $500 at the time. The ship was crewed by two men, Captain John Sather and First Mate Charles Nordbach. About 9 nautical miles (17 km) from Port Washington she was caught in a storm. The ship eventually capsized, and Mate Morbach died.
A steamboat that was abandoned in Yellowstone Lake.
Torpedoed by U-79 in Rathlin Sound.
Foundered and sank off Lacada Point, County Antrim.
Sank in collision off Belfast Lough.
Foundered and sunk off Kilroot.
Foundered in heavy seas off the Copeland Islands.
A passenger liner that ran aground on Hunter Rock.
A merchant ship torpedoed and sunk by SM U-19 off Black Head near Larne, County Antrim.
A Kilkeel fishing boat that sank after a gas explosion.
Ran aground and was wrecked in the River Clyde.
Sank off Vatersay, Outer Hebrides in a gale, with the loss of 350 lives.
An ocean liner that was torpedoed by UB-67 off the coast of Ireland.
A cargo ship that was sunk by U-2336 south of the Isle of May.
An Aberdeen trawler that wrecked on the Ve Skerries, Shetland, killing the ~9 crew.
Dutch cargo ship, sunk by two Heinkel 111 bombers in Ardmucknish Bay off Oban.
A Brummer-class cruiser that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
Sank 35 miles (56 km) off Cape Wrath due to bad weather.
A cargo ship that foundered 12 nautical miles (22 km) east of Muckle Skerry.
A Spanish-owned, UK-registered longliner that wrecked on the Ve Skerries, Shetland.
A Cöln-class cruiser that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
British container ship ran aground at Killantringan lighthouse, Wigtownshire.
A frigate wrecked in the Sound of Mull.
Aircraft carrier sunk by a major internal explosion. Lies in the Clyde estuary.
Intercepted and sunk by German submarine SM U-17, 35 miles (56 km) off Montrose.
A Cöln-class cruiser that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
An Aberdeen trawler that wrecked on the Ve Skerries, Shetland.
A cargo ship torpedoed by U-122 off Barra Head.
A tug that sank in foggy conditions in the River Clyde at Clydebank.
An Acorn-class destroyer wrecked at Start Point.
A ship of the Spanish Armada that was wrecked on Fair Isle.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-32 off Lewis, Outer Hebrides.
Formerly the German U-boat U-570. Captured and taken into Royal Navy service in 1942, she ran aground and was wrecked on Islay in 1944.
British armoured cruiser that struck a mine off Orkney.
A Swedish steamboat that struck rocks in the Sound of Mull.
An I-class destroyer that collided with HMS Glasgow off Duncansby Head.
A steamship that was torpedoed by U-96 south of Burrow Head.
An admiralty yacht sank in The Minch outside Stornoway harbour with the loss of 205 men returning from World War I.
Struck a mine on 5 July 1942 in the Denmark Strait. The forepart was salved but broke tow on 1 September 1952 and was later wrecked at Torrisdale Bay, Sutherland on 5 September.
A Königsberg-class cruiser that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
A King Edward VII-class battleship that struck a mine laid by SMS Möwe off Cape Wrath.
A König-class battleship that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
A König-class battleship that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
A straggler from Convoy SC 121 that was hit by a torpedo from U-642 and sank west of the Hebrides. The master and 25 crewmembers were lost.
A König-class battleship that was among the 74 ships scuttled in Scapa Flow by Admiral Reuter.
A paddle steamer that sank off Wigtownshire.
British minelayer ran aground in the Kyle of Lochalsh, caught fire while being unloaded, destroyed by explosion.
An armed boarding steamer that was sunk by SMS Meteor northeast of Fair Isle.
A minesweeper that sank following a collision with HMS Imperieuse in Scapa Flow, near Longhope.
Sunk in the Sound of Mull in a storm.
A Revenge-class battleship torpedoed in Scapa Flow by U-47, with 833 deaths.
A ship of the Spanish Armada that was blown up at Tobermory.
An S-class submarine scuttled off the Isle of Arran.
A cargo ship that sank off the Bo Vich Chuan Rock in the Outer Hebrides.
A cruise ship that ran aground on the island of Mousa.
A warship that sunk in a storm while anchored off Duart Castle.
A steamship that ran aground on a reef in the Sound of Mull.
An ocean liner that was torpedoed by UB-77 off Islay, Inner Hebrides.
A Type VIIA U-boat that was sunk by HMS Gleaner in the Firth of Clyde.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was sunk by a British Short Sunderland flying boat of No. 201 Squadron RAF 16 nautical miles (30 km) west of Yesnaby, Orkney Islands.
German U-Boat sunk by depth charges from the South African frigate HMSAS Natal. She was discovered in the Firth of Forth in 2007.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk in the Sea of the Hebrides by HMS Fitzroy, HMS Redmill and HMS Byron.

A training ship of the Royal Technical College, Glasgow, ran aground and wrecked at Colonsay of her first voyage as a training ship.
A cargo steamship that ran aground at St. David's Head.

A 6,100 ton steamer, 436 ft (133 m) in length, with a cargo of 4,700 tons of government stores, allegedly including Harley Davidson motorbikes. Sunk by magnetic parachute mine in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire.
A Canadian barque that ran aground in a gale off Strumble Head.
A cargo ship that ran aground off The Skerries, Anglesey.
A training ship wrecked near Menai Bridge.
A 6,400 ton steamer, 400 ft (120 m) in length, with a cargo of 1,300 tons of tinplate. Sunk by magnetic parachute mine approx 1-nautical-mile (1.9 km) west of Dale in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire.
A protected wrecksite; a three-masted square rigger with a composite hull, forerunner of the Ocean liners, lost in Cardigan Bay.
A coastal trading vessel that struck a mine off Pembrokeshire.
A cable layer that was attacked by a Heinkel He 111 off Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire, and sank the following day off St Anne's Head. It is now a protected wreck.

Former Bibby Line liner, 7,000 tons, on passage to breakers, lost tow in a storm and ran aground on Cardigan Island; no lives lost, but rats destroyed puffin and Manx shearwater colonies; lies in 12m of water.
A steamship that sank in a storm off the Great Orme.

A 1,218 ton rigged sailing ship, 225 ft (69 m) in length, with a cargo of 7,000 cases of whiskey, beer & general goods. Ran aground at Thorne Island in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire. Now at a depth of 25 feet (7.6 m), is very broken up, but the brick ballast is still visible.
A 52 metres (171 ft) coaster, sank off Skomer Island, Pembrokeshire, while carrying a cargo of calcium carbide from Uddevalla, Sweden to Barry.
A protected wrecksite; the first British Royal Yacht, hit rocks in fog off Anglesey.
A barque that caught fire and sank northeast of Llandudno.
A Collins Line transatlantic steamer that sank (possibly in the Irish Sea) from unknown causes. Wreck found in 1986.
A four masted windjammer that was wrecked on the Cefn Sidan sands.
A protected wrecksite near Rhyl.
A paddle steamer that ran aground and broke up at the eastern end of the Menai Strait in 1831.
A steam clipper driven onto rocks near Moelfre, Anglesey.
A steamship wrecked off Sker Point.
Sank after hitting a large wave following gale force 8 conditions 20 nautical miles (37 km) off the coast of Anglesey.

A tugboat that sank in the 1980s. The wreck is a popular shallow depth dive site.
A ship that was sacked and burned along with the Abu Mahir fort on Muharraq Island. The ship's cannons are now kept outside the Bahrain National Museum.
A supply ship that capsized about 10 nautical miles (19 km; 12 mi) off Doha.
A Ro-Pax vessel, later renamed Al Fahad, that was anchored after engine problems and abandoned 14.6 kilometres (9.1 mi) southwest of the old city center of Jeddah.

A Norwegian ferry, formerly Europafergen, reported to be laid up at Shoieba.

A cruise ship that ran between Nanjing and Chongqing. It capsized on the Yangtze River after being hit by a downburst in Jianli County, Jingzhou, Hubei, killing 442.

A protected cruiser that struck a mine off the Lüshunkou District.

A late Ming dynasty (1368–1644) merchant ship, the first ever found in the South China Seas.

A gunboat that collided with Akagi in heavy fog off Lüshunkou.
A Petropavlovsk-class battleship that was sunk by a mine in the Yellow Sea.
A ferry on the Guangzhou–Zhaoqing route. It capsized in thunderstorm at Shanshui, Guangdong, with at least 147 people confirmed dead.
Capsized in Yangtze River, Hejiang, Sichuan, with at least 131 people confirmed dead.
A Petropavlovsk-class battleship that was scuttled in the Yellow Sea to avoid capture.
An ancient Chinese merchant ship dating back to the reign of the Kangxi Emperor (1654–1722) of the Qing dynasty.
A Bathurst-class corvette that was sunk by Japanese aircraft off Betano Bay.
A W-class destroyer that ran aground at Betano Bay.
A steamship that sank in a typhoon, killing 125 people on board.
A ferry that sank near Lantau Island during the height of Typhoon Rose; of the 92 on board, only 4 people survived.

A wreck that was discovered in a coconut grove near Kadakkarappally, Kerala, that dates from around 1020–1160 AD.
A cargo ship that became stranded in the Karnaphuli River, Chittagong.
An Armide-class frigate that was wrecked in the Java Sea.
A Fubuki-class destroyer that struck a mine near Balikpapan.
A cargo ship that was bombed and sunk by the CIA while anchored at Ambon, Maluku, as part of a covert operation to drive foreign trade from Indonesian waters.

A schooner-rigged diesel yacht that was confiscated from its German owners and renamed USS Hermes. After WWI, it was sold to MGM, who renamed it MV Lanakai and used it in the film The Hurricane, starring Jon Hall and Dorothy Lamour. During WWII, the ship operated as a covert intelligence-gathering vessel around the Philippines and Vietnam. It was sunk by a typhoon in 1947.
A Mahan-class destroyer that was sunk between Leyte and Ponson Island.

A lumber transport, known locally as El Capitan, that was commissioned for supply duties during World War II. A Liberty ship, the vessel received a Battle Star for her duties and survived being torpedoed by a Japanese submarine at Guadalcanal. She was sunk by typhoon in Subic Bay, whilst undergoing re-fit/repair after the war.
An Asashio-class destroyer that was sunk in the Battle of Surigao Strait.
A Chinese merchant vessel that was sunk off the coast of Marinduque.

A Japanese prisoner-of-war (POW) transport ship "hell ship" that was sunk by aircraft from USS Hornet in Subic Bay. Oryuko Maru was "unmarked" as a POW transport. 200 Allied POWs died during the sinking, with a further 100 murdered or dying of suffocation or dehydration prior to the attack. Of a total of 1,620 POWs initially loaded on Oryuko Maru, only 403 survived Japanese captivity during the war.
A PC-461-class submarine chaser that was sunk by a Shin'yō suicide boat off Luzon.
A merchant ship that was sunk by Japanese bombing at Manila.
A motor vessel that capsized in Manila Bay.
A passenger ferry that sank in San Fernando, Romblon, resulting in over 500 deaths.
An Independence-class aircraft carrier that was lost at the Battle of Leyte Gulf.

A schooner, chartered to the East India Company, that struck a reef 46 miles (74 km) from Palawan, en route to Balambangan Island. All but three crewmen survived the sinking and were picked up by the British ship Union. The three sailors who drowned were apparently drunk and refused to take to the lifeboats.
A merchant vessel in wartime auxiliary naval service, sunk by US forces in Subic Bay during World War II. The wreck is located in the Grande Island channel, at a depth of 54 metres (177 ft).
A John C. Butler-class destroyer escort that sank during the Battle off Samar.
A Spanish gunboat that was scuttled between Grande Island and Chiquita Islands, near the mouth of Subic Bay, during the Spanish–American War, in the hope of blocking the passage to the US Navy.
A Natsushima-class minelayer that was sunk by US aircraft off Magsaysay.
A Mutsuki-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft in Manila Bay.

A 3,712-ton freighter serving in wartime auxiliary naval service. It was initially requisitioned in September 1940, as an auxiliary anti-submarine net-layer and patrol boat, before being re-enrolled as an auxiliary transport in August 1942. She was converted to an emergency tanker in January 1943, and sunk by US naval aircraft in Subic Bay during World War II.
A destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft at Ormoc Bay.
A Kagerō-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft 80 miles (130 km) north of Iloilo.
A Sonoma-class fleet tug that was sunk by Japanese aircraft off Dulag, Leyte.
A Casablanca-class escort carrier of the United States Navy during World War II, and the first major warship sunk by a kamikaze attack during the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
A Kagerō-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS Harder in Sibutu Passage.
A replenishment oiler that was torpedoed by US submarines off Ilocos Norte.
A Mutsuki-class destroyer that was sunk by US torpedo boats 50 miles (80 km) northeast of Cebu.
A Hatsuharu-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft in the Battle of Leyte Gulf.
An Akizuki-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft in Ormoc Bay.
A minelayer that was sunk by US aircraft off Palawan.
An Asashio-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS McDermut in the Battle of Surigao Strait.
A Fusō-class battleship that was sunk in the Battle of Surigao Strait.
A Kamikaze-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS Picuda northeast of Cape Bojeador Lighthouse.
A Mutsuki-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft 65 miles (105 km) northeast of Cebu.
A November-class submarine that was scuttled off the northeastern coast of Novaya Zemlya.
A Niitaka-class protected cruiser that capsized in a typhoon off the Ust-Bolsheretsky District.
An icebreaker that was sunk by the German cruiser Admiral Scheer northwest of Russky Island.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by T-116 east of the Mona Islands.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by S-101 off Cape Flissingsky.
A Gato-class submarine that was sunk by Japanese aircraft in La Perouse (Soya) Strait, between Hokkaidō and Sakhalin, during World War II.

A French liner belonging to the Messageries Maritimes fleet that collided with Onda (British India Steam Navigation Company) due to thick fog, and sank 30 nautical miles (56 km; 35 mi) off Singapore. 101 died, while many of the 61 who survived suffered grave wounds when attacked by sharks, prior to being saved by the crew of Onda. Refusing to be saved, the Captain of the French liner went down with his ship.
A Yosu-Busan route ferry that capsized off Busan. At least 249 people were confirmed dead; only seven survived.
A Mokpo-Jin Island route ferry that capsized off Jeollanam-do. According to South Korean Coast Guard official confirmed report, at least 103 people were confirmed dead, only 48 persons survived.
A YMS-1-class minesweeper that hit a mine off North Gyeongsang Province.
A ferry that ran between Busan and Jeju-do, and capsized in Korea Strait, killing 323 people. Only 12 were rescued.
A Dutch trading ship with the VOC (Dutch East India Company). It was blown off course and capsized in stormy weather off Jeju-do, killing 48 people, with 16 survivors.
A Puan County to Ui Island route ferry, capsized off Jeollabuk-do. According to South Korean Coast Guard official confirmed report, 292 person lost to lives, only 70 person rescued.

A ferry with 476 souls on board – most of which were high school students – that capsized near Donggeochado after making a "sudden turn" that overbalanced the ship, which could not be righted. Only 172 survived. The captain and crew were later charged with criminal negligence, gross negligence and manslaughter after it was revealed the ship was heavily overbalanced, and that the captain and crew abandoned ship after ordering the passengers to remain seated even as water began filling the ship, resulting in unnecessary deaths.
A Yeonhwa Island to Mokpo route ferry, capsized off Jeollanam-do. According to South Korean Coast Guard official confirmed report, 140 person lost to lives, only a person rescued.
A steamship that ran aground near Trincomalee.
A tanker that was sunk off Batticaloa by Japanese aircraft.
An 18th century shipwreck on the Great Basses Reef, discovered by Arthur C. Clarke in 1961.
A corvette that was sunk by Japanese air attack.
A cargo ship that was forcibly boarded by LTTE Sea Tigers and run aground near Mullaitivu. The Sri Lanka Army re-captured the wreck in 2009.
An S-class destroyer that was sunk at Colombo during the Indian Ocean raid.
A V-class destroyer that was sunk by Japanese air attack.
An aircraft carrier that was sunk by Japanese air attack.
An Algerine-class minesweeper of the Royal Ceylon Navy that sank in a strong storm in the Gulf of Mannar.
A Kamikaze-class destroyer that was sunk by US aircraft at Kaohsiung.
A Minekaze-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS Pogy off Taitung County.
A car ferry that hit a reef off the Phi Phi Islands.
A cruise ship that had been abandoned for a year without any maintenance, sank and capsized in shallow waters near the port of Laem Chabang, Sri Racha.
A French ship that was sunk by Turkish coastal artillery about 1-mile (1.6 km) outside Avova Bay (Ağva Körfezi).
An ironclad warship that ran aground off Yalıköy, Istanbul.
A destroyer that collided with HMS Hope in the Dardanelles.
A pre-dreadnought battleship, launched in 1896 and sunk by Turkish coastal artillery in the Dardanelles Campaign.
A Magdeburg-class light cruiser that was sunk in the Battle of Imbros.
A Phoenician merchant vessel that was wrecked around 1200 BCE.
An iron-screw steamer ketch built in Hull in 1893. It was sold and renamed Carmen in 1902, and sold again in 1919. Its subsequent fate was unknown until the wreckage was discovered in the 1950s.
A Majestic-class battleship that was torpedoed by SM U-21 off Cape Helles.
A French submarine that was scuttled off Cape Nara, near Çanakkale.

A French naval patrol ship sunk by Turkish coastal artillery off Kemer inside Avova Bay (Ağva Körfezi). Approximately 150 shots were fired, of which 110 hit the target. The crew were rescued by Turkish soldiers.
An Abercrombie-class monitor that was sunk by Turkish ships off Imbros.
A Turkish ship that was sunk by an unidentified (probably French) submarine. Of the 200 aboard, only 32 survived.
A cargo ship which struck a reef while suffering engine trouble. The wreckage was discovered in 1994, close to the wreck of Duchess of York.
A Type IIB U-boat that was scuttled in the Black Sea.
A merchant ship dating to the late Bronze Age.
A Katori-class light cruiser that was sunk by US aircraft off Qui Nhon.
A Minekaze-class destroyer that was torpedoed by USS Pargo north of Nha Trang.
An Acheron-class destroyer that was torpedoed by U-27 and sank under tow off Vlorë, Albania.
A B-class destroyer that was sunk by German bombers off Koksijde.
An Apollo-class cruiser scuttled as a blockship in the mouth of Ostend harbour.
A German destroyer sunk by mines laid by HMS Plover.
A cargo ship that stuck a mine in the River Scheldt.
A G-class destroyer that was torpedoed by U-62 off Nieuwpoort.
A RORO ferry that capsized four minutes out from Zeebrugge, resulting in 193 deaths.
A tank landing ship that struck a mine off Ostend.
A Type U 5 U-boat that sank north of Zeebrugge.
A German submarine mined in the First Battle of the Atlantic.
A Type UB I U-boat that was scuttled off Zeebrugge.
A Type UB III U-boat that was scuttled off Zeebrugge.
A German minelaying submarine that struck a mine off Zeebrugge.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by a mine off Zeebrugge.
A German minelaying submarine sunk by a mine off Flanders.
An East Indiaman that ran aground off Zeebrugge.
A steamship that struck a mine off Burgas.
A cargo ship that struck a mine off Burgas.
An ocean liner that ran aground on Fuerteventura under tow, then split in half and broke into many pieces.
A cement barge that ran aground off Arona, Tenerife.
A cargo ship that was forced aground near Arricife, Lanzarote.
A Surveillante-class frigate that sank in a severe storm in the Strait of Bonifacio.
An Urakaze-class destroyer that was sunk by HMS Wheatland and HMS Avon Vale off Pag, during the action of 1 November 1944.
An Austrian steam liner sunk by an underwater mine near Rovinj.
An Italian Alessandro Poerio-class cruiser sunk by an underwater mine near Ližnjan.
A Giuseppe Garibaldi-class armored cruiser that was torpedoed by U-4 southeast of Dubrovnik.
A Gazelle-class light cruiser that ran aground on Silba and was sunk by British motor torpedo boats.
A Tegetthoff-class dreadnought battleship that was sunk off Molat island by Italian torpedo boat MAS-15.
A Type UB III U-boat that was scuttled at Rijeka.
A Tegetthoff-class dreadnought battleship that was sunk at anchor at Pula by an Italian human torpedo.
A gunboat that sank at Larnaca.
A cargo ship that ran aground off Paphos in heavy seas, during a voyage from Greece to Syria with a cargo of timber.
A Greek merchant ship dating to the 4th century BC that now sits on display in a museum at Kyrenia Castle.
A Swedish RO-RO ferry that sank 1-mile (1.6 km) off the port of Larnaca.
A German made pleasure craft intentionally sunk in 18 metres (59 ft) water off the coast of Limassol.
A Russian trawler intentionally sunk in 25 metres (82 ft) water off the coast of Limassol.
A Russian frigate that ran aground off the coast of Thyborøn.
A Duke of Edinburgh-class armored cruiser that sank at the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
A ship of the line that exploded and sank in the Great Northern War during the action of 4 October 1710.
A 74-gun third-rate ship of the line that stranded off Thorsminde in heavy storm, together with HMS St George.
A Minotaur-class armoured cruiser that suffered a magazine explosion during the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
A Pillau-class light cruiser that was scuttled following a collision with SMS Posen in the Battle of Jutland.
A Gazelle-class light cruiser that was torpedoed and shelled during the Battle of Jutland.
A Swedish tugboat that sank outside Frederikshavn. The vessel now rests at a depth of 23 metres (75 ft).
A Chinese bulk carrier that sank after a collision with the Cypriot container vessel Gdynia, without injury or loss of life.
An Indefatigable-class battlecruiser that suffered a magazine explosion during the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
An Invincible-class battlecruiser that was sunk in the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
A wreck discovered in Kolding Fjord, thought to date from around 1190.
A Derfflinger-class battlecruiser that was scuttled off Horns Reef after severe damage in the Battle of Jutland.
A Cruizer-class brig-sloop that ran aground off Skagen, Jutland.
A Deutschland-class predreadnought battleship that suffered a magazine explosion during the Battle of Jutland.
A battlecruiser that suffered a magazine explosion during the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
A 98-gun second-rate ship of the line that stranded off Thorsminde in heavy storm, together with HMS Defence.
A Type U 19 U-boat that ran aground and was scuttled by her crew on the following day.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was accidentally sunk by the German torpedo boat T17 off Skagen.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by a British aircraft east of Aarhus.
A Duke of Edinburgh-class armored cruiser that foundered under tow after severe damage in the Battle of Jutland. The site is a protected place.
A cruise ferry that sunk in international waters of the Baltic Sea, about 40 kilometres (22 nmi) south-southeast of Utö island, Finland, claiming 852 lives.
A wreck off Saaremaa island dating to the 16th century.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by a mine.
A British trawler that was sunk in Tórshavn Harbour.
A steamship that sank after a storm in the sound of Fugloyarfjørður.
Sank after hitting the nesse of Mjóvanes.
A 19th-century schooner that was discovered in 2003 off Föglö, along with a well-preserved cargo of champagne.
A ship of the Hanseatic League that was wrecked in a storm off Raseborg.
A Russian frigate sunk in the Battle of Svensksund.
A Dutch merchant ship that ran aground and sank.
A German luxury ocean liner that was sunk in Lübeck Bay.
A freighter that was stranded on Grosser Vogelsand off the mouth of the Elbe River.
A training ship that struck a mine northwest of Fehmarn.
A British freighter that was stranded on Grosser Vogelsand off the mouth of the Elbe River.
A Vorpostenboot that was sunk by British aircraft off Spiekeroog.
A Bussard-class cruiser that was being used as a mine hulk when a mine exploded on board, sinking Seeadler in the Jade Bight.
A Type IIB U-boat that was scuttled at Wilhelmshaven.
A Type IIC U-boat that was scuttled at Wilhelmshaven.
A Type IIC U-boat that was scuttled at Wilhelmshaven.
A Type IXB U-boat that was sunk by Canadian bombers at Kiel.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled near Schleimünde.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by British bombs at Kiel.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled at Neustadt after taking damage from British aircraft.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk, possibly by a mine, in the Elbe estuary.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled near Travemünde.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was scuttled near Nordenham.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled near Wilhelmshaven.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled off Warnemünde.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by American aircraft near Hamburg.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by American aircraft near Hamburg.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by British aircraft off Wilhelmshaven.
A Type IXC/40 U-boat that was sunk by American bombs at Bremen.
A Type VIIC U-boat that ran aground and was scuttled at Amrum.
A Type IXC/40 U-boat that was sunk by US aircraft at Kiel.
A naval armament carrier that exploded at Gun Wharf.
A cargo ship that ran aground at Europa Point in gale-force winds.
A cargo ship that collided with Torm Gertrud off Europa Point.
An English ship-of-the-line lost in a severe storm.
A wreck on Antikythera island that contained the Antikythera mechanism and dates from approximately 86 BC.
A Condottieri-class light cruiser that was sunk in the Battle of Cape Spada.
A White Star Liner sunk by flooding after striking a mine near the isle of Kea.
A small freight ship that was swept away by the sea from the port of Gythio and left stranded on a sandy beach.
The oldest known underwater shipwreck discovery, dating to c. 2200 BCE.
A Hunt-class destroyer that was attacked by German aircraft in the Battle of Leros and scuttled.
A protected cruiser that was sunk by the Italian submarine Delfino off Tinos.
A RO-RO passenger ferry that capsized after hitting a rock off the island of Paros.
A Town-class light cruiser that was sunk by German dive bombers in the Battle of Crete.
A G-class destroyer that was sunk by German dive bombers northwest of Crete.
An H-class destroyer that was sunk by German dive bombers off Crete.
A Hunt-class destroyer that struck a mine east of Kalymnos.
A Greek destroyer that was sunk by German bombers off Kardiotissa.
An I-class destroyer that was sunk by German aircraft at Leros.
A cruise ship that collided with an Italian freighter off Piraeus.
A K-class destroyer that was sunk by German dive bombers south of Gavdos.
A K-class destroyer that was sunk by German dive bombers south of Gavdos.
An M15-class monitor that was sunk in the Battle of Imbros.
An ocean liner that capsized in Elevsis Bay.
HMS Taurus sank the Greek sailing vessel Mimis with explosives, off Skiathos, Greece.
Cargo ship that ran aground off the port of Diakofti in Kithira Island where its stern can be seen jutting out of the water still.
A coastal trading ship run aground on the isle of Zakynthos, while allegedly smuggling cigarettes from Turkey.
A wheel steamboat lost off Kea Island.
A submarine sunk by a mine near the island of Kefalonia.
A Greek cruise ship that struck a reef off the harbor of Santorini island and sank the following day.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by HMS Porpoise off Methoni, while carrying 2,000 UK and Dominion POWs.
A troopship that was sunk by German aircraft south of Spetses during the Battle of Greece.
A French warship that sunk off Heraklion after an accidental explosion of the powder-keg.
A U-boat that sunk at Saronikos Gulf after hitting a Greek mine.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled near Salamis Island.
A Greek destroyer sunk by Luftwaffe bombers in the port of Leros island.
A weather ship that was scuttled at Cape Sussi, Shannon Island.
A liner that struck an iceberg and sank on her maiden voyage off the coast of Western Greenland
A weather ship that was scuttled in Hansa Bay.
A weather ship that was scuttled off Store Koldewey to prevent capture.
A Treasury-class cutter that was torpedoed by U-132 off Reykjavík, and sank the next day.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-300 off Gardskagi. Totals of 42 casualties and 21 survivors.
A Halcyon-class minesweeper that was sunk by a mine off the Westfjords.
A Type VIIC U-boat that sank in the Denmark Strait.
A British steamship that ran aground in fog on Kedge Rocks near Baltimore Island.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-46 northeast of Rathlin Island.
A British battleship that sank after striking a German mine near Lough Swilly.
A Norwegian motor vessel that ran aground on the Kish Bank during a snow storm.
A Cunard Line transatlantic passenger steamship famous for coming to the rescue of RMS Titanic in 1912. It was torpedoed and sunk by German U-boat U-55.

A 4,050-GRT Elders & Fyffes cargo liner and banana boat running the Avonmouth to Jamaica route. She struck a mine laid by UC-75 0.5 nautical miles (0.93 km) SE of Black Head lighthouse in Belfast Lough and sank, without loss of life.
A steamship that was torpedoed by German submarine U-20.
A barque that sank off Kedge Island, near Baltimore, County Cork
A passenger sailing vessel that sank off the coast of Kilkee, County Clare.
An ocean liner bombed by aircraft and then torpedoed and sunk by U-32.
A sailing ship that caught fire and was abandoned at sea.
A cargo ship that sunk in a storm off the coast of Kilkee, County Clare. 17 lost their lives.
A very broken-up steamer that sank after colliding with the cliffs in fog on the eastern side of Cape Clear Island, County Cork.
A tanker that ran aground off the Maidens.
A steamer that was torpedoed by U-64 26 kilometres (14 nmi) east of the Kish Light Vessel.
A ship of the Spanish Armada that was driven aground at Streedagh Strand, then in Cairbre, now County Sligo.
A ship of the Spanish Armada that was driven aground at Streedagh Strand, then in Cairbre, now County Sligo.
A ship of the Spanish Armada that was driven aground at Streedagh Strand, then in Cairbre, now County Sligo.
A Bridge-class ore-bulk-oil carrier that sank with its cargo of iron ore when sailing from Sept-Îles, Quebec to the River Clyde.
A Cunard Line ocean liner sunk near Fastnet Rock by German submarine U-50.
An armed merchantman that struck two mines off Lough Swilly.
A C-class destroyer that was wrecked off Blacksod Bay.
The Dublin to Holyhead mailboat, torpedoed and sunk 6 kilometres (3.2 nmi) east of the Kish Lighthouse by UB-123.
A hospital ship that was torpedoed by U-86, with the loss of 234 lives.
A British ocean liner torpedoed and sunk by the German U-boat U-20.
An ocean liner torpedoed by German submarine U-48 near Fastnet Rock.

A cargo ship, wrecked off the coast of Inisheer, the smallest of the Aran Islands, and has since been thrown above high tide mark at Carraig na Finise. Islanders rescued the entire crew from the stricken vessel – an event captured in a pictorial display at the National Maritime Museum in Dún Laoghaire, County Dublin. The wreck appears in the opening credits of the comedy series Father Ted.

A Spanish container ship on charter to the Icelandic shipping company, Hafskip. It was washed onto rocks at Dunmore head, near Slea Head on the Dingle Peninsula after losing engine power in a storm. The 15 crew members were rescued by the local rocket team and an RAF helicopter. Some of the wreck was removed in 1991 due to filming, and the bow and other wreckage is still visible today.
The sinking of the Rochdale and the Prince of Wales in Dublin Bay resulted in 400 deaths and the building of a new harbour.
A vessel that ran aground near Cobh.
A crane barge that ran aground at Ardmore.
A White Star Line clipper that ran aground and sank off Lambay Island 8 kilometres (4.3 nmi) from Dublin Bay.
At 1,100 tonnes, one of the Spanish Armada's largest ships; wrecked 32 kilometres (17 nmi) west of Lacada Point in Kinnagoe Bay, County Donegal.
A fishing boat that sank 11 kilometres (5.9 nmi) off Kilkeel.
A Type U 66 submarine that was sunk by HMS Farnborough off Dingle.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled 6 kilometres (3.2 nmi) south of Glandore.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled as part of Operation Deadlight.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was surrendered to the Allies. It was towed offshore to be scuttled as part of Operation Deadlight, but sank before reaching the scuttling ground.
A Type IXC/40 U-boat that was surrendered to the British and sank under tow northwest of Tory Island.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled northwest of Malin Head as part of Operation Deadlight.
A Type IXD2 U-boat that was scuttled as part of Operation Deadlight.
A Type UC II submarine that was sunk by HMS PC61 in St. George's Channel.
A Type UC II submarine that sank for unknown reasons off Roche's Point.
A gunboat wrecked off Tory Island.
A Beagle-class destroyer that collided with Rosemary off Arranmore.
An East Indiaman that was deliberately mis-piloted by prisoners who had taken over another vessel.
A scallop dredger that sunk in a storm off Ramsey, and was later raised and laid up at Douglas.
The remains of a wooden barge discovered in Fiumicino.
A cargo ship that was sunk by U-21 north of Palermo, Sicily.
A cargo ship that developed a leak and sank south of Savona.

An unidentified ship carrying illegal immigrants to Sicily, sunk with the loss of at least 283 lives. For five years, the wreck's existence was kept from the authorities by local fishermen, who feared an investigation would interfere with their livelihood.
An Etruscan wreck off Giglio Island, dating to the early Iron Age, c. 600 BC.
A Giussano-class light cruiser that was sunk by HMS Urge off Stromboli.
A 230,000 GRT VLCC oil tanker that sunk off Genoa following an onboard explosion and fire, becoming the largest wreck in the Mediterranean Sea.
A Halcyon-class minesweeper that was sunk by a mine off Bari.
An I-class destroyer that was sunk by a German bomber off Nettuno.
A J-class destroyer that was sunk by a German torpedo bomber off Anzio.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by HMS Unruffled about 8 nautical miles (15 km) west of Capo Gallo, near Palermo, Sicily.
The wreck of a warship discovered in the harbour of Marsala in 1969, believed to date from around 235 BC.
Two large ships built by the Roman emperor Caligula at Lake Nemi in the 1st century AD. The wrecks were recovered from the lake in 1932, and largely destroyed by fire during World War II.
An Odin-class submarine that was sunk by Italian destroyers in the Gulf of Taranto.
A P-class destroyer that was damaged by Italian ships and scuttled off Mazara del Vallo.
An Auk-class minesweeper that was sunk by a mine off Nettuno.
An ocean liner that sank during its launch.
A Littorio-class battleship that was sunk by German aircraft off Asinara.
An SC-497-class submarine chaser that was sunk by German dive bombers off Palermo, Sicily.
A barque and convict ship that sank off Rio Marina.
A Dido-class cruiser that was sunk by German aircraft off Anzio.
An Auk-class minesweeper that was sunk by a mine off Anzio.
A T-class submarine that was sunk by the Italian corvette Cicogna off Sicily.
An ocean liner that was torpedoed by U-63 near Bergeggi Island, Savona.
A naval trawler that was sunk by American motor-torpedo boats off Deiva Marina.
A troopship that was sunk by Soviet bombers while carrying evacuees from Estonia. Nearly 2,700 out of 3,350 people aboard were killed.
A Type VIIC U-boat that collided with the target ship Angelburg west of Klaipėda.
A Royal Navy yacht that was sunk by mines laid by U-73
A D-class destroyer that ran aground on a breakwater outside Grand Harbour.
A Turkish cargo ship that took on water and sank off Malta due to bad weather.
A Gozo ferry that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A drifter converted into a minesweeper that struck a mine off Grand Harbour.
A Robust-class tugboat that was sunk by German or Italian aircraft at Grand Harbour, then raised and scuttled off Valletta.
An oil tanker which ran aground at Qawra on 10 February 2018, then deliberately scuttled as an artificial reef off Xatt l-Aħmar, Gozo in 2022.
A Gozo ferry that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A J-class destroyer that struck a mine off Grand Harbour.
A Captain Morgan ferry boat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A Hunt-class destroyer that struck a mine during Operation Harpoon.
The tour boat (formerly a minesweeper) that sunk off its moorings at Sliema.
A cable ship that was decommissioned and scuttled off the Grand Harbour.
A collier that was sunk by a torpedo fired by UC-22.
A Tribal-class destroyer that was sunk by German aircraft at Grand Harbour, then raised and scuttled off Valletta.
A French passenger ship that was sunk by German aircraft in Kalkara.
An Arabis-class sloop that was sunk by mines laid by U-73
An Odin-class submarine that was sunk by a mine.

FLAG: Maritime Squadron of the Armed Forces of Malta
NOTES: A Kondor I-class patrol boat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.

FLAG: Maritime Squadron of the Armed Forces of Malta
NOTES: A Kondor I-class patrol boat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.

FLAG: Maritime Squadron of the Armed Forces of Malta
NOTES: A Bremse-class patrol boat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A French passenger ship that was sunk by a torpedo fired by UC-22.
A tugboat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A Duncan-class predreadnought battleship that was sunk by mines laid by U-73
A German E-boat that was sunk by a mine (probably laid by herself or another E-boat).
One of six captured German E-boats that were scuttled off Marsaxlokk.
An Admiralty tugboat that struck a mine off Grand Harbour.
A Tanac type tugboat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A Hunt-class destroyer that hit a mine and sunk shortly after the Second Battle of Sirte.
An S-class submarine that was sunk as a target.
A tugboat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A Melita type tugboat that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.
A Libyan oil tanker that suffered an internal explosion on 3 February 1995, and remained at Valletta for three years before being scuttled as an artificial reef.
A fuel lighter that was sunk by German or Italian aircraft at Manoel Island.
A Gozo ferry that was decommissioned and scuttled as an artificial reef.

Fresnel was one of 18 Pluviôse-class submarines built for the French Navy (Marine Nationale) in the first decade of the 20th century. In 1915, while on close blockade duty off Cattaro, Fresnel was detected and pursued by Austrian warships and aircraft. She was driven aground at the mouth of the Bojana river near Ulcinj, scuttled and abandoned.
A paddle steamer that was confiscated by the occupying Italians during WWII, then seized and scuttled in Lake Skadar by members of the Yugoslav Partisans, an anti-Nazi resistance group.
A tanker that struck a mine off Terschelling.
A ferry that was sunk near Hook of Holland during a storm.
A troopship that struck a mine and was beached at the Zuid-Steenbank.
An E-class submarine that was sunk about 6 nautical miles (11 km) northwest of Texel.
A sloop that was sunk by German aircraft off Zijpe.
A Polish cargo ship sunk near Terschelling during a storm.
A Magicienne-class frigate that ran aground on a sandbank off Terschelling with a large cargo of gold.
A steamship that ran aground near the Nieuwe Waterweg.
A passenger ship that ran aground off Haamstede.
A Type U 5 U-boat that was sunk by friendly fire from U-22.
A Type UB III U-boat that was sunk by a mine off Vlieland.
A Type UC I U-boat that was torpedoed by HMS E54.

A Dutch East Indiaman that was lost after striking a sand bank off the coast of Vlissingen, Zeeland. Every one of the 461 sailors, soldiers and merchants aboard perished. The wreck was discovered in late 1981.
A Dutch East India Company ship that sank in a storm off Runde. In 1972, 57,000 gold and silver coins were recovered from the wreck.
A Type 1936-class destroyer that was sunk in the First Naval Battle of Narvik.
A tanker that was torpedoed by U-457 southwest of Bear Island.
A cargo liner that sunk by British aircraft about 2 nautical miles (3.7 km) west of Tranøy Lighthouse.
A Type 1934A-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A Bittern-class sloop that was sunk by German aircraft at Namsos.
A Norwegian steamship that was bombed during WWII at Rørvik.
An Admiral Hipper-class heavy cruiser that was sunk at the Battle of Drøbak Sound.
A Balao-class submarine that caught fire and sank off Hammerfest.
A C-class cruiser that was sunk by German aircraft in Ofotfjord.
A Type 1936-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A German steamer stranded 20 nautical miles (37 km) from Haugesund near Blikshavn, Island of Karmøy, whilst undertaking a cruise.
A troopship that was sunk by German aircraft near Gratangen.
A Hawkins-class heavy cruiser that struck a rock near Bodø and was scuttled.
An Eidsvold-class coastal defence ship that was torpedoed by German destroyers at Narvik.
A Type 1934A-class destroyer that was sunk by British ships in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A Type 1934A-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A minelayer that was scuttled while under attack from German forces in the Stjørnfjord.
A Draug-class destroyer that was sunk by German aircraft.
A deep-sea trawler sunk in the Barents Sea.
A Type 1934-class destroyer that was run aground in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A Grom-class destroyer that was bombed by German aircraft in Rombaken.
An iron steamship sunk in the Vestfjorden following collision with another ship.
A German fish factory transport ship sunk by a British destroyer in Lofoten.
A Type 1936-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
An H-class destroyer that was attacked by German destroyers and ran aground at Vidrek.
A civilian cargo ship that was sunk by a Royal Norwegian Navy torpedo boat off Kristiansund.
An H-class destroyer that was sunk by German destroyers in the First Battle of Narvik.
A Type 1936-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A civilian cargo liner that was sunk by a Royal Norwegian Navy torpedo boat off Kristiansund.
A Königsberg-class light cruiser that was torpedoed by HMS Truant and scuttled off Kristiansand.
A frigate wrecked off Hvaler in the Christmas flood of 1717.
A cargo ship that was sunk by U-4 in Skagerrak.
Soviet-era cruiser, grounded while being towed to India for scrapping.
A Norwegian steamship that grounded during WWII at Rørvik.
A troopship that was sunk by British warships at Hemnesberget.
An Eidsvold-class coastal defence ship that was sunk by the Z11 Bernd von Arnim at Narvik.
An O-class submarine that was used for an Arctic expedition and was later scuttled in Byfjorden.
An Odin-class submarine that was sunk by friendly fire from HMS Triton.
A cargo liner that was sunk by a New Zealand torpedo bomber, killing 986 people, most of them prisoners-of-war.
A passenger/cargo ship that sunk by German aircraft in the Norwegian Sea whilst carrying troops.

A prisoner-of-war transport that was sunk by Supermarine Seafire fighters and Fairey Firefly dive-bombers from the Royal Navy aircraft carrier HMS Implacable, south of Sandnessjøen, with 2,572 deaths.
A 1.-class torpedo boat that was sunk in action with German warships in the Hardangerfjord
A steamship that was sunk by 6 Bristol Beaufighters aircraft from the Canadian 404 Squadron off the islet of Buholmen.
A German Scharnhorst-class battleship sunk in the Battle of North Cape.
A cargo ship that was damaged in crossfire and sunk at Dvergsnestangen.
A Norwegian steamship that was bombed during WWII at Rørvik.
A cargo ship that was sunk by a German bomber off Dyrøya.
A Trygg-class torpedo boat that was sunk in action with German warships in the Hardangerfjord
A 1.-class torpedo boat that ran aground and sank in Hordaland
A T-class submarine that was torpedoed by U-4 off Stavanger.
A Bismarck-class battleship that was sunk by British aircraft off Tromsø in Operation Catechism.
A Type U 5 U-boat that was torpedoed by HMS E16 off Stavanger.
A Type VIIB U-boat that was sunk by HMS Fearless and HMS Brazen near Harstad.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by US aircraft at Trondheim.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by British aircraft off Harstad during Operation Judgement.
A Type VIIC U-boat that collided with German depot ship MRS 25 in the Vestfjorden.
A Type IXD2 U-boat that was scuttled by HMS Venturer while on a logistics mission to Japan.
A U-class submarine that ran into a minefield southwest of Fugløyvær.
A Type 1936-class destroyer that was sunk in the First Naval Battle of Narvik.
A Type 1934A-class destroyer that was scuttled in the Second Naval Battle of Narvik.
A German luxury passenger liner turned armoured transport ship that was torpedoed and sunk by Soviet submarine S-13.
Germany's only aircraft carrier in World War II, scuttled after the war by the Soviet Navy.
A Type VIIC U-boat that sank in a collision with Bolkoburg in Gdańsk Bay.
A Type IXC/40 U-boat that struck a mine north of Świnoujście.
A passenger ship on a rescue mission torpedoed and sunk by Soviet submarine S-13 in the Baltic Sea. Over 9,000 people were lost.
A cargo ship that ran aground off the Berlengas Islands.
An Apollo-class frigate that ran aground 9 nautical miles (17 km) south of Cape Mondego.
A freight vessel sunk off the coast of Sesimbra, in the early 20th century.
A Spanish war frigate sunk in the bay of Sesimbra.
A Portuguese Indiaman found at the mouth of the Tagus.
A Portuguese freight vessel sank off the coast of Cabo Espichel.
A Nigerian freight vessel sank off the coast of Cabo Espichel, Setubal.
A Confederate steamship that sank in the Angra do Heroísmo Bay.

SHIP: Spanish ship San Pedro de Alcantara
NOTES: A man-of-war that sank near Peniche with a cargo of treasure.
A République-class battleship that was torpedoed by U-52 off Lisbon.
A Type VIIC/41 U-boat that was scuttled off Porto.
A British steamboat sunk off the coast of Lisbon.
A ship sunk off the coast of Cascais, carrying Chinese ceramics, pepper and cowries.
Carrying Chinese and Burmese porcelain, pots and copper utensils, the caravel sunk in Porto Pim, (island of Faial) in the Azores during a storm, with a loss of 150 men.
Found in Lisbon in April 1995, during the excavation of a subway station.

A Greek cargo ship, ran ashore at Vama Veche. The crew was saved but the ship remained on the spot. For many years, it remained visible above the water, but decayed over time due to rust and waves. The shipwreck is now completely under the water.
A Greek freighter, grounded off Costinesti; part of an insurance fraud.
A Shchuka-class submarine that struck a mine 6 nautical miles (11 km) from Constanta.
An ocean liner that collided with the Pyotr Vasev in Tsemes Bay.
A British sailing vessel sunk in a collision with HMS Medina in the Black Sea near Balaklava.
A Soviet hospital ship sunk by German torpedo-carrying planes; estimated over 5,000 casualties.
A Flower-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-711 in the Kola Inlet.
A Russian cruise ship lost in a storm on the Volga River.
A Castle-class corvette that was torpedoed by U-992 and sank under tow in the Kola Inlet.
A Clemson-class destroyer that was sunk off the Murman Coast.

A Soviet-era submarine that accidentally sank while being towed for scrapping in the Barents Sea. She was decommissioned in 1989, prior to sinking, but both of her nuclear reactors are still on board.
Soviet submarine scuttled in the Kara Sea by the Soviet Navy. The boat had suffered irreparable nuclear reactor plant damage at sea in 1968. Both nuclear reactors are still on board.
A Tribal-class destroyer that was torpedoed by U-454 off Teriberka.
A cargo ship that was torpedoed by U-1163 near Semiostrovskiy Reid.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was sunk by three British frigates north of Murmansk.
A Type VIIC U-boat that was scuttled at Königsberg (now Kaliningrad) after taking damage in a Soviet air raid.
A Spanish España-class battleship sunk by a mine off Santander.
A King Edward VII-class battleship that was torpedoed by UB-50 off Cape Trafalgar.
A Spanish C-class submarine that was torpedoed by U-34 about 4 nautical miles (7.4 km) southeast of Málaga.
A warship that capsized in a storm off Cape Finisterre.
A cargo ship that caught fire and was grounded off Cape Finisterre.
A Royal Mail Ship that sank off the coast of Cape Finisterre after colliding with the Spanish steamship Yrurac Bat.
An Egret-class sloop sunk by enemy aircraft near Vigo.
A UK troopship sunk by UK torpedoes after German aerial bombardment left her burning.
A Balao-class submarine that was scuttled off Cartagena.
A November-class submarine that caught fire and sank while being towed in the Bay of Biscay. Four nuclear warheads and two nuclear reactors are still on board.
A Spanish Montañés-class ship of the line wrecked in the Bay of Cádiz.
A merchant ship that sank off Ribadesella. It lies on sand at a depth of 50 metres (160 ft).
An oil tanker that sank off Galicia.
An Italian merchant steamship which ran aground on a reef off Cape Palos and the Hormigas Islands off the Spanish coast, killing hundreds of migrants to Argentina.
A German Type IXB U-boat sunk by enemy aircraft off Cape Ortegal.
A German Type IID U-boat sunk by depth charges off Cadiz.
A German Type VIIC U-boat sunk by depth charges off Cape Ortegal.
A German Type VIIC U-boat sunk off Isla de Alborán.
A German Type VIIC U-boat sunk off Cartagena.
A Spanish steamship that sank off the coast of Cape Finisterre after colliding with RMS Douro.
An Italian liner that sank near Koper after being hit by rockets fired by RAF aircraft.
A cargo ship that collided with SS Normandie off Dalarö.
A shipwreck discovered in 2003 off Dalarö.
A RORO ferry that capsized in a storm.
Warship discovered in the 1970s, one of the best-preserved wrecks from the late medieval period.
A towboat that foundered in heavy weather and was wrecked near Grundkallen.
A cargo ship that capsized 5 nautical miles (9.3 km) off Sandhammaren.
The largest warship in the Swedish navy during the Scanian War. It sank in rough weather in the Battle of Öland, and was rediscovered in 1980.
A wreck in Luleå Northern Harbour measuring 7m by 20m made from wood dated to approximately 1700. Discovered during the Sailing World Cup held in Luleå in 1988 and dated in 2011.
A Swedish warship that was sunk 18 kilometres north of Öland during the Northern Seven Years' War.
A Soviet S-class submarine that hit a mine west of Åland.
A Soviet S-class submarine that was torpedoed by Vesihiisi off Stockholm.
A Som-class submarine that sank in a collision in the Sea of Åland.
A three-masted schooner, built 1902, that sank in a storm off the coast of Öland.
A Swedish warship that foundered on her maiden voyage and sank in Stockholm.
A prisoner transport that was sunk by a mine off Marstrand.
A Conte di Cavour-class battleship that exploded in Sevastopol Bay, resulting in 608 deaths.
A steam frigate that was grounded in the Crimean War 5 nautical miles (9.3 km) southwest of Odessa.
